--Word--
n 
--Type--
abbreviation
UnKnownKind, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
(in units of measurement) nano- (10⁻⁹)
Neuter.
Normal (denoting straight-chain hydrocarbons)
Note (used in a book's index to refer to a footnote)
Noun.
An unspecified or variable number.
(used in recording moves in chess) knight.
(on a gear lever) neutral.
(chiefly in place names) New.
Newton(s).
(with reference to solutions) normal.
North or Northern.
Norway (international vehicle registration).
Nuclear.
The chemical element nitrogen.
The fourteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after M in a set of items, categories, etc.
--Examples--
‘500 ng’
‘n-hexane’
‘450n’
‘at the limit where n equals infinity’
‘17.Na4?’
‘N Zealand’
‘the pH was adjusted to 7.0 with 1 N HCl’
‘78° N’
‘N Ireland’
‘the N bomb’

--Word--
nabism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Art. In form Nabism. The artistic theories or style of the Nabis.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nabataean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient Arabian people who from 312 BC formed an independent kingdom with its capital at Petra (now in Jordan). The kingdom was allied to the Roman Empire from 63 BC and incorporated as the province of Arabia in AD 106.
The extinct language of the Nabataeans, a form of Aramaic strongly influenced by Arabic.
Relating to the Nabataeans or their language.
--Examples--

A member of an ancient Arabian people who from 312 BC formed an independent kingdom with its capital at Petra (now in Jordan). The kingdom was allied to the Roman Empire from 63 BC and incorporated as the province of Arabia in AD 106.

Relating to the Nabataeans or their language.

Nabi Group 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of late 19th-century French painters, largely symbolist in their approach and heavily indebted to Gauguin. Members of the group included Maurice Denis, Pierre Bonnard, and Édouard Vuillard.
--Examples--
--Word--
nabk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two thorny shrubs or small trees of the genus Ziziphus (family Rhamnaceae) that are native to the Middle East and North Africa, Z. lotus and Z. spina-christi. Also "†nabk-thorn", "nabk-tree".

Nabokov, Vladimir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1977), Russian-born American novelist and poet; full name Vladimir Vladimirovich Nabokov. He is best known for Lolita (1955), his novel about a middle-aged man's obsession with a twelve-year-old girl.

Nabothian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
"Nabothian cyst"noun a cyst containing secreted fluid which forms following obstruction of a mucous gland of the uterine cervix. Also "Nabothian follicle", "†Nabothian gland".

Comaneci, Nadia

--Meanings--

Gordimer, Nadine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1923–2014), South African novelist and short-story writer. Her experience of the effects of apartheid underlies much of her work. Notable novels: The Conservationist (Booker Prize, 1974). Nobel Prize for Literature (1991).

--Word--
nag 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Harass (someone) constantly to do something that they are averse to.
Be persistently painful or worrying to.
A person who nags someone to do something.
A persistent feeling of anxiety.
A horse, especially one that is old or in poor health.
A horse suitable for riding rather than as a draught animal.
--Examples--
‘she constantly nags her daughter about getting married’
‘she nagged him to do the housework’
‘he's always nagging at her for staying out late’
‘something nagged at the back of his mind’
‘he felt a little nag of doubt’
‘the old nag the lad fetched smelled sweaty’
--Word--
naga 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A member of a group of peoples living in or near the Naga Hills of Burma (Myanmar) and north-eastern India.
Any of the Tibeto-Burman languages of the Nagas, with about 340,000 speakers altogether.
Relating to the Nagas or their language.
(in Indian mythology) a member of a semi-divine race, part human, part cobra in form, associated with water and sometimes with mystical initiation.
(in some Hindu sects) a naked wandering ascetic, in particular one belonging to a sect whose members carry arms and serve as mercenaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
nagaika 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short, thick, plaited leather whip, probably of Nogai origin, traditionally used in Russia (especially by Cossacks).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nagaland 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the far north-east of India, on the border with Burma (Myanmar); capital, Kohima. It was created in 1962 from parts of Assam.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nagami 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "Nagami kumquat". The oval or oblong fruit of a cultivated type of kumquat of the species Fortunella margarita; the shrub or small tree bearing this fruit.
--Examples--
--Word--
nagana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of cattle, antelope, and other livestock in southern Africa, characterized by fever, lethargy, and oedema, and caused by trypanosome parasites transmitted by the tsetse fly.
--Examples--

--Type--

Nagasaki 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Harass (someone) constantly to do something that they are averse to.
Be persistently painful or worrying to.
A person who nags someone to do something.

Nagy, Imre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1958), Hungarian communist statesman, prime minister 1953–5 and 1956. In 1956 he withdrew Hungary from the Warsaw Pact, seeking neutral status for it. He was executed after the Red Army crushed the uprising later that year.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
A monoclinic (pseudotetragonal) telluride, antimonide, and sulphide of lead and gold, occurring as dark grey tabular crystals.

adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) constantly harassing someone to do something.
Persistently painful or worrying.
--Examples--
‘jokes about nagging wives and tyrannous mothers-in-law’
‘a nagging pain’
‘only a handful of nagging doubts remained’
--Word--
nagsman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A skilled horseman who is employed to train or show horses.
--Examples--
--Word--
nag 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Harass (someone) constantly to do something that they are averse to.
Be persistently painful or worrying to.
A person who nags someone to do something.
A persistent feeling of anxiety.
A horse, especially one that is old or in poor health.
A horse suitable for riding rather than as a draught animal.
--Examples--
‘she constantly nags her daughter about getting married’
‘she nagged him to do the housework’
‘he's always nagging at her for staying out late’
‘something nagged at the back of his mind’
‘he felt a little nag of doubt’
‘the old nag the lad fetched smelled sweaty’
--Word--
nagual 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Among certain indigenous peoples of Mexico and surrounding countries: a guardian spirit in animal form, believed to accompany and guide an individual through life; an animal form believed to be assumed by a human through magical or supernatural means.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nagualism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Among certain indigenous peoples of Mexico and surrounding countries: belief in a personal guardian spirit residing or embodied in a particular animal, etc.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of peoples native to southern Mexico and Central America, including the Aztecs.
The Uto-Aztecan language of the Nahuatl, which has over 1 million speakers.
Relating to the Nahuatl or their language.

nay

adverb, noun

No.

--Word--
naiad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in classical mythology) a water nymph said to inhabit a river, spring, or waterfall.
The aquatic larva or nymph of a dragonfly, mayfly, or stonefly.
A submerged aquatic plant with narrow leaves and minute flowers.

--Word--
nail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small metal spike with a broadened flat head, driven into wood to join things together or to serve as a hook.
A horny covering on the upper surface of the tip of the finger and toe in humans and other primates.
An animal's claw.
A hard growth on the upper mandible of some soft-billed birds.
A medieval measure of length for cloth, equal to 21/4 inches.
A medieval measure of wool, beef, or other commodity, roughly equal to 7 or 8 pounds.
Fasten with a nail or nails.
Detect or catch (someone, especially a suspected criminal)
Expose (a lie or other deception)
(of a player) strike (a ball) forcefully and successfully.
(of a fielder) put (a runner) out by throwing to a base.
(of a player) defeat or outwit (an opponent)
(of a player) secure (a victory) conclusively.
Perform (an action or task) perfectly.
(of a man) have sexual intercourse with.
--Examples--
‘don't try and hammer nails into the ceiling joists’
‘a masonry nail’
‘she began to bite her nails’
‘a pair of nail clippers’
‘the clicking of a dog's nails on a wooden floor’
‘the strips are simply nailed to the roof’
‘have you nailed the killer?’
‘he spoke out to nail the lie that he'd had a row with his manager’
‘she was stretched to the limit and failed to nail the smash’
‘he muffed a perfect throw home that should have nailed Slo-Joe by yards’
‘Navratilova tried to nail her on the backhand side’
‘I fancy the Scots to nail a win’
‘she absolutely nailed the high notes’
‘I guess they were indeed impressed (nailed it!)’
--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

--Type--
adjective

noun

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Naismith, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1861–1939), Canadian-American physical education teacher. He invented the game of basketball in 1891, while teaching at the International YMCA Training School in Springfield, Massachusetts. Basketball Hall of Fame (1959).

naive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or action) showing a lack of experience, wisdom, or judgement.
(of a person) natural and unaffected; innocent.
Of or denoting art produced in a style which deliberately rejects sophisticated artistic techniques and has a bold directness resembling a child's work, typically in bright colours with little or no perspective.
--Examples--
‘the rather naive young man had been totally misled’
‘Andy had a sweet, naive look when he smiled’

naked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or part of the body) without clothes.
(of an object) without the usual covering or protection.
(of a tree, plant, or animal) without leaves, hairs, scales, etc.
Devoid of.
Exposed to harm; vulnerable.
(especially of feelings or behaviour) expressed openly; undisguised.
--Examples--
‘he'd never seen a naked woman before’
‘he was stripped naked’
‘her room was lit by a single naked bulb’
‘the naked branches of the trees’
‘areas of skin naked of feathers’
‘John looked naked and defenceless without his spectacles’
‘naked fear made him tremble’
‘the naked truth’

(especially of feelings or behaviour) expressed openly; undisguised.
--Examples--
‘he'd never seen a naked woman before’
‘he was stripped naked’
‘her room was lit by a single naked bulb’
‘the naked branches of the trees’
‘areas of skin naked of feathers’
‘John looked naked and defenceless without his spectacles’
‘naked fear made him tremble’
‘the naked truth’

‘a quick-footed American chappie’

nalorphine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A synthetic opioid similar to morphine in chemical structure, which acts as a mixed opioid antagonist and agonist and formerly was used in the diagnosis and treatment of narcotic abuse and overdosage; (−)-(5R,6S)-9a-allyl-4,5-epoxymorphin-7-en-3,6-diol, C₁₉H₂₁NO₃. [A trademark for this drug in the United States is Nalline.]

Nam 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Nama 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of one of the Khoikhoi peoples of South Africa and south-western Namibia. Traditionally nomadic herders and hunter-gatherers, they were displaced from the region near the Cape by Dutch settlers.
The language of the Nama, which belongs to the Khoisan family and is the only language of the Khoikhoi peoples still spoken by a substantial number (over 100,000).
Relating to the Nama or their language.

Namaqualand 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of south-western Africa, the homeland of the Nama people. Little Namaqualand lies immediately to the south of the Orange River and is in the South African province of Northern Cape, while Great Namaqualand lies to the north of the river, in Namibia.

--Word--
name 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A word or set of words by which a person or thing is known, addressed, or referred to.
A famous person.
A reputation, especially a good one.
(in the UK) an insurance underwriter belonging to a Lloyd's syndicate.
Give a name to.
Identify correctly by name.
Give a particular title or epithet to.
Mention by name.
Appoint (someone) to a particular position or task.
(of the Speaker) mention (a Member of Parliament) by name as disobedient to the chair and thereby subject to a ban from the House.
Specify (a sum, time, or place) as something desired, suggested, or decided on.
(of a person or product) having a well-known name.
--Examples--
‘my name is John Parsons’
‘Köln is the German name for Cologne’
‘the big race will lure the top names’
‘the school has gained a name for excellence’
‘hundreds of diseases had not yet been isolated or named’
‘she decided to name the child Edward’
‘the dead man has been named as John Mackintosh’
‘she was named as Student of the Year’
‘the sea is as crystal clear as any spot in the Caribbean you might care to name’
‘he was named to head a joint UN–OAS diplomatic effort’
‘the club have asked United to name their price for the striker’
‘specialized name brands geared to niche markets’

--Word--
nameless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having no name or no known name.
Deliberately not identified; anonymous.
(of a child) illegitimate.
(especially of an emotion) not easy to describe; indefinable.
Too horrific to be described.
--Examples--
‘some pictures were taken by a nameless photographer’
‘the clinic was situated in a little nameless square off James Street’
‘the director of an organization which shall remain nameless’
‘his grandfather had been a nameless, parentless child’
‘a nameless yearning for transcendence’
‘the myths talk about nameless horrors infesting our universe’

--Word--
Nanak 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1469–1539), Indian religious leader and founder of Sikhism; known as Guru Nanak. Not seeking to create a new religion, he preached that spiritual liberation could be achieved through meditating on the name of God. His teachings are contained in a number of hymns which form part of the Guru Granth Sahib.

NAND 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Boolean operator which gives the value zero if and only if all the operands have a value of one, and otherwise has a value of one (equivalent to NOT AND).

--Meanings--
Very small unicellular plankton, at the limits of resolution of light microscopy.
--Examples--

nanosecond 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One thousand-millionth of a second.
A very short time; a moment.
--Examples--
‘she can flick between manic laughter and tears in a nanosecond’
--Word--
nanosecond 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One thousand-millionth of a second.
A very short time; a moment.
--Examples--
‘she can flick between manic laughter and tears in a nanosecond’

--Word--
Nanticoke 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a North American Indian people, formerly inhabiting the area of the Nanticoke River on the Eastern Shore of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland and Delaware. Later, also (in extended use): of, relating to, or designating a confederacy of closely related peoples residing on the Eastern Shore, including the Nanticoke, Choptank, and others.
A member of the Nanticoke people. Later, also (in extended use): a member of the Nanticoke confederacy.
The extinct Eastern Algonquian language spoken by the Nanticoke and neighbouring groups until the mid-19th cent.

noun
--Meanings--

naphthalene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A volatile white crystalline compound produced by the distillation of coal tar, used in mothballs and as a raw material for chemical manufacture.
--Examples--
--Word--
naphthaleneacetic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two crystalline isomers, C₁₀H₇CH₂COOH, obtained by replacing one of the hydrogen atoms of naphthalene by an acetic acid group; specifically (more fully "α-naphthaleneacetic acid") one which has the action of an auxin and is used to stimulate the rooting of plant cuttings, to initiate flowering of the pineapple, to prevent premature drop of fruit, and to improve the colour of apples.

--Word--
naphthoquinone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of six isomeric compounds, C₁₀H₆O₂, notionally obtained by replacing two of the ≧CH groups of naphthalene by carbonyl groups; specifically (more fully "1,4-naphthoquinone", "α-naphthoquinone") a volatile yellow solid whose molecule forms part of the structure of vitamin K.

--Meanings--
A seaport on Hawke Bay, in the North Island, New Zealand; population 55,359 (2006). Originally a whaling port, the town was named after the British general and colonial administrator Sir Charles Napier (1809–54).

Naples 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
napoleon 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A gold twenty-franc French coin minted in the reign of Napoleon I.
A boot worn by men in the 19th century, reaching above the knee in front and with a piece cut out behind.
A flaky rectangular pastry with a sweet filling.
The name of three rulers of France.
Napoleon I (1769–1821), emperor 1804–14 and 1815; full name Napoleon Bonaparte; known as Napoleon. In 1799 Napoleon joined a conspiracy which overthrew the Directory, becoming the supreme ruler of France. He declared himself emperor in 1804, and established an empire stretching from Spain to Poland. After defeats at Trafalgar (1805) and in Russia (1812), he abdicated and was exiled to the island of Elba (1814). He returned to power in 1815, but was defeated at Waterloo and exiled to the island of St Helena.
Napoleon II (1811–1832), son of Napoleon I and Empress Marie-Louise; full name Napoleon François Charles Joseph Bonaparte. In 1814 Napoleon I abdicated on behalf of himself and Napoleon II, who had no active political role.
Napoleon III (1808–73), emperor 1852–70; full name Charles Louis Napoleon Bonaparte; known as Louis-Napoleon. A nephew of Napoleon I, Napoleon III was elected president of the Second Republic in 1848 and staged a coup in 1851. He abdicated in 1870 after defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.
--Examples--
--Word--
Napoleonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Napoleon I or his time.
--Examples--

Napoleonically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a style resembling or a manner characteristic of Napoleon I.

--Word--
Napoleonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attachment to or support for the policy or dynasty of the Napoleons.
The policies or principles of Napoleon I or Napoleon III; specifically the method of government associated with Napoleon I; the assumption of absolute control over subject peoples or countries.
Conduct or behaviour likened to that of Napoleon I.
--Examples--
--Word--
Napoleonist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A supporter of Napoleon I or the Napoleonic dynasty.
Of or relating to Napoleon I or the Napoleonic dynasty. In quot. 1989 in extended use: radical; romantically revolutionary. Compare "Bonapartist", "Napoleonic", Napoleonistic. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Napoleonistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Napoleon I or his policies.
--Examples--

napoleonite

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
napoleon 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A gold twenty-franc French coin minted in the reign of Napoleon I.
A boot worn by men in the 19th century, reaching above the knee in front and with a piece cut out behind.
A flaky rectangular pastry with a sweet filling.
The name of three rulers of France.
Napoleon I (1769–1821), emperor 1804–14 and 1815; full name Napoleon Bonaparte; known as Napoleon. In 1799 Napoleon joined a conspiracy which overthrew the Directory, becoming the supreme ruler of France. He declared himself emperor in 1804, and established an empire stretching from Spain to Poland. After defeats at Trafalgar (1805) and in Russia (1812), he abdicated and was exiled to the island of Elba (1814). He returned to power in 1815, but was defeated at Waterloo and exiled to the island of St Helena.
Napoleon II (1811–1832), son of Napoleon I and Empress Marie-Louise; full name Napoleon François Charles Joseph Bonaparte. In 1814 Napoleon I abdicated on behalf of himself and Napoleon II, who had no active political role.
Napoleon III (1808–73), emperor 1852–70; full name Charles Louis Napoleon Bonaparte; known as Louis-Napoleon. A nephew of Napoleon I, Napoleon III was elected president of the Second Republic in 1848 and staged a coup in 1851. He abdicated in 1870 after defeat in the Franco-Prussian War.

noun, adjective

Obstinacy or disobedience on the part of a horse.

--Word--
nar 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
In attributive use. That is the nearer of two things or people; (also, in Old English) †later in time (obsolete). In Old English also as noun In later use: left-hand; chiefly in "nar horse", "nar leg", "nar side".
Near, close.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nara 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in central Japan, on the island of Honshu; population 367,902 (2007). It was the first capital of Japan (710–84) and an important centre of Japanese Buddhism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Narayan, R. K. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–2001), Indian novelist and short-story writer; full name Rasipuram Krishnaswamy Narayan. His best-known novels are set in an imaginary small Indian town, and portray its inhabitants in an affectionate yet ironic manner; they include Swami and Friends (1935) and The Man-Eater of Malgudi (1961).
--Examples--
--Word--
Narayanganj 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river port in Bangladesh, on the Ganges delta south-east of Dhaka; population 286,899 (2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
Narbonne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern France, in Languedoc-Roussillon, just inland from the Mediterranean; population 51,996 (2006). Founded by the Romans, it was capital of the province of Gallic Narbonensis. It was a prosperous port until its harbour silted up in the 14th century.

--Word--
narcissus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A bulbous Eurasian plant of a genus that includes the daffodil, especially (in gardening) one with flowers that have white or pale outer petals and a shallow orange or yellow cup in the centre.
A beautiful youth who rejected the nymph Echo and fell in love with his own reflection in a pool. He pined away and was changed into the flower that bears his name.
--Examples--
--Word--
narcissine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or resembling Narcissus, the youth of Greek mythology; loving or admiring oneself excessively, narcissistic.
--Examples--
--Word--
narcissism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's physical appearance.
Extreme selfishness, with a grandiose view of one's own talents and a craving for admiration, as characterizing a personality type.
Self-centredness arising from failure to distinguish the self from external objects, either in very young babies or as a feature of mental disorder.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
narcoleptic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Affected by or relating to an extreme tendency to fall asleep.
Tending to induce sleep; soporific.
A person affected by an extreme tendency to fall asleep.
--Examples--
‘he is narcoleptic, so he takes a drug that helps keep him awake’
‘a narcoleptic coma’
‘narcoleptic drugs’
‘a plot so tired it's narcoleptic’
‘a narcoleptic who falls asleep up against the wall’
--Word--
narcomania 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally (in the terminology of N. Kerr): uncontrollable craving for intoxication by alcohol or narcotic drugs (now disused). Later: addiction to or abuse of narcotic drugs.
--Examples--

narcomaniac 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who craves narcotic drugs; a drug addict.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

narcosynthesis

noun

narcosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A state of stupor, drowsiness, or unconsciousness produced by drugs.
--Examples--
‘the patient was treated in prone position without narcosis’
--Word--
narcotic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An addictive drug affecting mood or behaviour, especially an illegal one.
A drug which induces drowsiness, stupor, or insensibility, and relieves pain.
Relating to or denoting narcotics or their effects or use.
--Examples--
‘cultivation of a plant used to make a popular local narcotic’
‘pethidine, usually given as an injection, is a narcotic which causes drowsiness’
‘the substance has a mild narcotic effect’

--Word--
irritant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance that causes slight inflammation or other discomfort to the body.
A thing that is continually annoying or distracting.
Causing slight inflammation or other discomfort to the body.
--Examples--
‘a powerful skin irritant’
‘in 1966 Vietnam was becoming an irritant to the government’
‘chlorine bleaches can be irritant to the skin’
--Word--
narcotic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An addictive drug affecting mood or behaviour, especially an illegal one.
A drug which induces drowsiness, stupor, or insensibility, and relieves pain.
Relating to or denoting narcotics or their effects or use.
--Examples--
‘cultivation of a plant used to make a popular local narcotic’
‘pethidine, usually given as an injection, is a narcotic which causes drowsiness’
‘the substance has a mild narcotic effect’
--Word--
narcotine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two stereoisomeric crystalline alkaloids of the formula C₂₂H₂₃NO₇; specifically (more fully "α-narcotine") the one occurring in opium and formerly used medicinally.
--Examples--
--Word--
narcotization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
narcotize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Affect with or as if with a narcotic drug.
Make (something) have a soporific or narcotic effect.
--Examples--
‘they wanted to narcotize you so you wouldn't be sensitive to them’
‘the essence of apple blossom narcotizes the air’

--Word--
nardoo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Australian fern with long stalks bearing either silvery-green clover-like lobes or woody globular cases containing spores, growing typically in water in areas of intermittent flooding.
A food made from the spores of the nardoo, traditionally eaten by Aborigines.
--Examples--
‘nardoo flour’

nardus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany (In form Nardus) a monotypic genus of the family Gramineae, comprising mat-grass, Nardus stricta; (also nardus) the plant mat-grass (also "nardus grass").

--Word--
Narmada 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river which rises in Madhya Pradesh, central India, and flows generally westwards for 1,245 km (778 miles) to the Gulf of Cambay. It is regarded by Hindus as sacred.
--Examples--
--Word--
narra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall, rapidly-growing tree of South-East Asia, Pterocarpus indicus (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)), which bears panicles of fragrant orange or yellow fruit. Also: the decorative wood of this tree, used for cabinetmaking (also called amboyna wood, Andaman redwood, Burmese rosewood, etc.).
--Examples--

--Word--
narrative 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A spoken or written account of connected events; a story.
The narrated part of a literary work, as distinct from dialogue.
The practice or art of telling stories.
A representation of a particular situation or process in such a way as to reflect or conform to an overarching set of aims or values.
In the form of or concerned with narration.
--Examples--
‘a gripping narrative’
‘the dialogue and the narrative suffer from awkward syntax’
‘traditions of oral narrative’
‘the coalition's carefully constructed narrative about its sensitivity to recession victims’
‘a narrative poem’
‘narrative technique’

--Word--
narrow 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Of small width in relation to length.
Limited in extent, amount, or scope.
(of a person's attitude or beliefs) limited in range and unwilling or unable to appreciate alternative views.
Precise or strict in meaning.
(of a phonetic transcription) showing fine details of accent.
Denoting or relating to a contest that is won or lost by only a very small margin.
Denoting a vowel pronounced with the root of the tongue drawn back so as to narrow the pharynx.
Become or make less wide.
Almost close (one's eyes) so as to focus on something, or to indicate anger or other emotion.
Become or make more limited in extent or scope.
A narrow channel connecting two larger areas of water.
narrow something down
Reduce the number of possibilities or options.
--Examples--
‘he made his way down the narrow road’
‘they ate a narrow range of foods’
‘companies fail through their narrow view of what contributes to profit’
‘the idea of nationalism in the narrowest sense of the word’
‘the home team just hung on for a narrow victory’
‘the road narrowed and crossed an old bridge’
‘the Victoria Embankment was built to narrow the river’
‘she narrowed her eyes at him suspiciously’
‘her eyes narrowed as she looked at him’
‘the gap between the sexes is narrowing’
‘the trade surplus narrowed to £70 m in January’
‘the committee narrowed the selection to three designers’
‘there was a car ferry across the narrows of Loch Long’
‘the company has narrowed down the candidates for the job to two’

(of a phonetic transcription) showing fine details of accent.
Denoting or relating to a contest that is won or lost by only a very small margin.
Denoting a vowel pronounced with the root of the tongue drawn back so as to narrow the pharynx.
Become or make less wide.
Almost close (one's eyes) so as to focus on something, or to indicate anger or other emotion.
Become or make more limited in extent or scope.
A narrow channel connecting two larger areas of water.
narrow something down
Reduce the number of possibilities or options.
--Examples--
‘he made his way down the narrow road’
‘they ate a narrow range of foods’
‘companies fail through their narrow view of what contributes to profit’
‘the idea of nationalism in the narrowest sense of the word’
‘the home team just hung on for a narrow victory’
‘the road narrowed and crossed an old bridge’
‘the Victoria Embankment was built to narrow the river’
‘she narrowed her eyes at him suspiciously’
‘her eyes narrowed as she looked at him’
‘the gap between the sexes is narrowing’
‘the trade surplus narrowed to £70 m in January’
‘the committee narrowed the selection to three designers’
‘there was a car ferry across the narrows of Loch Long’
‘the company has narrowed down the candidates for the job to two’

--Word--
meshed 
--Type--
adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
Having the form or appearance of a mesh or network.
(of a geometric object) represented by an arrangement of a finite number of geometric components.
(of a computer network) consisting of nodes which are each linked to the network via two or more connections, each node typically being connected (directly or indirectly) to every other node.
--Examples--
‘a meshed grille’
‘fine-meshed sieves’
‘a meshed sphere’
‘meshed wireless networks’

narrowness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Small width in relation to length.
Limited extent, amount, or scope.
Limited willingness or ability to appreciate alternative views.
The fact of a victory being achieved with only a small margin.
--Examples--
‘the narrowness of the tunnels deters many from entering’
‘concerns about the narrowness of the roads’
‘education has to compensate for the narrowness of local horizons’
‘a weakness of his work is the narrowness of the sources’
‘this distasteful reference revealed the narrowness of his outlook’
‘narrowness of vision and understanding’
‘the narrowness of the vote shows there is everything to fight for’
‘there is a warning in the narrowness of the victory’

nasal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the nose.
(of a speech sound) pronounced by the breath resonating in the nose, e.g. m, n, ng, or French en, un.
(of the voice or speech) produced or characterized by resonation in the nose as well as the mouth.
A nasal speech sound.
A nosepiece on a helmet.
--Examples--
‘the nasal passages’
‘a nasal spray’
‘a drawling nasal voice’

--Word--
Naseby, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A major battle of the English Civil War, which took place in 1645 near the village of Naseby in Northamptonshire. The Royalist army of Prince Rupert and King Charles I was decisively defeated by the New Model Army under General Fairfax and Oliver Cromwell.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nash, Richard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1674–1762), Welsh dandy; known as Beau Nash. He was an arbiter of fashion and etiquette in the early Georgian age.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nashe, Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1567–1601), English pamphleteer, prose writer, and playwright. Notable works: The Unfortunate Traveller (1594).

Nasmyth, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1808–90), Scottish engineer. He invented the steam hammer (1839).

--Word--
nasociliary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to a branch of the ophthalmic nerve that supplies the skin and mucous membrane of the nose, the eyelids, and parts of the eyeball, and connects with the ciliary ganglion.

nasofrontal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the nasal and frontal bones.

nasolabial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the nose and upper lip; specifically designating a pair of folds in the skin between the nose and the corners of the mouth.

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
nasologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: an expert in or proponent of nasology (now rare). Later (also): a rhinologist (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
nason 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of flute-stop in an organ, often of oak, introduced to England by the organ-builder Bernard Smith (1630–1708) in the late 17th cent.
--Examples--
--Word--
nasonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trigonal silicate and chloride of calcium and lead, Ca₄Pb₆(Si₂O₇)₃Cl₂, which forms prismatic crystals and occurs as white or grey granular masses.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
= nasopalatine.

nasopalatine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

nasopharyngeal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the upper part of the pharynx, connecting with the nasal cavity above the soft palate.
--Examples--
‘the roof of the nasopharyngeal cavity’
‘nasopharyngeal carcinoma’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

nasoturbinal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Nassa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †a genus of carnivorous marine gastropods of the family Nassariidae which includes some dog whelks (obsolete: see note). Subsequently also: a genus of marine gastropods of the family Muricidae. Also (occasionally with lower-case initial): a mollusc of either of these genera; (also, in "nassa shell") the shell of such a mollusc.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nassau 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A former duchy of western Germany, centred on the small town of Nassau, from which a branch of the House of Orange arose. It corresponds to parts of the present-day states of Hesse and Rhineland-Palatinate.
A port on the island of New Providence, capital of the Bahamas; population 240,000 (est. 2007).
An eighteen-hole match in which the players bet on the first nine holes, the second nine holes, and the entire round.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nasser, Lake 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A lake in south-eastern Egypt that was created in the 1960s by building two dams on the Nile River at Aswan.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nast, Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1840–1902), US political cartoonist; born in Germany. He was a staff artist at Harper's Weekly 1861–86 and creator of the Republican elephant and the Democratic donkey symbols, as well as of the US image of Santa Claus.
--Examples--
--Word--
nastaliq 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A Persian script developed in the 14th–15th cent., combining features of the naskhi and taliq scripts and characterized by curving forms and groups of connected letters written sloping slightly downwards.
Of, relating to, or designating this script.
--Examples--
--Word--
nasty 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Very bad or unpleasant.
(of the weather) unpleasantly cold or wet.
Repugnant to the mind.
Behaving in an unpleasant or spiteful way.
Annoying or unwelcome.
Damaging or harmful.
An unpleasant or harmful person or thing.
A horror video or film.
--Examples--
‘plastic bags burn with a nasty, acrid smell’
‘dad's had a nasty accident’
‘it's a nasty old night’
‘her stories are very nasty, full of murder and violence’
‘Harry was a nasty, foul-mouthed old devil’
‘life has a nasty habit of repeating itself’
‘a nasty, vicious-looking hatchet’
‘a water conditioner to neutralize chlorine and other nasties’
--Word--
nastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of the movement of plant parts) caused by an external stimulus but unaffected in direction by it.
--Examples--

--Word--
nasus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An elongated rostrum on the head of soldier termites of the subfamily Nasutiterminae, through which a sticky defensive fluid can be sprayed.
--Examples--
--Word--
nasute 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. Nose-shaped; having a pronounced proboscis; (Entomology) of or designating a caste of soldier termites of the genus Nasutitermes or the subfamily Nasutitermitinae, which have a nasus; of or designating a termite genus or species characterized by such soldiers.
A nasute termite.
--Examples--
--Word--
nasute 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. Nose-shaped; having a pronounced proboscis; (Entomology) of or designating a caste of soldier termites of the genus Nasutitermes or the subfamily Nasutitermitinae, which have a nasus; of or designating a termite genus or species characterized by such soldiers.
A nasute termite.

--Word--
Nat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who advocates political independence for a particular country.
A member or supporter of a political party called the National Party.
--Examples--
‘winning the seat in central Scotland would give the Nats a massive psychological boost’
‘the Nats had the most members, followed by Labor’
--Word--
pro re nata 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
For an occasion as it arises; extempore, without prior provision; as required, as needed.
Of a meeting, council, etc.: extraordinary, held or called to deal with a specific matter. Also more generally: resulting from or responding to particular circumstances.
--Examples--
--Word--
natal 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the place or time of one's birth.
Relating to the buttocks.
A former province of South Africa, situated on the east coast. Having been a Boer republic and then a British colony, Natal acquired internal self-government in 1893 and became a province of the Union of South Africa in 1910. It was renamed KwaZulu-Natal in 1994.
A port on the Atlantic coast of north-eastern Brazil, capital of the state of Rio Grande do Norte; population 774,230 (2007).
--Examples--
‘he was living in the south, many miles from his natal city’
‘the natal cleft’
--Word--
Natalian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or relating to Natal, formerly a colony, South African province, and, since 1994, a part of the province of KwaZulu-Natal, located on the east coast of South Africa. Now rare.
A native or inhabitant of Natal, or (now) of KwaZulu-Natal.
--Examples--
--Word--
Wood, Natalie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1938–81), American actress. She played the vulnerable adolescent heroine of Rebel Without A Cause (1955), and similar roles in Cry in the Night (1956), West Side Story (1961), and Inside Daisy Clover (1966).

--Word--
Natchez 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A historic port city on the Mississippi River in southwestern Mississippi; population 16,413 (est. 2008). The Natchez Trace, which leads from here to Nashville in Tennessee, was a 19th-century route for riverboatmen returning north from trips to New Orleans.

El Nath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The star α Arietis, the brightest star of the constellation Aries; (Astrology) the first mansion of the moon.
The star β Tauri, the second brightest star of the constellation Taurus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Sarraute, Nathalie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1902–99), French writer; born in Russia; born Nathalie Ilyanova Tcherniak. Her novels included Portrait of a Man Unknown (1947) and Martereau (1953). Some of her essays are collected in The Age of Suspicion (1956).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hale, Nathan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1755–76), American hero. He volunteered in 1776 during the American Revolution to spy behind British lines on Long Island. Disguised as a schoolmaster, he was captured by the British and hanged without trial. His last words are said to have been, “I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country. ”.
--Examples--
--Word--
West, Nathanael 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–40), US writer; born Nathan Wallenstein Weinstein. His works include novels such as Miss Lonelyhearts (1933), A Cool Million (1934), and The Day of the Locust (1939).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hawthorne, Nathaniel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1804–64), American novelist and short-story writer. Much of his fiction explores guilt, sin, and morality. Notable works: Twice-Told Tales (short stories, 1837), The Scarlet Letter (1850), and The House of the Seven Gables (1851).

natheless

--Meanings--

natheless

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Natica 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of carnivorous marine gastropods (family Naticidae) which burrow into the shells of bivalves. Also (in form natica): a gastropod of this genus; any gastropod of the family Naticidae with a calcareous operculum, a moon snail; (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
naticoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a mollusc of the genus Natica or its shell.
--Examples--
--Word--
nation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large body of people united by common descent, history, culture, or language, inhabiting a particular state or territory.
A North American Indian people or confederation of peoples.
--Examples--
‘the world's leading industrialized nations’
--Word--
national 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of a nation; common to a whole nation.
Owned, controlled, or financially supported by the state.
A citizen of a particular country.
A national newspaper as opposed to a local one.
A nationwide competition or tournament.
--Examples--
‘this policy may have been in the national interest’
‘a national newspaper’
‘plans for a national art library’
‘a German national’
‘the inability of the local press to compete with the nationals for news’
‘she finished 16th at the nationals that year’
--Word--
nationalizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nationalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Identification with one's own nation and support for its interests, especially to the exclusion or detriment of the interests of other nations.
Advocacy of or support for the political independence of a particular nation or people.
--Examples--
‘their nationalism is tempered by a desire to join the European Union’
‘Scottish nationalism’
--Word--
nationalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Identification with one's own nation and support for its interests, especially to the exclusion or detriment of the interests of other nations.
Advocacy of or support for the political independence of a particular nation or people.
--Examples--
‘their nationalism is tempered by a desire to join the European Union’
‘Scottish nationalism’
--Word--
nationalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who strongly identifies with their own nation and vigorously supports its interests, especially to the exclusion or detriment of the interests of other nations.
A person who advocates or supports the political independence of a particular nation or people.
Relating to nationalists or nationalism.
--Examples--
‘he was a staunch nationalist during his 22 years in power’
‘a Basque nationalist’
‘a nationalist movement’
--Word--
nationalistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or expressing strong identification with one's own nation and vigorous support for its interests, especially to the exclusion or detriment of the interests of other nations.
--Examples--
‘he was fiercely nationalistic’
‘nationalistic pride’

nationalistically

--Meanings--

--Word--
nationality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The status of belonging to a particular nation.
Distinctive national or ethnic character.
An ethnic group forming a part of one or more political nations.
--Examples--
‘men of Spanish nationality’
‘the tapestry was created by women of all nationalities’
‘the change of a name does not discard nationality’
‘all the main nationalities of Ethiopia’

verb

‘he is now a nationalized Frenchman’

--Word--
nation 
--Type--
noun

A large body of people united by common descent, history, culture, or language, inhabiting a particular state or territory.

‘the world's leading industrialized nations’
--Word--
nation state 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sovereign state of which most of the citizens or subjects are united also by factors which define a nation, such as language or common descent.
--Examples--
‘Nepal emerged as a nation state in the eighteenth century’
--Word--
nationwide 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Extending or reaching throughout a whole nation.
Throughout a whole nation.
--Examples--
‘a nationwide hunt’
‘the company employs 6,000 people nationwide’
--Word--
native 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person born in a specified place or associated with a place by birth, whether subsequently resident there or not.
A local inhabitant.
A non-white original inhabitant of a place, as regarded by European colonists or travellers.
An animal or plant indigenous to a place.
An oyster reared in British waters.
Associated with the place or circumstances of a person's birth.
Of the indigenous inhabitants of a place.
(of a plant or animal) of indigenous origin or growth.
Used in names of animals or plants resembling others familiar elsewhere, e.g. native bee.
(of a quality) belonging to a person's character from birth; innate.
(of a metal or other mineral) found in a pure or uncombined state.
Designed for or built into a given system, especially denoting the language associated with a given processor, computer, or compiler, and programs written in it.
--Examples--
‘a native of Montreal’
‘an eighteen-year-old Brooklyn native’
‘New York in the summer was too hot even for the natives’
‘the marigold is a native of southern Europe’
‘he's a native New Yorker’
‘her native country’
‘a ceremonial native dance from Fiji’
‘eagle owls aren't native to Britain’
‘Scotland's few remaining native pinewoods’
‘some last vestige of native wit prompted Guy to say nothing’
--Word--
native-born 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to a particular place or country by birth.
--Examples--
‘the island has a population of 56,000, 90 percent of whom are native-born Inuits’

--Word--
native 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person born in a specified place or associated with a place by birth, whether subsequently resident there or not.
A local inhabitant.
A non-white original inhabitant of a place, as regarded by European colonists or travellers.
An animal or plant indigenous to a place.
An oyster reared in British waters.
Associated with the place or circumstances of a person's birth.
Of the indigenous inhabitants of a place.
(of a plant or animal) of indigenous origin or growth.
Used in names of animals or plants resembling others familiar elsewhere, e.g. native bee.
(of a quality) belonging to a person's character from birth; innate.
(of a metal or other mineral) found in a pure or uncombined state.
Designed for or built into a given system, especially denoting the language associated with a given processor, computer, or compiler, and programs written in it.
--Examples--
‘a native of Montreal’
‘an eighteen-year-old Brooklyn native’
‘New York in the summer was too hot even for the natives’
‘the marigold is a native of southern Europe’
‘he's a native New Yorker’
‘her native country’
‘a ceremonial native dance from Fiji’
‘eagle owls aren't native to Britain’
‘Scotland's few remaining native pinewoods’
‘some last vestige of native wit prompted Guy to say nothing’
--Word--
nativism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that concepts, mental capacities, and mental structures are innate rather than acquired by learning.
The policy of protecting the interests of native-born or established inhabitants against those of immigrants.
A return to or emphasis on indigenous customs, in opposition to outside influences.
--Examples--
‘a deep vein of xenophobia and nativism’

--Word--
natura naturata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Nature as a created entity or system; the natural phenomena and forces in which creation is manifested.
--Examples--
--Word--
lusus naturae 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A freak of nature.
--Examples--
‘they said he was wonderful, surprisingly fit, a lusus naturae’
--Word--
natural 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Existing in or derived from nature; not made or caused by humankind.
Having had a minimum of processing or preservative treatment.
(of fabric) having a colour characteristic of the unbleached and undyed state; off-white.
In accordance with the nature of, or circumstances surrounding, someone or something.
(of a person) having an innate skill or quality.
(of a skill or quality) coming instinctively to a person; innate.
(of a person or their behaviour) relaxed and unaffected; spontaneous.
Entirely to be expected.
(of law or justice) felt instinctively to be morally right and fair.
(of a parent or child) related by blood.
(of a child) illegitimate.
(of a note) not sharp or flat.
(of a brass instrument) having no valves and able to play only the notes of the harmonic series above a fundamental note.
Relating to the notes and intervals of the harmonic series.
Relating to earthly human or physical nature as distinct from the spiritual or supernatural realm.
(of a bid) straightforwardly reflecting one's holding of cards.
A person having an innate talent for a particular task or activity.
A thing that is particularly suited for something.
A sign (♮) denoting a natural note when a previous sign or the key signature would otherwise demand a sharp or a flat.
A natural note.
Any of the longer, lower keys on a keyboard instrument that are normally white.
An off-white colour.
(in a gambling game) a combination or score that immediately wins.
A hand of two cards making 21 in the first deal in blackjack and similar games.
A first throw of 7 or 11 at craps.
An insect or other small creature used as bait, rather than an artificial imitation.
A person born with a learning disability.
Naturally.
--Examples--
‘carrots contain a natural antiseptic’
‘natural disasters such as earthquakes’
‘natural food’
‘our nutritional products are completely natural’
‘sharks have no natural enemies’
‘he was a natural entertainer’
‘Laura's natural adaptability enabled her to settle quickly’
‘he replied with just a little too much nonchalance to sound natural’
‘Ken was a natural choice for chairman’
‘you might feel that holding the teacher responsible for the results contravenes natural justice’
‘such adopted children always knew who their natural parents were’
‘the Baron left a natural son by his mistress’
‘the bassoon plays G natural instead of A flat’
‘his bid of one heart was natural and positive’
‘she was a natural for television work’
‘perky musical accompaniment would seem a natural for this series’
‘colour for the summer is defined by the trend towards naturals’
‘keep walking—just act natural’
--Word--
natural-born 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a specified innate characteristic or ability.
Having a particular position by birth.
--Examples--
‘Glen was a natural-born sailor’
‘a natural-born citizen’
--Word--
minimum naturale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Usually in plural Each of the smallest natural particles of matter of which all bodies or objects were considered to be composed, the existence of which was first proposed by Aristotle.
--Examples--
--Word--
naturalesque 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Compare natural. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
naturalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The admittance of a foreigner to the citizenship of a country.
The introduction of a plant or animal to a region where it is not indigenous.
The alteration of an adopted foreign word so that it conforms more closely to the phonology or orthography of the adopting language.
The act of causing something to appear natural.
--Examples--
‘an application for naturalization as a British citizen’
‘the naturalization process can be intimidating’
‘the first report of naturalization of this species in the United States’
‘the successful naturalization of trout in the barren waters of the Sierra’
‘French naturalization of Creole words or phrases’
‘trailers have contributed to the naturalization of a variety of social desires’
‘the naturalization of gender roles’
‘he continued the naturalization of the landscape, removing the old formal garden’
--Word--
naturalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Admit (a foreigner) to the citizenship of a country.
(of a foreigner) be admitted to the citizenship of a country.
Establish (a plant or animal) so that it lives wild in a region where it is not indigenous.
(with reference to a cultivated plant) establish or become established in a natural situation.
Alter (an adopted foreign word) so that it conforms more closely to the phonology or orthography of the adopting language.
Regard as or cause to appear natural.
Explain (a phenomenon) in a naturalistic way.
--Examples--
‘he was born in a foreign country and had never been naturalized’
‘the opportunity to naturalize as British’
‘the species was naturalized in Britain as early as 1620’
‘this species of crocus naturalizes itself very easily’
‘the stoccafisso of Liguria was naturalized in Nice as stocoficada’
‘globalization has been naturalized as the inevitable pathway to economic prosperity and success’
--Word--
naturalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in art and literature) a style and theory of representation based on the accurate depiction of detail.
The philosophical belief that everything arises from natural properties and causes, and supernatural or spiritual explanations are excluded or discounted.
(in moral philosophy) the theory that ethical statements can be derived from non-ethical ones.
--Examples--
‘his attack on naturalism in TV drama’
‘this romanticized attitude to the world did conflict with his avowed naturalism’
--Word--
naturalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in art and literature) a style and theory of representation based on the accurate depiction of detail.
The philosophical belief that everything arises from natural properties and causes, and supernatural or spiritual explanations are excluded or discounted.
(in moral philosophy) the theory that ethical statements can be derived from non-ethical ones.
--Examples--
‘his attack on naturalism in TV drama’
‘this romanticized attitude to the world did conflict with his avowed naturalism’

natural 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Existing in or derived from nature; not made or caused by humankind.
Having had a minimum of processing or preservative treatment.
(of fabric) having a colour characteristic of the unbleached and undyed state; off-white.

(of a parent or child) related by blood.
(of a child) illegitimate.
(of a note) not sharp or flat.
(of a brass instrument) having no valves and able to play only the notes of the harmonic series above a fundamental note.
Relating to the notes and intervals of the harmonic series.

(of a bid) straightforwardly reflecting one's holding of cards.
A person having an innate talent for a particular task or activity.

A natural note.
Any of the longer, lower keys on a keyboard instrument that are normally white.
An off-white colour.

A hand of two cards making 21 in the first deal in blackjack and similar games.
A first throw of 7 or 11 at craps.
An insect or other small creature used as bait, rather than an artificial imitation.
A person born with a learning disability.
Naturally.

--Word--
nature 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The phenomena of the physical world collectively, including plants, animals, the landscape, and other features and products of the earth, as opposed to humans or human creations.
The physical force regarded as causing and regulating the phenomena of the world.
The basic or inherent features, character, or qualities of something.
The innate or essential qualities or character of a person or animal.
Inborn or hereditary characteristics as an influence on or determinant of personality.
A person of a specified character.
--Examples--
‘the breathtaking beauty of nature’
‘it is impossible to change the laws of nature’
‘helping them to realize the nature of their problems’
‘there are a lot of other documents of that nature’
‘it's not in her nature to listen to advice’
‘I'm not violent by nature’
‘Emerson was so much more luminous a nature’

nature print 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An illustration or impression obtained by nature-printing.
--Examples--
--Word--
nature printing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of producing a print of a natural object (such as a leaf) or a textile by making an impression of it directly on to a soft metal printing plate under great pressure and then taking an inked impression on paper.
--Examples--

--Word--
Naugatuck 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial borough in southwestern Connecticut, on the Naugatuck River next to Waterbury; population 31,931 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
naught 
--Type--
pronoun, noun
--Meanings--
Nothing.
--Examples--
‘he's naught but a worthless fool’
--Word--
naughty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of a child) badly behaved; disobedient.
Mildly rude or indecent, typically because related to sex.
Wicked.
--Examples--
‘you've been a really naughty boy’
‘naughty goings-on’

--Word--
Gabo, Naum 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1890–1977), Russian-born American sculptor, brother of Antoine Pevsner; born Naum Neemia Pevsner. A founder of Russian constructivism, Gabo experimented with kinetic art and transparent materials.
--Examples--
--Word--
naumachia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mock sea battle staged for entertainment.
A place specially constructed for the exhibition of mock sea battles; especially a building enclosing an artificial stretch of water.

naumannite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native silver selenide, Ag₂Se, crystallizing in the orthorhombic system and usually occurring as black metallic cubes.

--Word--
Nauru 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island country in the south-western Pacific Ocean, near the equator; population 10,000 (estimated 2015); no official capital but government is in Yaren District; official languages, Nauruan (an Austronesian language) and English.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nauruan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the south-western Pacific island of Nauru or its people or language.
A native or inhabitant of the south-western Pacific island of Nauru.
The Austronesian language spoken on Nauru.
--Examples--
‘a history from a Nauruan perspective’
‘Nauruans want to rehabilitate the island’
‘they are publishing a growing number of titles in Nauruan’
--Word--
nausea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A feeling of sickness with an inclination to vomit.
A feeling of loathing or disgust.
--Examples--
‘a wave of nausea engulfed him’
‘the stories will launch a wave of public nausea and outrage’
--Word--
ad nauseam 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to the fact that something has been done or repeated so often that it has become annoying or tiresome.
--Examples--
‘the phrase he repeated ad nauseam’
--Word--
nauseant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance or agent which produces nausea.
Producing nausea; (in extended use) nauseating, extremely distasteful.

--Word--
nautic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly poetic and literary. Nautical. Now archaic and rare.
Informal. A sailor, especially one in the Royal Navy.

--Word--
nautilus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A cephalopod mollusc with a light external spiral shell and numerous short tentacles around the mouth.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, launched in 1954. This US navy vessel made a historic journey (1–5 August 1958) under the ice of the North Pole.
--Examples--
--Word--
nautiloid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mollusc of a group of mainly extinct marine molluscs which includes the pearly nautilus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nautiloidea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With plural or singular concord. A subclass of cephalopod molluscs possessing a many-chambered shell (either straight or coiled), of which the genus Nautilus is the only living member; (in some classifications) one of a number of subdivisions of the tetrabranchiate cephalopods.
--Examples--
--Word--
nautilus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A cephalopod mollusc with a light external spiral shell and numerous short tentacles around the mouth.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, launched in 1954. This US navy vessel made a historic journey (1–5 August 1958) under the ice of the North Pole.

--Word--
Navajo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American people of New Mexico and Arizona.
The Athabaskan language of the Navajo, with about 130,000 speakers.
Relating to the Navajo or their language.

--Word--
Navarino, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A decisive naval battle in the Greek struggle for independence from the Ottoman Empire, fought in 1827 in the Bay of Navarino off Pylos in the Peloponnese. Britain, Russia, and France sent a combined fleet which destroyed the Egyptian and Turkish fleet.
--Examples--
--Word--
Navarre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An autonomous region of northern Spain, on the border with France; capital, Pamplona. It represents the southern part of the former kingdom of Navarre, which was conquered by Ferdinand in 1512 and attached to Spain, while the northern part passed to France in 1589 through inheritance by Henry IV. Spanish name Navarra /naˈβarra/.
--Examples--
--Word--
Navarrese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the province of Navarre in northern Spain (formerly a kingdom which also included part of south-west France).
Of or relating to Navarre.
--Examples--
--Word--
navar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A navigational radar system in which the positions of aircraft near an airport are determined by ground radar and then transmitted to pilots in the vicinity.
--Examples--
--Word--
nave 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The central part of a church building, intended to accommodate most of the congregation. In traditional Western churches it is rectangular, separated from the chancel by a step or rail, and from adjacent aisles by pillars.
The hub of a wheel.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun

A rounded knotty depression in the centre of a person's belly caused by the detachment of the umbilical cord after birth; the umbilicus.
The central point of a place.

‘the Incas saw Cuzco as the navel of the world’

navew 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Rape, Brassica napus, either (more fully "†navew gentle") in the form grown for its sweet fleshy spindle-shaped root or (more fully "wild navew") in its supposedly wild form.

navy

noun
--Meanings--
The branch of the armed services of a state which conducts military operations at sea.

A dark blue colour.

‘a navy blue suit’

navicert 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A British consular certificate granted to a neutral ship in wartime testifying that its cargo is correctly described in the manifest.

--Word--
navicular 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Boat-shaped.
A boat-shaped bone in the ankle or wrist, especially that in the ankle, between the talus and the cuneiform bones.
A chronic disorder of the navicular bone in horses, causing lameness in the front feet.
--Examples--
--Word--
naviculoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or resembling a diatom of the genus Navicula, which has bilaterally symmetrical boat-shaped or spindle-shaped cells.
More generally: = "navicular".
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
navigable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a waterway or sea) able to be sailed on by ships or boats.
(of a track or road) suitable for vehicles.
(of a website) easy to move around in.
--Examples--
‘a navigable channel’
‘many of the rivers ceased to be navigable’
‘a good cart track, navigable by cars’
‘the use of white space can help make your mobile-optimized site clearer and more navigable’
--Word--
navigably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a navigable manner; so as to be navigable.
--Examples--
--Word--
navigably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a navigable manner; so as to be navigable.
--Examples--
--Word--
navigate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Plan and direct the course of a ship, aircraft, or other form of transport, especially by using instruments or maps.
Travel on a desired course after planning a route.
(of an animal) find its way.
(of a passenger in a vehicle) assist the driver by planning a route and map reading.
Move around a website, the Internet, etc.
(of a ship or boat) sail; proceed.
Sail or travel over (a stretch of water or terrain), especially carefully or with difficulty.
Guide (a vessel or vehicle) over a specified route or terrain.
Guide or steer (someone)
--Examples--
‘they navigated by the stars’
‘he taught them how to navigate across the oceans’
‘whales use their own inbuilt sonar system to navigate’
‘we'll go in my car—you can navigate’
‘I used a browser to navigate around the Web’
‘software used to navigate the Internet’
‘we sailed out while navigating around large icebergs’
‘ships had been lost while navigating the narrows’
‘the drivers skilfully navigated a muddy course’
‘she navigated the car safely through the traffic’
‘Ted was navigating her towards the other end of the room’

--Word--
navigation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or activity of accurately ascertaining one's position and planning and following a route.
The passage of ships.
A navigable inland waterway, especially a canal.
The action of moving around a website, the Internet, etc.
--Examples--
‘Columbus corrected his westward course by celestial navigation’
‘transporter bridges to span rivers without hindering navigation’
‘most of the navigation from Wormley to Tottenham was frozen’
--Word--
navigational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or used for navigation on a route.
Relating to the action of moving around a website, the Internet, etc.
--Examples--
‘navigational aids like lighthouses or buoys’
‘this is a test of navigational skills, not speed’
‘the incorporation of navigational aids into Web search tools’
--Word--
navigationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
navigation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or activity of accurately ascertaining one's position and planning and following a route.
The passage of ships.
A navigable inland waterway, especially a canal.

--Examples--

--Word--
navigator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who navigates a ship, aircraft, etc.
A person who explores by sea.
An instrument or device which assists in navigating a vessel or aircraft.
A browser program for accessing data on the Internet or another information system.
--Examples--
‘the starry sky was a navigator's dream’
‘the driver relies on his navigator's skill at reading the road’
‘New Zealand was discovered by Dutch navigator, Abel Tasman’

Navratilova, Martina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1956), Czech-American tennis player. Her major successes include nine Wimbledon singles titles (1978–9; 1982–7; 1990), two world championships (1980; 1984), and eight successive grand slam doubles titles.

Nazarean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Church History and Judaism. = "Nazarene".
Church History and Judaism. = "Nazarene". In quot. 1876 perhaps = "Nazirite".
--Examples--
--Word--
Nazarene 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Nazareth.
Jesus Christ.
(chiefly in Jewish or Muslim use) a Christian.
A member of an early sect of Jewish Christians, especially one in 4th-century Syria observing much of the Jewish law.
A member of the Church of the Nazarene, a Protestant denomination founded in California.
A member of a group of German painters formed in 1809, who sought to revive the art and techniques of medieval Germany and early Renaissance Italy.
Relating to Nazareth or Nazarenes.
--Examples--

Nazarenism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Art. The characteristics or artistic principles of the Nazarene school of artists or their followers; archaism. Compare "Nazarene". In quot. 1947 in extended use.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nazareth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A historic town in lower Galilee, in present-day northern Israel; population 66,400 (est. 2008). Mentioned in the Gospels as the home of Mary and Joseph, it is closely associated with the childhood of Jesus and is a centre of Christian pilgrimage.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nazirite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Israelite who was consecrated to the service of God, under vows to abstain from alcohol, let the hair grow, and avoid defilement by contact with dead bodies (Num. 6).

Neal, Patricia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–2010), US stage and movie actress; born Patsy Louise Neal. She was an award-winning actress when she suffered several massive strokes in 1965. Her long, hard recovery was remarkable, and she returned to acting in 1968. Among the many movies in which she appeared were Hud (1963), The Subject Was Roses (1968), and Cookie's Fortune (1999).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hurston, Zora Neale 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1901–60), American novelist. Her novels reflect her interest in folklore, especially that of the Deep South. Notable works: Jonah's Gourd Vine (1934) and Seraph on the Suwanee (1948).

--Word--
Neanderthal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct species of human that was widely distributed in ice-age Europe between c.120,000 and 35,000 years ago, with a receding forehead and prominent brow ridges. The Neanderthals were associated with the Mousterian flint industry of the Middle Palaeolithic.
An uncivilized, unintelligent, or uncouth man.
Relating to Neanderthals.
(of a man) uncivilized, unintelligent, or uncouth.
--Examples--
‘the stereotype of the mechanic as a macho Neanderthal’
‘a Neanderthal axe’
‘they were pushed back by Neanderthal security guards’

Neanderthal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct species of human that was widely distributed in ice-age Europe between c.120,000 and 35,000 years ago, with a receding forehead and prominent brow ridges. The Neanderthals were associated with the Mousterian flint industry of the Middle Palaeolithic.

neanthropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the single extant species of human, Homo sapiens, as opposed to extinct forms or species known only from fossil remains. Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
neap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tide just after the first or third quarters of the moon when there is least difference between high and low water.
(of a boat) be kept aground or in harbour by a neap tide.
(of a tide) tend towards or reach the highest point of a neap tide.
--Examples--
‘neaps occur at 6 a.m. and 6 p.m.’
‘a change of wind could leave you neaped’

--Word--
near 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
At or to a short distance away; nearby.
A short time away in the future.
Almost.
Nearly.
At or to a short distance away from (a place)
A short period of time from.
Close to (a state); verging on.
A small amount below (another amount)
Similar to.
Located a short distance away.
Only a short time ahead.
Similar.
Close to being (the thing mentioned)
Having a close family connection.
Located on the nearside of a vehicle.
(of a person) mean; miserly.
Come near to; approach.
--Examples--
‘a bomb exploded somewhere near’
‘she took a step nearer’
‘his retirement was drawing near’
‘a near perfect fit’
‘I near fell out of the chair’
‘the car park near the sawmill’
‘do you live near here?’
‘the table nearest the door’
‘near the end of the war’
‘details will be given nearer the date’
‘she gave a tiny smile, brave but near tears’
‘she was near to death’
‘temperatures near 2 million degrees’
‘a shape near to the original’
‘a large house in the near distance’
‘I was a mile from the nearest village’
‘the conflict is unlikely to be resolved in the near future’
‘walking in these shoes is the nearest thing to floating on air’
‘his state of near despair’
‘a near disaster’
‘the loss of a child or other near relative’
‘the near right-hand end window of the caravan’
‘soon the cab would be nearing Oxford Street’
‘lunchtime neared’

‘I near fell out of the chair’
‘the car park near the sawmill’
‘do you live near here?’
‘the table nearest the door’
‘near the end of the war’
‘details will be given nearer the date’
‘she gave a tiny smile, brave but near tears’
‘she was near to death’
‘temperatures near 2 million degrees’
‘a shape near to the original’
‘a large house in the near distance’
‘I was a mile from the nearest village’
‘the conflict is unlikely to be resolved in the near future’
‘walking in these shoes is the nearest thing to floating on air’
‘his state of near despair’
‘a near disaster’
‘the loss of a child or other near relative’
‘the near right-hand end window of the caravan’
‘soon the cab would be nearing Oxford Street’
‘lunchtime neared’
--Word--
near 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
At or to a short distance away; nearby.
A short time away in the future.
Almost.
Nearly.
At or to a short distance away from (a place)
A short period of time from.
Close to (a state); verging on.
A small amount below (another amount)
Similar to.
Located a short distance away.
Only a short time ahead.
Similar.
Close to being (the thing mentioned)
Having a close family connection.
Located on the nearside of a vehicle.
(of a person) mean; miserly.
Come near to; approach.
--Examples--
‘a bomb exploded somewhere near’
‘she took a step nearer’
‘his retirement was drawing near’
‘a near perfect fit’
‘I near fell out of the chair’
‘the car park near the sawmill’
‘do you live near here?’
‘the table nearest the door’
‘near the end of the war’
‘details will be given nearer the date’
‘she gave a tiny smile, brave but near tears’
‘she was near to death’
‘temperatures near 2 million degrees’
‘a shape near to the original’
‘a large house in the near distance’
‘I was a mile from the nearest village’
‘the conflict is unlikely to be resolved in the near future’
‘walking in these shoes is the nearest thing to floating on air’
‘his state of near despair’
‘a near disaster’
‘the loss of a child or other near relative’
‘the near right-hand end window of the caravan’
‘soon the cab would be nearing Oxford Street’
‘lunchtime neared’

--Word--
fighting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of fighting; violence or conflict.
Displaying or engaging in violence, combat, or aggression.
--Examples--
‘terrible fighting broke out in the streets’
‘he was a fighting man’
‘he put up his fists and took a fighting stance’
--Word--
following 
--Type--
preposition, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Coming after or as a result of.
A body of supporters or admirers.
What follows or comes next.
Next in time.
About to be mentioned.
(of a wind) blowing in the same direction as the course of a vessel etc.
--Examples--
‘police are hunting for two men following a spate of robberies in the area’
‘he attracted a worldwide following’
‘the following are both grammatically correct sentences’
‘the following day there was a ceremony in St Peter's Square’
‘you are required to provide us with the following information’
--Word--
growing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a living thing) undergoing natural development by increasing in size and changing physically.
Becoming greater over a period of time; increasing.
--Examples--
‘the needs of the growing child’
‘the growing concern over ozone levels’

--Word--
nearhand 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective
--Meanings--
Nearly, almost.
Near, in space or time; close at hand, close by.
Near to, close to (a place, person, point of time, or action).
Near, nearby, near-at-hand. "nearhand cut"noun a short cut.

--Word--
near miss 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A narrowly avoided collision or other accident.
A bomb or shot that just misses its target.
Something almost achieved.
--Examples--
‘she had a near miss when her horse was nearly sucked into a dyke’
‘the terrifying near miss took place at 4,500 ft’
‘he had escaped more than twenty near misses’
‘a victory in Houston and a near miss in the finals of the French Open’

--Word--
nearshore 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the region of the sea or seabed relatively close to a shore.
Relating to the transfer of a business operation to a nearby country.
(of a company) transfer (a business operation) to a nearby country, especially in preference to a more distant location.
--Examples--
‘volunteers monitor humpback whales in nearshore waters’
‘corals are essential to the nearshore ecosystem’
‘nearshore IT services’
‘we set up a nearshore operation in Poland’
‘many capital market firms are starting to nearshore their operations’
--Word--
nearside 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The side of a vehicle nearest the kerb (in Britain, the left)
The left side of a horse.
--Examples--
‘he veered to the nearside and crashed into a van’
‘the front nearside wheel’

--Word--
silk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine, strong, soft lustrous fibre produced by silkworms in making cocoons and collected to make thread and fabric.
Thread or fabric made from the fibre produced by the silkworm.
Garments made from silk, especially as worn by a jockey in the colours of a particular horse owner.
The silky styles of the female maize flower.
A Queen's (or King's) Counsel.
--Examples--
‘a silk shirt’
‘some were dressed in racing silks’
‘peel back husks from corn without detaching from cobs; remove silks’
