--Word--
neat 
--Type--
adjective, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Arranged in a tidy way; in good order.
(of a person) habitually tidy, smart, or well organized.
Having a pleasing appearance; well formed.
Done with or demonstrating skill or efficiency.
Tending to disregard specifics for the sake of convenience; facile.
(of liquid, especially spirits) not diluted or mixed with anything else.
Very good; excellent.
A bovine animal.
Cattle.
Non-exercise activity thermogenesis (the energy dissipated as heat by a person during minor physical activity, such as fidgeting or shivering, that does not involve a large expenditure of energy and is not perceived as exercise).
--Examples--
‘the books had been stacked up in neat piles’
‘her daughter was always neat and clean’
‘Alan noted down the orders in his neat, precise script’
‘a neat bit of deduction’
‘this neat division does not take into account a host of associated factors’
‘he drank neat Scotch’
‘it was really neat seeing the city’

‘this neat division does not take into account a host of associated factors’
‘he drank neat Scotch’
‘it was really neat seeing the city’

--Word--
neat 
--Type--
adjective, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Arranged in a tidy way; in good order.
(of a person) habitually tidy, smart, or well organized.
Having a pleasing appearance; well formed.
Done with or demonstrating skill or efficiency.
Tending to disregard specifics for the sake of convenience; facile.
(of liquid, especially spirits) not diluted or mixed with anything else.
Very good; excellent.
A bovine animal.
Cattle.
Non-exercise activity thermogenesis (the energy dissipated as heat by a person during minor physical activity, such as fidgeting or shivering, that does not involve a large expenditure of energy and is not perceived as exercise).
--Examples--
‘the books had been stacked up in neat piles’
‘her daughter was always neat and clean’
‘Alan noted down the orders in his neat, precise script’
‘a neat bit of deduction’
‘this neat division does not take into account a host of associated factors’
‘he drank neat Scotch’
‘it was really neat seeing the city’

--Word--
Nebraska 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the central US to the west of the Missouri River; population 1,783,432 (est. 2008); capital, Lincoln. It was acquired as part of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803 and became the 37th state of the US in 1867.

noun

--Word--
nebulium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hypothetical chemical element proposed in the 1860s to explain certain lines in the spectra of nebulae, later discovered to arise from forbidden transitions in oxygen and nitrogen ions.
--Examples--
‘nebulium lines’
--Word--
nebulization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Medicine. The conversion of a liquid into a fine mist or spray, especially for inhalation therapy. Also: inhalation therapy using this technique; medical treatment using a nebulizer.
Generally. The transformation of something into a nebulous state; an instance of this.
--Examples--

--Word--
necessary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Needed to be done, achieved, or present; essential.
Determined, existing, or happening by natural laws or predestination; inevitable.
(of a concept, statement, etc.) inevitably resulting from the nature of things, so that the contrary is impossible.
(of an agent) having no independent volition.
The basic requirements of life, such as food and warmth.
The action or item needed.
The money needed.
--Examples--
‘they granted the necessary planning permission’
‘it's not necessary for you to be here’
‘a necessary consequence’
‘not merely luxuries, but also the common necessaries’
‘poor people complaining for want of the necessaries of life’
‘see when they need a tactful word of advice and do the necessary’
‘a bag containing my wallet: the money, the necessary’

--Word--
necessity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being required.
The state of being unavoidable.
A situation enforcing a certain course of action.
An indispensable thing.
The principle according to which something must be so, by virtue either of logic or of natural law.
A condition that cannot be otherwise, or a statement asserting this.
--Examples--
‘the necessity of providing parental guidance’
‘the necessity of growing old’
‘political necessity induced him to consider it’
‘a good book is a necessity when travelling’

--Word--
neck 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part of a person's or animal's body connecting the head to the rest of the body.
The part of a garment that is around or close to the neck.
Meat from an animal's neck.
A person's neck regarded as bearing a burden of responsibility or guilt.
A narrow connecting or end part of something.
The part of a bottle or other container near the mouth.
A narrow piece of land or sea, such as an isthmus or channel.
A narrow part near one end of an organ, such as the uterus.
The part of a violin, guitar, or other similar instrument that bears the fingerboard.
A column of solidified lava or igneous rock formed in a volcanic vent, especially when exposed by erosion.
A narrow supporting part in a plant, especially the terminal part of the fruiting body in a fern, bryophyte, or fungus.
The length of a horse's head and neck as a measure of its lead in a race.
(of two people) kiss and caress amorously.
Swallow (something, especially a drink)
Form a narrowed part at a particular point when subjected to tension.
--Examples--
‘she had a silver crucifix around her neck’
‘her dress had three buttons at the neck undone’
‘a round neck’
‘neck of lamb’
‘he'll be stuck with a loan around his neck’
‘he seized the neck of the whisky bottle’
‘the narrow neck of land between loch and sea’
‘the neck of the womb, usually called the cervix’
‘Dolpour won by a neck from Wood Dancer’
‘we started necking on the sofa’
‘after necking some beers, we left the bar’
‘the nylon filament necks down to a fraction of its original diameter’

Neckar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of western Germany, which rises in the Black Forest and flows 367 km (228 miles) north and west through Stuttgart to meet the River Rhine at Mannheim.

--Word--
deep 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Extending far down from the top or surface.
Extending or situated far in from the outer edge or surface.
(after a measurement and in questions) extending a specified distance from the top, surface, or outer edge.
As far up or down as a specified point.
In a specified number of ranks one behind another.
Taking in or giving out a lot of air.
(of a fielding position) relatively distant from the batsman; near the boundary.
(in ball games) to or from a position far down or across the field.
Very intense or extreme.
(of an emotion or feeling) intensely felt.
Profound or penetrating in awareness or understanding.
Difficult to understand.
Fully absorbed or involved in (a state or activity)
(of a person) unpredictable and secretive.
(of sound) low in pitch and full in tone; not shrill.
(of colour) dark and intense.
The sea.
A deep part of the sea.
The part of the field distant from the batsman.
Far down or in; deeply.
(in sport) distant from the batsman or forward line of one's team.
--Examples--
‘a deep gorge’
‘the lake was deep and cold’
‘a deep alcove’
‘deep in the woods’
‘the well was 200 feet deep’
‘they stood waist-deep in the water’
‘they were standing three-deep at the bar’
‘she took a deep breath’
‘deep midwicket’
‘a deep cross from Neill’
‘she was in deep trouble’
‘a deep sleep’
‘deep disappointment’
‘a deep analysis’
‘this is all getting too deep for me’
‘they were deep in their own thoughts’
‘that Thomas is a deep one’
‘a deep, resonant voice’
‘a deep pink’
‘denizens of the deep’
‘the dark and menacing deeps’
‘the deeps of her imagination’
‘he travelled deep into the forest’
‘he swung the ball in deep’

--Meanings--
Moving or capable of moving at high speed.
Taking place at high speed; taking a short time.
Performing or able to perform a particular action quickly.
(of a surface) allowing or producing high-speed movement.
(of a sports field) likely to make the ball bounce or run quickly or to allow competitors to reach a high speed.
(of a clock or watch) showing a time ahead of the correct time.
Firmly fixed or attached.
(of friends) close and loyal.
(of a film) needing only a short exposure.
(of a lens) having a large aperture and therefore suitable for use with short exposure times.
(of a dye) not fading in light or when washed.
Engaging in or involving activities characterized by excitement, extranvagance, and risk-taking.
(of a person) prone to act in an unacceptably familiar way.
At high speed.
Within a short time.
So as to be hard to move; securely.
So as to be hard to wake.
--Examples--
‘a fast and powerful car’
‘the journey was fast and enjoyable’
‘a fast reader’
‘a wide, fast road’
‘I keep my watch fifteen minutes fast’
‘he made a rope fast to each corner’
‘they remained fast friends’
‘a 35-mm colour film which is ten times faster than Kodacolor II’
‘the dyes are boiled with the yarn to produce a fast colour’
‘the fast life she led in London’
‘Mammy said, ‘Stop asking questions, you too damn farse.’’
‘he was driving too fast’
‘we're going to have to get to the bottom of this fast’
‘the ship was held fast by the anchor chain’
‘they were too fast asleep to reply’
--Word--
neckful 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A quantity that fills the neck; as much as the neck will hold.
As much (punishment, annoyance, irritation, etc.) as one can endure.
--Examples--
--Word--
high-necked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a garment) having a collar or neckline that sits high against or close to the neck.
--Examples--
‘a beige high-necked sweater’
--Word--
neck-hole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The hollow in the back of the neck; the space between the back of the neck and the collar. Now rare (chiefly regional in later use).
An opening for the neck in an article of clothing.
--Examples--
--Word--
necking 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short, plain, concave section between the capital and the shaft of a classical Doric or Tuscan column.

necklace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An ornamental chain or string of beads, jewels, or links worn round the neck.
(in South Africa) a tyre doused or filled with petrol, placed round a victim's neck and set alight.
(in South Africa) kill (someone) with a tyre necklace.
--Examples--
‘a diamond necklace’
‘the harbour with its necklace of lights’

--Word--
neck-piece 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of meat: the part of a carcass between the shoulder and the head.
The collar of a garment, or the part of a garment that extends to or covers the neck. Now chiefly historical.
A piece of armour, cloth, etc., covering or protecting the neck (now chiefly historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
neck-piece 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of meat: the part of a carcass between the shoulder and the head.
The collar of a garment, or the part of a garment that extends to or covers the neck. Now chiefly historical.
A piece of armour, cloth, etc., covering or protecting the neck (now chiefly historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
neck-rein 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Of a horse: to be guided or turned by pressure of a rein against the neck on the opposite side to the direction to be turned.
Of a rider: to guide or turn a horse in this way.
--Examples--
--Word--
neck 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part of a person's or animal's body connecting the head to the rest of the body.
The part of a garment that is around or close to the neck.
Meat from an animal's neck.
A person's neck regarded as bearing a burden of responsibility or guilt.
A narrow connecting or end part of something.
The part of a bottle or other container near the mouth.
A narrow piece of land or sea, such as an isthmus or channel.
A narrow part near one end of an organ, such as the uterus.
The part of a violin, guitar, or other similar instrument that bears the fingerboard.
A column of solidified lava or igneous rock formed in a volcanic vent, especially when exposed by erosion.
A narrow supporting part in a plant, especially the terminal part of the fruiting body in a fern, bryophyte, or fungus.
The length of a horse's head and neck as a measure of its lead in a race.
(of two people) kiss and caress amorously.
Swallow (something, especially a drink)
Form a narrowed part at a particular point when subjected to tension.
--Examples--
‘she had a silver crucifix around her neck’
‘her dress had three buttons at the neck undone’
‘a round neck’
‘neck of lamb’
‘he'll be stuck with a loan around his neck’
‘he seized the neck of the whisky bottle’
‘the narrow neck of land between loch and sea’
‘the neck of the womb, usually called the cervix’
‘Dolpour won by a neck from Wood Dancer’
‘we started necking on the sofa’
‘after necking some beers, we left the bar’
‘the nylon filament necks down to a fraction of its original diameter’
--Word--
time-stretching 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(In digital sound recording and editing) the action or process of altering the duration of a sound, tempo of a piece of music, etc., without altering the pitch.

--Word--
neck-verse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Latin verse printed in black letter (usually the beginning of Psalm 51 Miserere mei Deus, ‘Have mercy upon me, O God’) formerly set before a person claiming benefit of clergy, by reading which he might prove his clerical status and hence save his neck. In later use historical.

--Word--
neckweed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Slang The plant hemp (used with humorous allusion to the use of hempen rope for hanging people).
US. Either of two speedwells, Veronica agrestis and V. peregrina, reputed to cure scrofula (tuberculosis of the lymph nodes of the neck). Now rare.

necrobacillosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease caused by the Gram-negative anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium necrophorum, affecting domestic and wild animals and (less commonly) humans; an instance or form of this.

--Word--
necrogenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Produced by contact with dead bodies; arising from dead bodies; (Medicine) designating a wart-like form of tuberculosis of the skin acquired by contact with infected human or bovine tissue, seen especially in pathologists, abattoir workers, and butchers (now historical).
Causing necrosis; relating to the development of necrosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
necrogenous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a reaction to a plant pathogen in which there is necrosis of the cells surrounding the site of infection, isolating the pathogen and preventing its further spread. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--

‘there is a strain of Elvis worship that veers close to necrolatry’

nectar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sugary fluid secreted within flowers to encourage pollination by insects and other animals, collected by bees to make into honey.

A delicious drink.

--Word--
nectophore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In some siphonophores: a zooid which has a swimming bell but lacks a manubrium, and which contracts rhythmically to propel the colony through the water.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nectria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of ascomycete fungi (family Hypocreaceae) mostly having brightly-coloured (red or yellow) fruiting bodies and including a number of plant pathogens, especially N. galligena, which causes apple canker; (also nectria) a fungus of this genus.

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Nederlands 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The Dutch language of the Netherlands.
Of or relating to the Nederlands language.
--Examples--
--Word--
née 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally called; born (used in giving a married woman's maiden name after her surname)
--Examples--
‘Mary Toogood, née Johnson’
--Word--
need 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.
Not want to be subjected to something.
Expressing necessity or obligation.
Be necessary.
Circumstances in which something is necessary; necessity.
A thing that is wanted or required.
The state of requiring help, or of lacking basic necessities such as food.
--Examples--
‘I need help now’
‘this shirt needs washing’
‘they need to win tomorrow’
‘I don't need your sarcasm’
‘need I say more?’
‘all you need bring are sheets’
‘lest you, even more than needs, embitter our parting’
‘the basic human need for food’
‘there's no need to cry’
‘his day-to-day needs’
‘help us in our hour of need’
‘children in need’
--Word--
if need be 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
If necessary.
--Examples--
‘I'll work from morning till night if need be’

needfire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scottish and English regional (northern). Fire obtained from dry wood by means of violent friction, formerly credited with various magical properties, especially in protecting cattle from disease.
--Examples--

Needham, Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1900–95), English scientist and historian. Notable works: History of Embryology (1934) and Science and Civilization in China (1954).

--Type--
adjective

‘those from needy backgrounds’

need 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.

Expressing necessity or obligation.

--Word--
needle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A very fine slender piece of polished metal with a point at one end and a hole or eye for thread at the other, used in sewing.
A similar, larger instrument used in crafts such as crochet, knitting, and lacemaking.
The pointed hollow end of a hypodermic syringe.
A very fine metal spike used in acupuncture.
A thin pointer on a dial, compass, or other instrument.
A stylus used to play records.
An etching tool.
A steel pin exploding the cartridge of a breech-loading gun.
The sharp, stiff, slender leaf of a fir or pine tree.
A pointed rock or peak.
A group of rocks in the sea off the western tip of the Isle of Wight in southern England.
An obelisk.
Hostility or antagonism provoked by rivalry.
A beam used as a temporary support during underpinning.
Prick or pierce with or as if with a needle.
Provoke or annoy (someone) by continual criticism or questioning.
--Examples--
‘a darning needle’
‘the meter needle barely moved’
‘she wound the gramophone and lowered the needle on to the record’
‘just left of the needle is a steep wall for those who like bold climbing’
‘Cleopatra's Needle’
‘there is already a little bit of needle between the sides’
‘dust needled his eyes’
‘I just said that to Charlie to needle him’
--Word--
needle and thread 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various long-awned grasses of the genus Stipa, especially S. comata.
--Examples--
--Word--
needle-bar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bar to which the needles are attached on a sewing or knitting machine.
--Examples--
--Word--
billed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a beak or bill of a specified kind.
--Examples--
‘black-billed and yellow-billed cuckoos’

needle-book 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A needle-case resembling a small book.
--Examples--
--Word--
needlebush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several shrubs or small trees of the genus Hakea (family Proteaceae) having stiff needle-like leaves, especially H. leucoptera and H. tephrosperma.
The nelia Acacia rigens, having needle-like phyllodes.
--Examples--
--Word--
needlecord 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Fine-ribbed corduroy fabric.
--Examples--
‘a soft needlecord jacket’

needlecraft 
--Type--

--Meanings--

needle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A very fine slender piece of polished metal with a point at one end and a hole or eye for thread at the other, used in sewing.
A similar, larger instrument used in crafts such as crochet, knitting, and lacemaking.
The pointed hollow end of a hypodermic syringe.
A very fine metal spike used in acupuncture.
A thin pointer on a dial, compass, or other instrument.
A stylus used to play records.
An etching tool.
A steel pin exploding the cartridge of a breech-loading gun.
The sharp, stiff, slender leaf of a fir or pine tree.
A pointed rock or peak.
A group of rocks in the sea off the western tip of the Isle of Wight in southern England.
An obelisk.
Hostility or antagonism provoked by rivalry.
A beam used as a temporary support during underpinning.
Prick or pierce with or as if with a needle.
Provoke or annoy (someone) by continual criticism or questioning.
--Examples--
‘a darning needle’
‘the meter needle barely moved’
‘she wound the gramophone and lowered the needle on to the record’
‘just left of the needle is a steep wall for those who like bold climbing’
‘Cleopatra's Needle’
‘there is already a little bit of needle between the sides’
‘dust needled his eyes’
‘I just said that to Charlie to needle him’

--Word--
negation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The contradiction or denial of something.
Denial of the truth of a clause or sentence, typically involving the use of a negative word (e.g. not, no, never) or a word or affix with negative force (e.g. nothing, non-).
A proposition whose assertion specifically denies the truth of another proposition.
Inversion.
The absence or opposite of something actual or positive.
--Examples--
‘there should be confirmation—or negation—of the findings’
‘the negation of A is, briefly, ‘not A’’
‘these formulae and their negations’
‘evil is not merely the negation of goodness’
--Word--
negational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Negative; involving or characterized by negation.
--Examples--
--Word--
negationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who denies or rejects something.
--Examples--
--Word--
negation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The contradiction or denial of something.
Denial of the truth of a clause or sentence, typically involving the use of a negative word (e.g. not, no, never) or a word or affix with negative force (e.g. nothing, non-).
A proposition whose assertion specifically denies the truth of another proposition.
Inversion.
The absence or opposite of something actual or positive.
--Examples--
‘there should be confirmation—or negation—of the findings’
‘the negation of A is, briefly, ‘not A’’
‘these formulae and their negations’
‘evil is not merely the negation of goodness’
--Word--
negation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The contradiction or denial of something.
Denial of the truth of a clause or sentence, typically involving the use of a negative word (e.g. not, no, never) or a word or affix with negative force (e.g. nothing, non-).
A proposition whose assertion specifically denies the truth of another proposition.
Inversion.
The absence or opposite of something actual or positive.
--Examples--
‘there should be confirmation—or negation—of the findings’
‘the negation of A is, briefly, ‘not A’’
‘these formulae and their negations’
‘evil is not merely the negation of goodness’
--Word--
negative 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Consisting in or characterized by the absence rather than the presence of distinguishing features.
Expressing or implying denial, disagreement, or refusal.
(of the results of a test or experiment) indicating that a certain substance or condition is not present or does not exist.
(of a person) not having a specified condition or showing traces of a specified substance in their body.
Denoting a complete lack of something.
(of a word, clause, or proposition) stating that something is not the case; expressing negation.
No (usually used in a military context)
(of a person, attitude, or situation) not desirable or optimistic.
(of a quantity) less than zero.
Denoting decrease or reversal.
Containing, producing, or denoting the kind of electric charge carried by electrons.
(of a photographic image) showing light and shade or colours reversed from those of the original.
Relating to or denoting any of the earth or water signs, considered passive in nature.
(in Parliament) relating to or denoting proposed legislation which will come into force after a specified period unless explicitly rejected in a parliamentary vote.
A word or statement that expresses denial, disagreement, or refusal.
A bad or unwelcome quality or aspect of a situation.
A word, affix, or phrase expressing negation.
A negative photographic image made on film or specially prepared glass, from which positive prints may be made.
A result of a test or experiment indicating that a certain substance or condition is not present or does not exist.
The part of an electric circuit that is at a lower electrical potential than another part designated as having zero electrical potential.
A number less than zero.
Refuse to accept; reject.
Prove to be untrue.
Render ineffective; neutralize.
--Examples--
‘that, I take it, was a negative answer’
‘a negative test result’
‘all the patients have tested negative for TB’
‘HPV-negative’
‘they were described as having negative vulnerability to water entry’
‘‘Any snags, Captain?’ ‘Negative, she's running like clockwork.’’
‘the new tax was having a negative effect on car sales’
‘not all the news is negative’
‘I don't want to be negative, but I don't see how we could do it’
‘the industry suffered negative growth in the 1990s’
‘she replied in the negative’
‘confidence will not be instilled by harping solely on the negative’
‘photographs and negatives should be supplied for enlargement purposes’
‘the percentage of false negatives generated by a cancer test was of great concern’
‘the bill was negatived on second reading by 130 votes to 129’
‘the insurer's main arguments were negatived by Lawrence’
‘should criminal law allow consent to negative what would otherwise be a crime?’

--Word--
negatively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a negative way, especially by expressing denial, disagreement, or refusal.
In a way that indicates absence of a certain substance or condition.
In a way that is not desirable or optimistic.
With negative electric charge.
--Examples--
‘53 per cent of Americans view her negatively, compared to 40 per cent favourably’
‘investors reacted negatively to the news’
‘women who originally tested negatively for the hepatitis C virus’
‘traffic congestion had impacted negatively on their business’
‘negatively charged ions’

--Word--
negatron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Electronics. A valve with negative resistance, having an anode on one side of the cathode and a second anode and a control grid on the other side. Now historical.
Physics. An ordinary negatively charged electron (as distinct from a positron). Compare "negaton". Now disused.
--Examples--
--Word--
negatron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Electronics. A valve with negative resistance, having an anode on one side of the cathode and a second anode and a control grid on the other side. Now historical.
Physics. An ordinary negatively charged electron (as distinct from a positron). Compare "negaton". Now disused.

--Word--
Negev 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An arid region forming most of southern Israel, between Beersheba and the Gulf of Aqaba, on the Egyptian border. Large areas are irrigated for agriculture.

--Word--
neglect 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fail to care for properly.
Not pay proper attention to; disregard.
Fail to do something.
The state of being uncared for.
The action of not taking proper care of someone or something.
Failure to do something.
--Examples--
‘the old churchyard has been sadly neglected’
‘you neglect our advice at your peril’
‘he neglected to write to her’
‘the place had a hopeless air of neglect’
‘she was accused of child neglect’
‘he was reported for neglect of duty’

--Word--
negotiate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Obtain or bring about by discussion.
Try to reach an agreement or compromise by discussion.
Find a way over or through (an obstacle or difficult route)
Transfer (a cheque, bill, or other document) to the legal ownership of another person, who thus becomes entitled to any benefit.
Convert (a cheque) into cash or notes.
--Examples--
‘he negotiated a new contract with the sellers’
‘they refused to negotiate with the rebels’
‘she cautiously negotiated the hairpin bend’

Negro 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a dark-skinned group of peoples originally native to Africa south of the Sahara.
Relating to black people.
--Examples--
--Word--
Negro 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a dark-skinned group of peoples originally native to Africa south of the Sahara.
Relating to black people.
--Examples--

Negroid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the division of humankind represented by the indigenous peoples of central and southern Africa.

--Meanings--

Negros

proper noun
--Meanings--
An island, the fourth largest of the Philippines; population 3,602,200 (est. 2007); chief city, Bacolod.

--Word--
Niantic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of either of two North American Indian peoples living along the coast of Rhode Island and Connecticut at the time of first European contact.
Of or relating to the Niantics.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nehemiah 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(5th century BC) a Hebrew leader who supervised the rebuilding of the walls of Jerusalem (c.444 BC) and introduced moral and religious reforms (c.432 BC).
A book of the Bible telling of Nehemiah.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nehru, Jawaharlal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1889–1964), Indian statesman, prime minister 1947–64; known as Pandit Nehru. Nehru was elected leader of the Indian National Congress in 1929. He was imprisoned nine times by the British for his nationalist campaigns, but went on to become the first prime minister of independent India.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nei kuan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acupuncture point situated between the central tendons on the inner surface of the forearm, approximately five centimetres from the wrist.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ney, Michel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1768–1815), French marshal. One of Napoleon's leading generals, he commanded the French cavalry at Waterloo (1815), but after Napoleon's overthrow was executed by the Bourbons.
--Examples--
--Word--
neigh 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A characteristic high whinnying sound made by a horse.
(of a horse) utter a neigh.
(of a person) make a sound similar to a neigh, especially when laughing.
--Examples--
‘he neighed several times in a very gentle way’
‘the neighing of horses’
‘they neighed dutifully at jokes they did not understand’
--Word--
neighbour 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person living next door to or very near to the speaker or person referred to.
A person or place in relation to others next or near to it.
Any person in need of one's help or kindness (after biblical use)
(of a place or object) be situated next to or very near (another)
--Examples--
‘our garden was the envy of the neighbours’
‘I chatted with my neighbour on the flight to New York’
‘matching our investment levels with those of our European neighbours’
‘love thy neighbour as thyself’
‘the square neighbours the old quarter of the town’
--Word--

--Word--
neighbourhood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A district or community within a town or city.
The area surrounding a particular place, person, or object.
Neighbourly feeling or conduct.
The set of points whose distance from a given point is less than (or less than or equal to) some value.
--Examples--
‘she lived in a wealthy neighbourhood of Boston’
‘he was reluctant to leave the neighbourhood of London’
‘the importance of neighbourhood to old people’

--Word--
neighbour-like 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
In a neighbourly fashion; as befits a neighbour. Now also (Scottish and Irish English (northern)): in emulation of one's neighbours; so as not to be outdone by one's neighbours.
Scottish and Irish English (northern). Emulating one's neighbours; striving not to be outdone by one's neighbours.

Sedaka, Neil 
--Type--
proper noun

--Examples--
--Word--
Sedaka, Neil 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1939), US singer and songwriter. He became popular during the 1960s and 1970s with hits such as “Breaking Up Is Hard to Do” (1962) and “Laughter in the Rain” (1974).
--Examples--
--Word--
Neisse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in central Europe, which rises in the north of the Czech Republic and flows over 225 km (140 miles) generally northwards, forming the southern part of the border between Germany and Poland (the Oder–Neisse Line) and joining the River Oder north-east of Cottbus.
A river of southern Poland, which rises near the border with the Czech Republic and flows 195 km (120 miles) generally north-eastwards, through the town of Nysa, joining the River Oder south-east of Wrocław.
--Examples--
--Word--
Neisseria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-negative, aerobic diplococci, chiefly comprising commensal inhabitants of the mucous membranes of humans and other mammals, but including several major pathogens, especially the causative agents of gonorrhoea (N. gonorrhoeae, also called gonococcus) and a form of bacterial meningitis (N. meningitidis, also called meningococcus). Also (in form neisseria): a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
neither 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Not the one nor the other of two people or things; not either.
Used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives (the others being introduced by ‘nor’) to indicate that they are each untrue or each does not happen.
Used to introduce a further negative statement.
--Examples--
‘neither side of the brain is dominant over the other’
‘neither of us believes it’
‘I am neither a liberal nor a conservative’
‘he didn't remember, and neither did I’
--Word--
Nejd 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An arid plateau region in central Saudi Arabia, north of the Rub' al-Khali desert, at an altitude of about 1,500 m (5,000 ft).

Gwyn, Nell 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1650–87), English actress; full name Eleanor Gwyn. Originally an orange seller, she became famous as a comedienne at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London. She was a mistress of Charles II.

--Word--
nelson 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wrestling hold in which one arm is passed under the opponent's arm from behind and the hand is applied to the neck (half nelson), or both arms and hands are applied (full nelson).
A port in New Zealand, on the north coast of the South Island; population 42,888 (2006). It was founded in 1841 by the New Zealand Company and named after the British admiral Lord Nelson.

Neman 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of eastern Europe, which rises south of Minsk in Belarus and flows 955 km (597 miles) west and north to the Baltic Sea. Its lower course, which forms the boundary between Lithuania and the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad, is called the Memel.

nematoceran 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the suborder Nematocera of dipteran flies, comprising those with long, straight, antennae with six or more segments (including mosquitoes, crane flies, midges, gnats, etc.).
A member of this suborder.

nematocyst 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A specialized cell in the tentacles of a jellyfish or other coelenterate, containing a barbed or venomous coiled thread that can be projected in self-defence or to capture prey.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nematoda 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large phylum of worms with slender, unsegmented, cylindrical bodies, including the roundworms, threadworms, and eelworms. They are found abundantly in soil and water, and many are parasites.
--Examples--
--Word--
nematode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A worm of the large phylum Nematoda, such as a roundworm or threadworm.
--Examples--
--Word--
nematode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A worm of the large phylum Nematoda, such as a roundworm or threadworm.
--Examples--
--Word--
nematogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. In certain mesozoans: an adult form that can reproduce asexually via a vermiform larval stage or give rise to the sexual adult form (rhombogen).
Physical Chemistry. A substance which can under certain conditions behave as a nematic liquid crystal.
--Examples--
--Word--
nematogenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Physical Chemistry. Able to behave as a liquid crystal; of or relating to a nematogen.
--Examples--
--Word--
nematognath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fish of the order Nematognathi (now Siluriformes); a catfish. Now rare or disused.

--Examples--
--Word--
nembutsu 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
In some forms of Japanese Buddhism: an invocation of Amida (Amitabha) chanted to achieve self-purification and spiritual awakening in this life (satori) and rebirth into Amida's Pure Land after death, to express gratitude to Amida on realization of enlightenment, or to cancel bad karma.
In extended use: the action, practice, or doctrine of reciting the nembutsu; Pure Land Buddhism.
Of or relating to the recitation of the nembutsu; belonging to the school of Pure Land Buddhism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nemean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to Nemea; specifically (in Classical Mythology) designating a monstrous lion said to have terrorized the Nemean region until killed by Hercules as the first of his twelve labours.
Greek History. Designating one of the national festivals of ancient Greece, held at Nemea in the second and fourth years of each Olympiad. Usually as "Nemean games", "Nemean festival".
--Examples--
--Word--
Nemertea 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A small phylum that comprises the ribbon worms.

--Word--
nemesis 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The inescapable agent of someone's or something's downfall.
A long-standing rival; an arch-enemy.
A downfall caused by an inescapable agent.
Retributive justice.
A goddess usually portrayed as the agent of divine punishment for wrongdoing or presumption (hubris).
--Examples--
‘injury, consistently his nemesis, struck him down during the match’
‘will Harry Potter finally defeat his nemesis, Voldemort?’
‘one risks nemesis by uttering such words’
‘Nemesis is notoriously slow’
--Word--
nemesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant related to the snapdragon, which is cultivated for its colourful funnel-shaped flowers.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging or relating to the group Nemocera (now the suborder Nematocera) of dipteran flies; nematoceran, nematocerous.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nemophila 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of annual herbaceous plants (family Hydrophyllaceae) native to western North America; (also nemophila) a plant of this genus, especially baby-blue-eyes, N. insignis, having cup-shaped blue flowers with a white centre, or a cultivated variety of this.

nemo dat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The basic principle that a person who does not own property, especially a thief, cannot confer it on another except with the true owner's authority.

--Word--
nenta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) Any of several poisonous plants of the family Crassulaceae, especially species of the genus Tylecodon (formerly Cotyledon). (b) The poisonous plant Lessertia annularis of the family Fabaceae (Leguminosae). rare.
Veterinary Medicine. A disorder of goats and sheep characterized by torticollis, convulsions, colic, collapse, and often death, caused by the ingestion of any of a variety of poisonous plants, especially of the genus Tylecodon.
--Examples--
--Word--
nenuphar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A water lily, especially the white water lily, Nymphaea alba, or the yellow water lily, Nuphar luteum. Also (especially in "†oil of nenuphar", "†syrup of nenuphar"): the roots, leaves, flowers, or seeds of these plants, used in medicinal preparations (obsolete). Now literary.

neanthropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the single extant species of human, Homo sapiens, as opposed to extinct forms or species known only from fossil remains. Now chiefly historical.

neoarsphenamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The sodium salt of a sulphated arsphenamine derivative, C₁₃H₁₃As₂N₂NaO₄S, a toxic yellow compound used to treat bacterial infections (formerly especially syphilis, now only in veterinary medicine).

The dialect of Greek used by the ancient Athenians. It was the chief literary form of classical Greek.

--Word--
neodymium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 60, a silvery-white metal of the lanthanide series. Neodymium is a component of misch metal and some other alloys, and its compounds are used in colouring glass and ceramics.

Egyptian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Egypt or its people.
Relating to the culture or language of ancient Egypt.
A native of ancient or modern Egypt, or a person of Egyptian descent.
The Afro-Asiatic language used in ancient Egypt, attested from c.3000 BC. It is represented in its oldest stages by hieroglyphic inscriptions and in its latest form by Coptic; it has been replaced in modern use by Arabic.

neognathous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating the type of palate and jaw characteristic of nearly all living and some fossil birds (forming the superorder Neognathae), in which, among other features, the vomers are usually small and completely fused.
--Examples--
--Word--
neo-Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or in a style of art and architecture that originated in the 19th century, characterized by the revival of medieval Gothic forms. In architecture it is manifested in pointed arches, vaulted ceilings, and mock fortifications.
The neo-Gothic style.
--Examples--
‘the large western window typical of neo-Gothic churches’
--Word--
Neogrammarian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a group of 19th-century German scholars who, having noticed that sound changes in language are regular and that therefore lost word forms can be reconstructed, postulated the forms of entire lost languages such as Proto-Indo-European by the comparison of related forms in existing languages.
--Examples--

--Word--
Hebrew 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient people living in what is now Israel and Palestine and, according to biblical tradition, descended from the patriarch Jacob, grandson of Abraham. After the Exodus (c.1300 BC) they established the kingdoms of Israel and Judah, and their scriptures and traditions form the basis of the Jewish religion.
A Jew.
The Semitic language spoken by the Hebrews, in its ancient or modern form.
Of or in Hebrew.
Of the Hebrews or the Jews.

neo-impressionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A late 19th-century movement in French painting which sought to improve on impressionism through a systematic approach to form and colour, particularly using pointillist technique. The movement's leading figures included Georges Seurat, Paul Signac, and Camille Pissarro.

--Type--

--Meanings--
Of or relating to neo-Lamarckism.

--Examples--
--Word--
neo-Lamarckism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various theories of evolution which seek to retain Lamarck's idea that heritable variation can be caused by environmental influence during the life of an organism (inheritance of acquired characteristics), contrary to the usual assumptions of neo-Darwinian theory.

neomorph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. An anatomical structure or feature that has arisen during phylogeny as a new development, rather than by derivation from earlier features; a structure that does not have a homologue in earlier forms.
Genetics. A mutant allele that produces an effect qualitatively different from that of the wild-type allele.
--Examples--
--Word--
neomorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to neomorphism; that has undergone neomorphism.
Biology. Designating or relating to a neomorph.
Genetics. That results in a qualitative alteration of function; of, relating to, or creating a neomorph.
--Examples--
--Word--
neomorphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. The evolutionary process that gives rise to a new anatomical structure or feature; the development of a neomorph; an instance of this.
Genetics. The property of being a neomorph.
Geology. The diagenetic transformation of a mineral which results in its replacement by new crystals of the same mineral or of a polymorph.
--Examples--
--Word--
neomorph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. An anatomical structure or feature that has arisen during phylogeny as a new development, rather than by derivation from earlier features; a structure that does not have a homologue in earlier forms.
Genetics. A mutant allele that produces an effect qualitatively different from that of the wild-type allele.
--Examples--
--Word--
neon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 10, an inert gaseous element of the noble gas group. It is obtained by the distillation of liquid air and is used in fluorescent lamps and illuminated advertising signs.
Fluorescent lighting or signs using neon or another gas.
A small lamp containing neon.
Very bright or fluorescent in colour.
--Examples--
‘the lobby of the hotel was bright with neon’
‘neons indicate the state of the mains wiring’
‘she had recently dyed her hair neon pink’

--Word--
neon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 10, an inert gaseous element of the noble gas group. It is obtained by the distillation of liquid air and is used in fluorescent lamps and illuminated advertising signs.
Fluorescent lighting or signs using neon or another gas.
A small lamp containing neon.
Very bright or fluorescent in colour.
--Examples--
‘the lobby of the hotel was bright with neon’
‘neons indicate the state of the mains wiring’
‘she had recently dyed her hair neon pink’
--Word--
neontology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of zoology dealing with living forms as distinct from fossils.

neopagan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a modern religious movement that seeks to incorporate beliefs or ritual practices from traditions outside the main world religions, especially those of pre-Christian Europe and North America.
Relating to a modern religious movement that seeks to incorporate beliefs or ritual practices from traditions outside main world religions, especially those of pre-Christian Europe and North America.
--Examples--
‘religious neopagans are not too far distant from a conventional religion’
‘the American neopagan community’
‘neopagan nature worship’

neopallium

Persian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of ancient or modern Persia (or Iran), or a person of Persian descent.
A long-haired domestic cat of a breed originating in Persia, having a broad round head, stocky body, and short thick legs.
A sheep of a breed common in South Africa.
The modern Persian language, a member of the Iranian branch of the Indo-European family written in Arabic script.
An earlier form of Persian spoken in ancient or medieval Persia.
Relating to ancient Persia or modern Iran or its people or language.

--Word--
roman 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A red or pink South African sea bream.
Relating to ancient Rome or its empire or people.
Relating to medieval or modern Rome.
Denoting the alphabet (or any of the letters in it) used for writing Latin, English, and most European languages, developed in ancient Rome.
(of type) of a plain upright kind used in ordinary print, especially as distinguished from italic and Gothic.
A citizen or soldier of the ancient Roman Republic or Empire.
A citizen of modern Rome.
A Roman Catholic.
Roman type.
--Examples--
‘a site rich in finds from Bronze Age and Roman settlements’
‘the Roman and Pisan lines of popes’
‘the Roman Church's instructions to its clergy’
‘he substituted the Roman alphabet for the Arabic in written Turkish’
‘each complete type family in bold, italic, bold italic and roman’
‘the Romans had a formidable army’
‘it is signed in roman rather than his usual cursive script’

Neotropical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Central and South America, including the tropical southern part of Mexico and the Caribbean. Distinctive animals include edentates, opossums, marmosets, and tamarins.
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising Central and South America but excluding the southern parts of Chile and Argentina.

neovolcanic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating volcanic rocks and phenomena dating from the Tertiary period (up to about 65 million years ago) to the present time (contrasted with palaeovolcanic). Now often: specifically designating or relating to zones of recent volcanic activity.

Neozoic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating an era following the Palaeozoic era, comprising both the Mesozoic and Cenozoic (Cainozoic) eras.
Frequently with the. Of, belonging to, or designating the most recent era; = "Cainozoic".
The Neozoic era; the rocks collectively dating from this time.

neper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of measurement used in comparing voltages, currents, and power levels, especially in communication circuits. The difference between two values in nepers is equal to the natural logarithm of their ratio for voltages and currents or to half of this for power differences.

nephridium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in many invertebrate animals) a tubule open to the exterior which acts as an organ of excretion or osmoregulation. It typically has ciliated or flagellated cells and absorptive walls.
--Examples--

--Word--
nephrocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(In various invertebrates) a cell whose function involves the accumulation or formation of waste or excretory products; specifically such a cell found in the haemocoel of many insects and other arthropods.

noun

--Word--
Neptunism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The erroneous theory that rocks such as granite were formed by crystallization from the waters of a primeval ocean. The chief advocate of this theory was Abraham Gottlob Werner.
--Examples--
--Word--
Neptunist 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
neptunium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 93, a radioactive metal of the actinide series. Neptunium was discovered as a product of the bombardment of uranium with neutrons, and occurs only in trace amounts in nature.
--Examples--

--Word--
nereid 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A bristle worm of the ragworm family (Nereidae ).
Any of the sea nymphs, daughters of Nereus. They include Thetis, mother of Achilles.
A satellite of Neptune, the furthest from the planet, discovered in 1949. It has an irregular shape (with a diameter of about 340 km) and an eccentric orbit.
--Examples--

Nerita 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of various, probably chiefly aquatic, gastropod molluscs. Later: specifically any mollusc of the genus Nerita, comprising tropical marine prosobranch gastropods with a thick shell, a short or flattened spire, and a semicircular aperture.

Nernst potential 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An electrical potential occurring in connection with the Nernst equation or the Nernst effect; specifically (for an ion passing across a membrane) the potential at which the diffusion force on the ion balances the electrical force acting on it.

Nero 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(AD 37–68), Roman emperor 54–68; full name Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus. Infamous for his cruelty, he wantonly executed leading Romans. His reign witnessed a fire which destroyed half of Rome in 64.

Neruda, Pablo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–73), Chilean poet and diplomat; born Ricardo Eliezer Neftalí Reyes. He took his pseudonym from the Czech poet Jan Neruda. His Canto General (completed 1950) is an epic covering the history of the Americas.

nervism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Physiology. A theory (advocated mainly by I. P. Pavlov and his followers) ascribing the control of most normal and abnormal physiological processes to the central nervous system. Now historical.

--Word--
nerve 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A whitish fibre or bundle of fibres in the body that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs.
One's steadiness and courage in a demanding situation.
Impudence or audacity.
Feelings of nervousness.
A prominent unbranched rib in a leaf, especially in the midrib of the leaf of a moss.
Brace oneself mentally to face a demanding situation.
--Examples--
‘the optic nerve’
‘an amazing journey which tested her nerves to the full’
‘he kept his nerve and won five games in a row’
‘he had the nerve to insult my cooking’
‘you've got a nerve coming here’
‘his first-night nerves soon disappeared’
‘she nerved herself to enter the room’
--Word--
ache 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
An emotion experienced with painful or bittersweet intensity.
Suffer from a continuous dull pain.
Feel intense sadness or compassion.
Feel an intense desire for.
--Examples--
‘the ache in her head worsened’
‘he had stomach ache’
‘an ache in her heart’
‘my legs ached from the previous day's exercise’
‘I'm aching all over’
‘she sat still and silent, her heart aching’
‘she looked so tired that my heart ached for her’
‘she ached for his touch’
‘he was aching to get his hands on the ball’

celled

--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘a single-celled organism’
--Word--
cutting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of cutting something.
A piece cut off from something, especially what remains when something is being trimmed or prepared.
An article or other piece cut from a newspaper or periodical.
A piece cut from a plant for propagation.
An open passage excavated through higher ground for a railway, road, or canal.
Capable of cutting something.
(of a comment) causing emotional pain; hurtful.
(of the wind) bitterly cold.
--Examples--
‘the cutting of the cake’
‘tax-cutting’
‘grass cuttings’
‘an archive of newspaper cuttings’
‘take cuttings of Christmas cactus and pot them on’
‘they found the cutting and scrambled down the slope’
‘the cutting blades of the hedge trimmer’
‘a cutting remark’
‘cutting winter winds’

--Meanings--
(of a medicine) used to calm the nerves.
A nervine medicine.
--Examples--
--Word--
nerviness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nerve 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A whitish fibre or bundle of fibres in the body that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs.
One's steadiness and courage in a demanding situation.
Impudence or audacity.
Feelings of nervousness.
A prominent unbranched rib in a leaf, especially in the midrib of the leaf of a moss.
Brace oneself mentally to face a demanding situation.
--Examples--
‘the optic nerve’
‘an amazing journey which tested her nerves to the full’
‘he kept his nerve and won five games in a row’
‘he had the nerve to insult my cooking’
‘you've got a nerve coming here’
‘his first-night nerves soon disappeared’
‘she nerved herself to enter the room’
--Word--
nerved 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘he was steely-nerved after the accident’
--Word--
nervish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Nervous, anxious, agitated.
--Examples--
--Word--
nervism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Physiology. A theory (advocated mainly by I. P. Pavlov and his followers) ascribing the control of most normal and abnormal physiological processes to the central nervous system. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
pars nervosa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The main part of the neurohypophysis (the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland).
--Examples--
--Word--
nervose 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany. Of a leaf or other plant part: having veins or nerves; specifically having parallel venation.
--Examples--
--Word--
nervosity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being nervous or of experiencing disordered or heightened sensitivity; nervousness.

--Word--
nervous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Easily agitated or alarmed.
Anxious or apprehensive.
(of a feeling or reaction) resulting from anxiety or anticipation.
Relating to or affecting the nerves.
--Examples--
‘a sensitive, nervous person’
‘staying in the house on her own made her nervous’
‘he's nervous of speaking in public’
‘nervous energy’
‘a nervous disorder’
--Word--
nervously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an anxious or apprehensive manner.
--Examples--
‘Kevin nervously glanced at his watch’
‘I was blushing and smiling nervously’
--Word--
nervousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being nervous.
--Examples--
‘there was a trace of nervousness in his voice’

noun
--Meanings--
A small nerve or vein in a leaf or other plant part or in an insect's wing.

noun

--Word--
Nesbit, E. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1858–1924), English novelist; full name Edith Nesbit. She is best known for her children's books, including Five Children and It (1902) and The Railway Children (1906).

nesquehonite

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
nessberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A North American soft fruit of the loganberry type; the bush producing this, thought to be a cross between a North American dewberry and a North American raspberry, or perhaps a variety or cultivar of the former.

Nesselrode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "Nesselrode cream", "Nesselrode pie", "Nesselrode pudding". An iced dessert made with chestnuts, cream, preserved fruits, etc., and frequently flavoured with rum.

--Word--
nesslerize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To treat (a solution or sample) with Nessler's reagent. Also: to measure the concentration of (ammonia) by means of the Nessler test.
--Examples--

nesslerization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Nessus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A centaur who was killed by Hercules with a poisoned arrow. Hercules eventually died when he was given a shirt smeared with the centaur's blood, which poisoned him.
--Examples--
--Word--
nest 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A structure or place made or chosen by a bird for laying eggs and sheltering its young.
A place where an insect or other animal breeds or shelters.
Something in the form of a bowl or layer, used to hold, protect, or support something.
A person's snug or secluded retreat.
A place filled with undesirable people, activities, or things.
A set of similar objects of graduated sizes, made so that each smaller one fits into the next in size for storage.
(of a bird or other animal) use or build a nest.
Fit (an object or objects) inside a larger one.
(of a set of objects) fit inside one another.
(especially in computing and linguistics) place (an object or element) in a lower position in a hierarchy.
--Examples--
‘two sparrows frantically building a nest’
‘a nest site’
‘an ants' nest’
‘potato nests filled with okra’
‘I'm off to my cosy nest’
‘a nest of spies’
‘a nest of tables’
‘the owls often nest in barns’
‘the town is nested inside a large crater on the flanks of a volcano’
‘Russian dolls that nest inside one another’
--Word--
nestable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being nested or packed within one another; (Computing, of subroutines, files, etc.) able to be embedded within similar objects to form a hierarchical structure.
--Examples--

--Word--
Nestor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A king of Pylos in the Peloponnese, who in old age led his subjects to the Trojan War. His wisdom was proverbial.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nestorian 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Nestorianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Christian doctrine that there were two separate persons, one human and one divine, in the incarnate Christ. It is named after Nestorius, patriarch of Constantinople (428–31), and was maintained by some ancient Churches of the Middle East. A small Nestorian Church still exists in Iraq.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nestorianizing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Professing, teaching, or tending towards Nestorianism.

--Word--
net 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of open-meshed material made of twine, cord, or something similar, used typically for catching fish or other animals.
A piece of net supported by a frame at the end of a handle, used for catching fish or insects.
The total amount of fish caught in one session or expedition.
A structure consisting of a net supported on a frame, forming the goal in games such as soccer and hockey.
A net supported on a cord between two posts to divide the playing area in tennis, badminton, volleyball, etc.
A strip of ground enclosed by a net, for batting and bowling practice.
A safety net.
A fine fabric with a very open weave.
Net curtains.
A means of catching someone; a trap.
A means of selecting or securing someone or something.
A communications or broadcasting network, especially of maritime radio.
A network of interconnected computers.
The Internet.
Catch (a fish or other animal) with a net.
Fish with nets in (a river)
Acquire or obtain in a skilful way.
(in sport) hit (a ball) into the net; score (a goal)
Cover with a net.
--Examples--
‘fishermen mending their nets’
‘good nets of roach, chub, and perch’
‘he turned Wilson's cross into the net’
‘Wales did find the net in the 32nd minute’
‘a full net practice’
‘he felt like a tightrope-walker without a net’
‘net curtains’
‘the search was delayed, allowing the murderers to escape the net’
‘he spread his net far and wide in his long search for success’
‘the radio net was brought to life with a mayday’
‘a computer news net’
‘ensuring privacy on the Net is an increasingly difficult job’
‘damage caused when netting the fish’
‘rabbits can be netted all the year round’
‘they were netting the River Naver’
‘customs officials have netted large caches of drugs’
‘Butler netted 14 goals’
‘we fenced off a rabbit-proof area for vegetables and netted the top’
--Word--
netball 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A seven-a-side game in which goals are scored by throwing a ball so that it falls through a netted hoop. By contrast with basketball, a player receiving the ball must stand still until they have passed it to another player.
The ball used in netball.
--Examples--
--Word--
nete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The name of the highest note in each of the highest two tetrachords.
--Examples--

Netherlands

The Low Countries.

noun

Fish with nets in (a river)
Acquire or obtain in a skilful way.
(in sport) hit (a ball) into the net; score (a goal)
Cover with a net.
--Examples--
‘fishermen mending their nets’
‘good nets of roach, chub, and perch’
‘he turned Wilson's cross into the net’
‘Wales did find the net in the 32nd minute’
‘a full net practice’
‘he felt like a tightrope-walker without a net’
‘net curtains’
‘the search was delayed, allowing the murderers to escape the net’
‘he spread his net far and wide in his long search for success’
‘the radio net was brought to life with a mayday’
‘a computer news net’
‘ensuring privacy on the Net is an increasingly difficult job’
‘damage caused when netting the fish’
‘rabbits can be netted all the year round’
‘they were netting the River Naver’
‘customs officials have netted large caches of drugs’
‘Butler netted 14 goals’
‘we fenced off a rabbit-proof area for vegetables and netted the top’
--Word--
veined 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Marked with or as if with veins.
--Examples--
‘a blue-veined cheese’
--Word--
tender 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Showing gentleness, kindness, and affection.
Solicitous of.
(of food) easy to cut or chew; not tough.
(of a part of the body) sensitive to pain.
(of a plant) easily injured by severe weather and therefore needing protection.
Requiring tact or careful handling.
Young, inexperienced, or vulnerable.
(of a ship) leaning or readily inclined to roll in response to the wind.
--Examples--
‘he was being so kind and tender’
‘she covered his face with tender kisses’
‘be tender of a lady's reputation’
‘tender green beans’
‘the pale, tender skin of her forearm’
‘pelargoniums are colourful but tender plants’
‘the issue of conscription was a particularly tender one’
‘he started sailing at the tender age of ten’
--Word--
netter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fisherman who uses nets to catch fish.
Someone who uses a net of a specified type.
A person who uses the Internet.
--Examples--
‘because of the ban on gill nets, Louisianans fear an influx of jobless Florida netters’
‘drift-netters’

nettle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant which has jagged leaves covered with stinging hairs.
Used in names of other plants with leaves of a similar appearance to those of the nettle, e.g. dead-nettle.
Irritate or annoy (someone)
Sting with nettles.
--Examples--
‘‘I was only asking,’ Jess said, nettled’

--Word--
net 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of open-meshed material made of twine, cord, or something similar, used typically for catching fish or other animals.
A piece of net supported by a frame at the end of a handle, used for catching fish or insects.
The total amount of fish caught in one session or expedition.
A structure consisting of a net supported on a frame, forming the goal in games such as soccer and hockey.
A net supported on a cord between two posts to divide the playing area in tennis, badminton, volleyball, etc.
A strip of ground enclosed by a net, for batting and bowling practice.
A safety net.
A fine fabric with a very open weave.
Net curtains.
A means of catching someone; a trap.
A means of selecting or securing someone or something.
A communications or broadcasting network, especially of maritime radio.
A network of interconnected computers.
The Internet.
Catch (a fish or other animal) with a net.
Fish with nets in (a river)
Acquire or obtain in a skilful way.
(in sport) hit (a ball) into the net; score (a goal)
Cover with a net.
--Examples--
‘fishermen mending their nets’
‘good nets of roach, chub, and perch’
‘he turned Wilson's cross into the net’
‘Wales did find the net in the 32nd minute’
‘a full net practice’
‘he felt like a tightrope-walker without a net’
‘net curtains’
‘the search was delayed, allowing the murderers to escape the net’
‘he spread his net far and wide in his long search for success’
‘the radio net was brought to life with a mayday’
‘a computer news net’
‘ensuring privacy on the Net is an increasingly difficult job’
‘damage caused when netting the fish’
‘rabbits can be netted all the year round’
‘they were netting the River Naver’
‘customs officials have netted large caches of drugs’
‘Butler netted 14 goals’
‘we fenced off a rabbit-proof area for vegetables and netted the top’

--Word--
network 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An arrangement of intersecting horizontal and vertical lines.
A group or system of interconnected people or things.
A complex system of railways, roads, or other routes.
A group of people who exchange information and contacts for professional or social purposes.
A group of broadcasting stations that connect for the simultaneous broadcast of a programme.
A number of interconnected computers, machines, or operations.
A system of connected electrical conductors.
Connect as or operate with a network.
Broadcast (a programme) on a network.
Link (computers or other machines) to operate interactively.
Interact with others to exchange information and develop professional or social contacts.
--Examples--
‘a spider constructs a complex network of several different kinds of threads’
‘the company has a network of 326 branches’
‘a trade network’
‘the railway network’
‘a support network’
‘network television’
‘a computer network’
‘compared with the railways the canals were less effectively networked’
‘the Spurs match which ITV had networked’
‘more and more PCs are networked together’
‘networked workstations’
‘the skills of networking, bargaining, and negotiation’

--Word--
neu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Usually in form neu: an oncogene originally identified in rat glioblastoma cells, which is overexpressed in some human malignancies, especially breast and ovarian cancers. Also (usually in form Neu): the product of this gene, which is a membrane protein related to the epidermal growth factor receptor.
--Examples--
--Word--
Neuchâtel, Lake 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The largest lake lying wholly within Switzerland, situated at the foot of the Jura Mountains in western Switzerland.

--Word--
seine 
--Type--
noun, verb, proper noun
--Meanings--
A fishing net which hangs vertically in the water with floats at the top and weights at the bottom edge, the ends being drawn together to encircle the fish.
Fish (an area) with a seine.
Catch (fish) with a seine.
A river of northern France. Rising north of Dijon, it flows north-westwards for 761 km (473 miles), through the cities of Troyes and Paris to the English Channel near Le Havre.
--Examples--
‘a seine boat’
‘the fishermen then seine the weir’
‘they seine whitefish and salmon’

Neumann problem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The problem of finding a solution to a partial differential equation within a bounded region, given the first partial derivative of the solution at the boundary in the direction normal to the boundary.

--Word--
neurenteric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Usually in form neurenteric. Designating a transient communication between the archenteron and the neural tube (or the yolk sac and the amniotic cavity) in vertebrate embryos. Also: designating a congenital malformation arising from a persistent connection between embryonic neural and intestinal tissue.
Of or relating to the neural structures or function of the gastrointestinal tract.
--Examples--
--Word--
neuridine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A polyamine isolated from putrefying animal tissue.

--Meanings--

neurility 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property of nerve tissue of being able to conduct impulses. Later also: neural nature (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
neurine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biochemistry. A quaternary ammonium compound which is present in various animal tissues and is also formed during putrefaction by dehydration of choline, and can be isolated as a toxic, odoriferous, syrupy liquid; trimethylvinylammonium hydroxide, CH₂=CHN(CH₃)₃OH. Formerly also: †choline itself (obsolete).
--Examples--

neurocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A nerve cell; = "neuron".
--Examples--
--Word--
neurocytoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: = "neuroblastoma" (now rare or disused). Later: a neuronal neoplasm; specifically (more fully "central neurocytoma", "intraventricular neurocytoma") an intraventricular neoplasm, usually benign, typically occurring in young adults and composed of uniform small cells of glial appearance but with neuronal differentiation.
--Examples--
--Word--
neurocoele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The central cavity of the embryonic neural tube or of the (developing) neuraxis.
--Examples--
--Word--
neurocoele 
--Type--

neurodermatitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

neuroepithelium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of epithelium containing sensory nerve endings and found in certain sense organs (e.g. the retina, the inner ear, the nasal membranes, and the taste buds).
(in embryology) ectoderm that develops into nerve tissue.

neuroleptanalgesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of pain relief employing an antipsychotic (neuroleptic) drug and an opioid analgesic; the state of sedation and indifference to pain, with retention of the ability to respond to commands, produced by this.

neuropter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect of the order Neuroptera; a neuropteran.
--Examples--
--Word--
Neuroptera 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
An order of predatory flying insects that includes the lacewings, alderflies, snake flies, and ant lions. They have four finely veined membranous wings.
Insects of the order Neuroptera.
--Examples--
‘the larvae of certain neuroptera’
--Word--
neuropteran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A predatory flying insect of the order Neuroptera, such as a lacewing or alderfly.
Relating to or denoting neuropterans.
--Examples--
--Word--
neuropterist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An entomologist who is an expert or specialist in the order Neuroptera.
--Examples--
--Word--
neuropteroid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling insects of the order Neuroptera; specifically designating or belonging to a group (sometimes referred to as the section Neuropterida) that comprises the neuroptera in the broader sense.
A neuropteroid insect.

noun

--Word--
neurosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A relatively mild mental illness that is not caused by organic disease, involving symptoms of stress (depression, anxiety, obsessive behaviour, hypochondria) but not a radical loss of touch with reality.
(in non-technical use) excessive and irrational anxiety or obsession.
--Examples--
‘Freud's two-stage account of neurosis’
‘psychoses, neuroses, and personality disorders’
‘too much neurosis about a child's progress is unproductive’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

neurotransmission 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘alterations of neurotransmission that affect consciousness and behaviour’
--Word--
neurotransmitter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chemical substance which is released at the end of a nerve fibre by the arrival of a nerve impulse and, by diffusing across the synapse or junction, effects the transfer of the impulse to another nerve fibre, a muscle fibre, or some other structure.
--Examples--
--Word--

Neustrian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Neustria, the western part of the Frankish empire (lying roughly west of the Meuse and north of the Loire rivers) in the Merovingian period.

adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of or denoting a gender of nouns in some languages, typically contrasting with masculine and feminine or common.
(of an animal) lacking developed sexual organs, or having had them removed.
(of a plant or flower) having neither functional pistils nor functional stamens.
(of a person) apparently having no sexual characteristics; asexual.
A neuter word.
The neuter gender.
A non-fertile caste of social insect, especially a worker bee or ant.
A castrated or spayed domestic animal.
An asexual person.
Castrate or spay (a domestic animal)
Make ineffective.
--Examples--
‘the Spirit is a neuter word in Greek’
‘soft, languid, sexually neuter types’
‘the conquering hero is a neuter’
‘all pit bulls must be registered and neutered’
‘a neutered tomcat’
‘disarmament negotiations that will neuter their military power’
--Word--
neuterdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being neuter (sexually or grammatically).
--Examples--
--Word--
neuter

--Word--
neuter 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of or denoting a gender of nouns in some languages, typically contrasting with masculine and feminine or common.
(of an animal) lacking developed sexual organs, or having had them removed.
(of a plant or flower) having neither functional pistils nor functional stamens.
(of a person) apparently having no sexual characteristics; asexual.

The neuter gender.
A non-fertile caste of social insect, especially a worker bee or ant.
A castrated or spayed domestic animal.
An asexual person.
Castrate or spay (a domestic animal)
Make ineffective.
--Examples--
‘the Spirit is a neuter word in Greek’

‘the conquering hero is a neuter’
‘all pit bulls must be registered and neutered’
‘a neutered tomcat’
‘disarmament negotiations that will neuter their military power’
--Word--
neutral 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Not supporting or helping either side in a conflict, disagreement, etc.; impartial.
Belonging to an impartial group or state.
Having no strongly marked or positive characteristics or features.
Of or denoting a pale grey, cream, or beige colour.
Neither acid nor alkaline; having a pH of about 7.
Having neither a positive nor negative electrical charge.
An impartial or unbiased state or person.
Pale grey, cream, or beige.
A disengaged position of gears in which the engine is disconnected from the driven parts.
An electrically neutral point, terminal, conductor, or wire.
--Examples--
‘neutral and non-aligned European nations’
‘the trial should be held on neutral ground’
‘her tone was neutral, devoid of sentiment’
‘walls are painted in neutral tones’
‘a neutral solution’
‘neutral soil conditions’
‘live and neutral contacts on plugs’
‘Sweden and its fellow neutrals’
‘I attended the Cup Final as a neutral’
‘classic shades of navy, white, and neutral’
‘she slipped the gear into neutral’
--Word--
neutralize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (something) ineffective by applying an opposite force or effect.
Make (an acidic or alkaline substance) chemically neutral.
Disarm (a bomb or similar weapon)
(in military or espionage contexts) used euphemistically to refer to killing or destruction.
--Examples--
‘impatience at his frailty began to neutralize her fear’
‘splashes on skin should be neutralized immediately’
‘120 bombs were neutralized’
‘counter-intelligence programmes designed to neutralize individuals’
--Word--
neutralism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A policy of political neutrality.
--Examples--
‘the arms deal was likely to encourage neutralism in the area’
--Word--
neutralist 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
neutralist 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
neutrality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of not supporting or helping either side in a conflict, disagreement, etc.; impartiality.
Absence of decided views, expression, or strong feeling.
The condition of being chemically or electrically neutral.
--Examples--
‘during the war, Switzerland maintained its neutrality’
‘the clinical neutrality of the description’
‘the structure has overall electrical neutrality’

neutretto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muon neutrino. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
neutretto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muon neutrino. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
neutrino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A neutral subatomic particle with a mass close to zero and half-integral spin, which rarely reacts with normal matter. Three kinds of neutrinos are known, associated with the electron, muon, and tau particle.
--Examples--
--Word--
neutrino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A neutral subatomic particle with a mass close to zero and half-integral spin, which rarely reacts with normal matter. Three kinds of neutrinos are known, associated with the electron, muon, and tau particle.
--Examples--

neutrino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
neutrodyne 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of high-frequency valve amplifier in which neutralization is employed to prevent oscillation throughout a range of frequencies. Usually attributive.
--Examples--
--Word--
neutron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle of about the same mass as a proton but without an electric charge, present in all atomic nuclei except those of ordinary hydrogen.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun

neutropenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The presence of abnormally few neutrophils in the blood, leading to increased susceptibility to infection.

--Meanings--

--Word--
neutrophilic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a cell or its contents) readily stained only by neutral dyes.
(of a medical condition) characterized by the presence of unusually high numbers of neutrophilic cells.
--Examples--
‘we investigated the in vitro control of MRSA by neutrophilic granulocytes because they contribute to abscess formation’
‘acute lung injury is characterized by neutrophilic inflammation and increased lung permeability’

--Meanings--

Neva 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A river in north-western Russia which flows 74 km (46 miles) westwards from Lake Ladoga to the Gulf of Finland, passing through St Petersburg.

--Word--
Nevada 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the western US; population 2,600,167 (est. 2008); capital, Carson City. Acquired from Mexico in 1848, it became the 36th state of the US in 1864.
--Examples--
