nevel 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To beat with the fists; to pound or pummel.
Scottish (now chiefly Orkney and Shetland). To grip or squeeze with the fingers; to knead; (occasionally) to pluck out. Also without object. Compare "nevelling".

--Word--
never 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
At no time in the past or future; not ever.
Not at all.
(expressing surprise) surely not.
--Examples--
‘they had never been camping in their lives’
‘I will never ever forget it’
‘he never turned up’
‘What, you, Annabel? Never!’

--Word--
certain 
--Type--
adjective, pronoun
--Meanings--
Able to be firmly relied on to happen or be the case.
Having or showing complete conviction about something.
Specific but not explicitly named or stated.
Used when mentioning the name of someone not known to the reader or hearer.
Some but not all.
--Examples--
‘it's certain that more changes are in the offing’
‘she looks certain to win an Oscar’
‘are you absolutely certain about this?’
‘he raised certain personal problems with me’
‘the exercise was causing him a certain amount of pain’
‘a certain General Percy captured the town’
‘certain of his works have been edited’

--Word--
constant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Occurring continuously over a period of time.
Remaining the same over a period of time.
(of a person) unchangingly faithful and dependable.
A situation that does not change.
A quantity or parameter that does not change its value whatever the value of the variables, under a given set of conditions.
A number expressing a relation or property which remains the same in all circumstances, or for the same substance under the same conditions.
--Examples--
‘the constant background noise of the city’
‘these discs rotate at a constant speed’
‘a constant friend’
‘the condition of struggle remained a constant’

--Word--
setting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The place or type of surroundings where something is positioned or where an event takes place.
The place and time at which a play, novel, or film is represented as happening.
The scenery and stage furniture used in a play or film.
A piece of metal in which a precious stone or gem is fixed to form a piece of jewellery.
A piece of vocal or choral music composed for particular words.
A speed, height, or temperature at which a machine or device can be adjusted to operate.
--Examples--
‘a romantic house in a wonderful setting beside the River Wye’
‘short stories with a contemporary setting’
‘a garnet in a heavy gold setting’
‘a setting of Yevtushenko's bleak poem’
‘if you find the room getting too hot, check the thermostat setting’

--Word--
silent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not making or accompanied by any sound.
(of a person) not speaking.
Not expressed aloud.
(of a letter) written but not pronounced, e.g. b in doubt.
(of a film) without an accompanying soundtrack.
Saying or recording nothing on a particular subject.
(of a person) not prone to speak much; taciturn.
--Examples--
‘the wood was still and silent’
‘she fell silent for a moment’
‘a silent prayer’
‘a silent ‘h’’
‘she appeared in a number of silent films’
‘the poems are silent on the question of marriage’
‘I'm the strong, silent type’

--Word--
stable 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of an object or structure) not likely to give way or overturn; firmly fixed.
(of a patient or their medical condition) not deteriorating in health after an injury or operation.
Sane and sensible; not easily upset or disturbed.
Not likely to change or fail; firmly established.
Not liable to undergo chemical decomposition, radioactive decay, or other physical change.
A building set apart and adapted for keeping horses.
An establishment where racehorses are kept and trained.
The racehorses of a particular training establishment.
An organization or establishment training or producing a particular type of person or product.
Put or keep (a horse) in a stable.
Put or base (a locomotive or train) in a depot.
--Examples--
‘specially designed dinghies that are very stable’
‘he is now in a stable condition in hospital’
‘the officer concerned is mentally and emotionally stable’
‘a stable relationship’
‘prices have remained relatively stable’
‘isocyanic acid reacts with amino groups to form a stable compound’
‘stable nuclei’
‘the horse was led from its stable’
‘racing stables’
‘the horse make his debut for the Mick Naughton stable’
‘the player comes from the same stable as Agassi’
‘they must be stabled and fed’
‘one of the two locomotives was stabled at Fort William’

‘a vacant stare’

Tyne 
--Type--

Newcomen, Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1663–1729), English engineer, developer of the first practical steam engine. His beam engine to operate a pump for the removal of water from mines was first erected in Worcestershire in 1712.

Newcomer's organ 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

cut 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make an opening, incision, or wound in (something) with a sharp-edged tool or object.
Make a deliberate incision in (one's flesh), as a symptom of psychological or emotional distress.
Remove (something) from something larger by using a sharp implement.
Castrate (an animal, especially a horse).
Make something by cutting.
Remove, exclude, or stop eating or doing something undesirable.
Separate an animal from the main herd.
Divide into pieces with a knife or other sharp implement.
Make divisions in (something)
Separate (something) into two; sever.
Cause something to fall by cutting it through at the base.
(of a weapon, bullet, or disease) kill or injure someone.
Make or form (something) by using a sharp tool to remove material.
Make or design (a garment) in a particular way.
Make (a path, tunnel, or other route) by excavation, digging, or chopping.
Make (a sound recording)
Trim or reduce the length of (grass, hair, etc.) by using a sharp implement.
Reduce the amount or quantity of.
Abridge (a text, film, or performance) by removing material.
Delete (part of a text or other display) so as to insert a copy of it elsewhere.
End or interrupt the provision of (a supply)
Switch off (an engine or a light)
Absent oneself from (something one should normally attend, especially school)
Ignore or refuse to recognize (someone)
(of a line) cross or intersect (another line)
Pass or traverse, especially so as to shorten one's route.
Have an effect regardless of (divisions or boundaries between groups)
Leave or move hurriedly.
Stop filming or recording.
Move to another shot in a film.
Make (a film) into a coherent whole by removing parts or placing them in a different order.
Divide a pack of playing cards by lifting a portion from the top, either to reveal a card at random or to place the top portion under the bottom portion.
Strike or kick (a ball) with an abrupt, typically downward motion.
Slice (the ball).
Hit (the ball) to the off side with the bat held almost horizontally; play such a stroke against (the bowler).
(of the ball) turn sharply on pitching.
Mix (an illegal drug) with another substance.
Come up to expectations; meet requirements.
A stroke or blow given by a sharp-edged implement or by a whip or cane.
A haircut.
A reduction in amount or size.
A power cut.
An act of cutting part of a book, play, etc.
An immediate transition from one scene to another in a film.
The halfway point of a golf tournament, where half of the players are eliminated.
A stroke made with an abrupt, typically horizontal or downward action.
A long, narrow incision in the skin made by something sharp.
A long, narrow opening or incision made in a surface or piece of material.
A piece of meat cut from a carcass.
A share of the profits from something.
A recording of a piece of music.
A version of a film after editing.
A passage cut or dug out, as a railway cutting or a new channel made for a river or other waterway.
A wounding remark or act.
The way or style in which something, especially a garment or someone's hair, is cut.

Newfoundland 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A large island off the east coast of Canada, at the mouth of the St Lawrence River. In 1949 it was united with Labrador (as Newfoundland and Labrador) to form a province of Canada.

--Word--
front 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The side or part of an object that presents itself to view or that is normally seen or used first; the most forward part of something.
The position directly ahead of someone or something; the most forward position or place.
The forward-facing part of a person's body, on the opposite side to their back.
The part of a garment covering a person's front.
A woman's bust or cleavage.
Any face of a building, especially that of the main entrance.
The foremost line or part of an armed force; the furthest position that an army has reached and where the enemy is or may be engaged.
The direction towards which a line of troops faces when formed.
A particular formation of troops for battle.
A particular situation or sphere of operation.
An organized political group.
The forward edge of an advancing mass of air.
An appearance or form of behaviour assumed by a person to conceal their genuine feelings.
A person or organization serving as a cover for subversive or illegal activities.
Boldness and confidence of manner.
A person's face or forehead.
Of or at the front.
(of a vowel sound) formed by raising the tongue, excluding the blade and tip, towards the hard palate.
(of a building or piece of land) have the front facing or directed towards.
Be or stand in front of.
Provide (something) with a front or facing of a particular type or material.
Lead or be the most prominent member in (an organization, group, or activity)
Present or host (a television or radio programme)
Act as a front or cover for illegal or secret activity.
Adopt a particular expression or form of behaviour to conceal one's genuine feelings.
Make an appearance; turn up.
Stand face to face with; confront.
Articulate (a vowel sound) with the tongue further forward.
Place (a sentence element) at the beginning of a sentence instead of in its usual position, typically for emphasis or as a feature of some dialects, as in horrible it was.
--Examples--
‘a page at the front of the book had been torn out’
‘he sealed the envelope and wrote on the front’
‘she quickly turned her head to face the front’
‘she rolled over on to her front’
‘porridge slopped from the tray on to his shirt front’
‘get your eyes off my front, meathead’
‘the west front of the Cathedral’
‘his regiment was immediately sent to the front’
‘the Spartans preserving an even and unbroken front’
‘there was some good news on the jobs front’
‘the National Progressive Patriotic Front’
‘she put on a brave front’
‘the CIA identified the company as a front for a terrorist group’
‘he's got a bit of talent and a lot of front’
‘the mark of fool set on his front’
‘the front cover of the magazine’
‘she was in the front garden’
‘the flats which fronted Crow Road’
‘both properties fronted on to the beach’
‘they reached the hedge fronting the garden’
‘a metal box fronted by an alloy panel’
‘a glass-fronted bookcase’
‘the group is fronted by two girl singers’
‘she is set to front a new BBC show’
‘he fronted for them in illegal property deals’
‘I can't front, I never really listened to much of his music’
‘parents get a bit worried if you don't front up now and then’
‘Tom fronted him with unwavering eyes’
‘the three velar consonants are normally fronted to some degree’
‘the fronting of /au/ was completed a couple of generations ago’

Newgate 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former London prison whose unsanitary conditions became notorious in the 18th century before the building was burnt down in the Gordon Riots of 1780. A new edifice was erected on the same spot but was demolished in 1902 to make way for the Central Criminal Court.

Newhouse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Samuel Irving, Sr. (1895–1979), US publisher; born Solomon Neuhaus. He founded Advance Publications, now the largest privately held media company, the holdings of which are controlled by his sons, Si (born 1927; full name Samuel Irving Newhouse, Jr. ) and Donald E. (born 1930).

--Word--
new light 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person holding novel religious doctrines; a revivalist; specifically a member of any of several churches, denominations, etc., arising from schism within various Protestant churches in Scotland and North America during the 18th and 19th centuries; (also, chiefly in plural) any of the groups to which these members belonged. Now historical.
United States regional. In form New Light. The white crappie, Pomoxis annularis (family Centrarchidae), a common freshwater fish of North America.
Frequently in form New Light. Of, relating to, or holding the views of, the New Lights. Now historical.

newton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The SI unit of force. It is equal to the force that would give a mass of one kilogram an acceleration of one metre per second per second, and is equivalent to 100,000 dynes.

--Meanings--
Relating to or arising from the work of Sir Isaac Newton.
Formulated or behaving according to the principles of classical physics.
--Examples--
--Word--
Newtonianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Newtonian system of physics; (in extended use) a philosophical approach based on that of Newton, or formed by analogy with his system of physics, typically emphasizing the role of laws and predictable order in the universe, and of experiment and observation in the discovery of truth.
--Examples--
--Word--
Newtonically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of Sir Isaac Newton; with regard to Newton's theories.
--Examples--
--Word--
Newtonist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Newtonian.
--Examples--
--Word--
newtonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= alunite.
--Examples--
--Word--
newton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The SI unit of force. It is equal to the force that would give a mass of one kilogram an acceleration of one metre per second per second, and is equivalent to 100,000 dynes.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
next 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, preposition, determiner
--Meanings--
(of a time) coming immediately after the time of writing or speaking.
(of a day of the week) nearest (or the nearest but one) after the present.
(of an event) occurring directly after the present one in time, without anything of the same kind intervening.
Coming immediately after the present one in order, rank, or space.
On the first or soonest occasion after the present; immediately afterwards.
Following in the specified order.
The next person or thing.
Next to.
Another.
--Examples--
‘we'll go to Corfu next year’
‘next week's Cup Final’
‘not this Wednesday, next Wednesday’
‘on Monday next’
‘campaigning for the next election’
‘next time I'll bring a hat’
‘the woman in the next room’
‘the next chapter’
‘building materials were next in importance’
‘he wondered what would happen next’
‘next, I heard the sound of voices’
‘Jo was the next oldest after Martin’
‘the week after next’
‘he plodded along next him’
‘every year sales down by a next ten per cent again’
--Word--
beside 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
At the side of; next to.
Compared with.
In addition to; apart from.
--Examples--
‘he sat beside me in the front seat’
‘the table beside the bed’
‘beside Paula she always felt clumsy’
‘he commissioned work from other artists beside Minton’
--Word--
next door 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In or to the next house or room.
Living or situated next door.
The people, building, or room next door.
--Examples--
‘the caretaker lives next door’
‘next-door neighbours’
‘next door's dog’
‘a man emerged from next door’

Giap, Vo Nguyen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–2013), Vietnamese military and political leader. As North Vietnamese vice-premier and defense minister, he was responsible for the strategy leading to the withdrawal of US forces from South Vietnam in 1973 and the subsequent reunification of the country in 1976.

--Word--
nibble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take small bites out of.
Eat frequently in small amounts.
Gently bite at (a part of the body), especially amorously or nervously.
Gradually erode or diminish.
Show cautious interest in a commercial opportunity.
An act or instance of nibbling.
A small piece of food bitten off.
Small savoury snacks, typically eaten before a meal or with drinks.
A show of interest in a commercial opportunity.
--Examples--
‘he nibbled a biscuit’
‘she nibbled at her food’
‘I put on weight because I was constantly nibbling’
‘Sebastian was nibbling Gloria's ear’
‘inflation was nibbling away at spending power’
‘there's an American agent nibbling’
‘I'm distracted by a nibble on my line’
‘I took a nibble from one of the sandwiches’
‘cheesy nibbles’
‘I had been trying to unload my apartment for weeks without even a nibble’

--Word--
Nibelung 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Germanic mythology) a member of a Scandinavian race of dwarfs, owners of a hoard of gold and magic treasures, who were ruled by Nibelung, king of Nibelheim (land of mist).
(in the Nibelungenlied) a supporter of Siegfried, or one of the Burgundians who stole the hoard from him.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nibelungenlied 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A 13th-century German poem, embodying a story found in the (Poetic) Edda, telling of the life and death of Siegfried, a prince of the Netherlands. There have been many adaptations of the story, including Wagner's epic music drama Der Ring des Nibelungen (1847–74).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nibelung 
--Type--

--Meanings--

(in the Nibelungenlied) a supporter of Siegfried, or one of the Burgundians who stole the hoard from him.

--Word--
NiCad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A battery or cell with a nickel anode, a cadmium cathode, and a potassium hydroxide electrolyte. NiCads are used chiefly as a rechargeable power source for portable equipment.
--Examples--
‘NiCad batteries’
--Word--
Nicaea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city in Asia Minor, on the site of modern Iznik, which was important in Roman and Byzantine times. It was the site of two ecumenical councils of the early Christian Church (in 325 and 787).
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

‘the Nicaeans secured the city’

Nicaragua

The largest country in Central America, with a coastline on both the Atlantic and the Pacific Ocean; population 6,100,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Spanish; capital, Managua.

niccolite 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Paganini, Niccolò 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1782–1840), Italian violinist and composer. His virtuoso violin recitals, including widespread use of pizzicato and harmonics, established him as a major figure of the romantic movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
nice 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Giving pleasure or satisfaction; pleasant or attractive.
(of a person) good-natured; kind.
Not good; unpleasant.
(especially of a difference) slight or subtle.
Requiring careful consideration.
Fastidious; scrupulous.
--Examples--
‘we had a very nice time’
‘he's a nicer man than Mark’
‘Joe had been very nice to her’
‘that's a nice way to come into my kitchen—no greeting!’
‘there is a nice distinction between self-sacrifice and martyrdom’
‘a nice point’

--Word--
nicety 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine or subtle detail or distinction.
Accuracy or precision.
A detail or aspect of polite social behaviour.
--Examples--
‘legal niceties are wasted on him’
‘she prided herself on her nicety of pronunciation’
‘we were brought up to observe the niceties’
--Word--
nicety 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine or subtle detail or distinction.
Accuracy or precision.
A detail or aspect of polite social behaviour.
--Examples--
‘legal niceties are wasted on him’
‘she prided herself on her nicety of pronunciation’
‘we were brought up to observe the niceties’
--Word--
niche 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A shallow recess, especially one in a wall to display a statue or other ornament.
A comfortable or suitable position in life or employment.
A role taken by a type of organism within its community.
A specialized segment of the market for a particular kind of product or service.
Denoting or relating to products, services, or interests that appeal to a small, specialized section of the population.
Place (something) in a niche.
--Examples--
‘each niche holding a shepherdess in Dresden china’
‘he is now head chef at a leading law firm and feels he has found his niche’
‘the niche left vacant by the disappearance of wolves’
‘he believes he has found a niche in the market’
‘smaller cooperatives must find and develop a niche for their speciality product’
‘other companies in this space had to adapt to being niche players’
‘a niche show that ran on late-night television’
‘the video game industry is no longer niche’
‘these elements were niched within the shadowy reaches’
‘niched statues’

verb, noun

‘the beast gave a low nicher of welcome’

--Word--
nitchevo 
--Type--
exclamation, noun
--Meanings--
In representations or imitation of Russian speech: ‘it is nothing’, ‘never mind’, ‘no matter’.
The attitude of resignation or fatalism conveyed by (habitual) use of the word ‘nitchevo’; the tendency to accept defeat or to do nothing.
--Examples--

--Word--
Nichols, Mike 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1931–2014), US director; born in Germany; born Michael Igor Peschowsky. He directed Barefoot in the Park (1963), The Odd Couple (1965), and Annie (1977) on Broadway. Movies he directed include Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (1966), The Graduate (1967), The Birdcage (1996), and Charlie Wilson's War (2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicholas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of two tsars of Russia.
Nicholas I (1796–1855), brother of Alexander I, reigned 1825–55. At home he pursued rigidly conservative policies, while his expansionism in the Near East led to the Crimean War.
Nicholas II (1868–1918), son of Alexander III, reigned 1894–1917. Forced to abdicate after the Russian Revolution in 1917, he was shot along with his family a year later.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicholas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of two tsars of Russia.
Nicholas I (1796–1855), brother of Alexander I, reigned 1825–55. At home he pursued rigidly conservative policies, while his expansionism in the Near East led to the Crimean War.
Nicholas II (1868–1918), son of Alexander III, reigned 1894–1917. Forced to abdicate after the Russian Revolution in 1917, he was shot along with his family a year later.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nichols, Mike 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1931–2014), US director; born in Germany; born Michael Igor Peschowsky. He directed Barefoot in the Park (1963), The Odd Couple (1965), and Annie (1977) on Broadway. Movies he directed include Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (1966), The Graduate (1967), The Birdcage (1996), and Charlie Wilson's War (2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicholson, Jack 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1937), US actor. He won Oscars for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) and Terms of Endearment (1983). Other films include The Shining (1980) and Batman (1989).
--Examples--
--Word--
nichrome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alloy of nickel with chromium (10 to 20 per cent) and sometimes iron (up to 25 per cent), used chiefly in high-temperature applications such as electrical heating elements.
--Examples--
‘Nichrome wire’
--Word--
nicht wahr 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In interrogative contexts (especially amongst German-speakers): ‘Is it not true?’; ‘Isn't that so?’ Compare n'est-ce pas.
--Examples--
--Word--
nycthemeral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or characterized by a variation that occurs in a period of twenty-four hours, especially corresponding to the contrast between day and night.
--Examples--
--Word--
nycthemeron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of twenty-four hours, consisting of a day and a night.

--Word--
nick 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small cut or notch.
Prison.
A police station.
The junction between the floor and side walls in a squash court or real tennis court.
Make a nick or nicks in.
Steal.
Cheat someone of (a sum of money)
Arrest (someone)
--Examples--
‘a small nick on his wrist’
‘he'll end up in the nick for the rest of his life’
‘he was being fingerprinted in the nick’
‘he had nicked himself while shaving’
‘she nicked fivers from the till’
‘banks will be nicked for an extra $40 million’
‘Stuart and Dan got nicked for burglary’

--Meanings--

--Word--
nickeline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mineralogy= niccolite.
Engineering. Any of various nickel alloys or varieties of nickel silver; specifically an alloy of copper, nickel, and zinc noted for its high electrical resistivity and low thermal expansion coefficient. Also: a tin alloy containing antimony and copper.

Nicklaus, Jack William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1940), US golfer. He won more than eighty tournaments during his professional career, including the Masters (1963, 1965, 1966, 1972, 1975, 1986), the PGA (1963, 1971, 1973, 1975, 1980), the US Open (1962, 1967, 1972, 1980), and the British Open (1966, 1970, 1978).

--Word--
Andaman and Nicobar Islands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Two groups of islands in the Bay of Bengal, constituting a Union Territory in India; population 423,700 (est. 2009); capital, Port Blair.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicobarese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the Nicobar Islands.
An ancient language spoken in the Nicobar Islands, distantly related to the Mon-Khmer and Munda families. It now has fewer than 20,000 speakers.
Relating to the Nicobar Islands, their inhabitants, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicodemite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who resembles Nicodemus; a secret or timid adherent; specifically a Protestant living in a Catholic country in the 16th cent. who concealed his or her faith to escape persecution.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicol prism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for producing plane-polarized light, consisting of two pieces of optically clear calcite or Iceland spar cemented together with Canada balsam in the shape of a prism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Sacco, Nicola 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1891–1927), US political radical; born in Italy. In 1921, along with Bartolomeo Vanzetti, he was accused and convicted of murder in a sensational trial. In 1927, both men were executed in the electric chair, in a still controversial outcome.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicolaitan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an early Christian or Gnostic sect, believed to have allowed its members to participate in pagan ceremonies. Also generally: a married priest, an opponent of clerical celibacy.
Of or relating to the Nicolaitans or their views; paganistic, libertine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicolaitanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The beliefs and practices of the Nicolaitan sect; libertinism; an instance of this. Later: specifically the practice of clerical marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
Sarkozy, Nicolas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1955), French statesman, president 2007–2012.
--Examples--
--Word--
Steno, Nicolaus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1638–86), Danish anatomist and geologist; Danish name Niels Steensen. His ideas on the geological history of the earth are now regarded as fundamental—that fossils are the petrified remains of living organisms, that many rocks arise from consolidation of sediments, and that such rocks occur in layers in the order in which they were laid down.
--Examples--
--Word--
Steno, Nicolaus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1638–86), Danish anatomist and geologist; Danish name Niels Steensen. His ideas on the geological history of the earth are now regarded as fundamental—that fossils are the petrified remains of living organisms, that many rocks arise from consolidation of sediments, and that such rocks occur in layers in the order in which they were laid down.
--Examples--
--Word--
Kidman, Nicole 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1967), Australian actress; born in Hawaii. Notable movies: Eyes Wide Shut (1999), Moulin Rouge! (2001), The Hours (2002), Cold Mountain (2003), and The Golden Compass (2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nicollet, Joseph Nicolas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1786–1843), US explorer; born in France. With John Frémont as his assistant, he led a government surveying expedition that mapped the region between the upper Mississippi and Missouri rivers 1838–39.
--Examples--

The capital of Cyprus; population 233,000 (est. 2007). Since 1974 it has been divided into Greek and Turkish sectors.

nicotiana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
nicotic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Malic acid, as obtained from the tobacco plant, Nicotiana tabacum, where it occurs in combination with nicotine; (occasionally also, by confusion) nicotinic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
nicotinamide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound which is the form in which nicotinic acid often occurs in nature.
--Examples--
--Word--
nicotine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A toxic colourless or yellowish oily liquid which is the chief active constituent of tobacco. It acts as a stimulant in small doses, but in larger amounts blocks the action of autonomic nerve and skeletal muscle cells.
--Examples--
--Word--
nicotinean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= nicotian.
--Examples--
--Word--
nicotined 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suffused with or affected by nicotine or tobacco smoke; stained with nicotine.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

nycteribiid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the family Nycteribiidae of wingless dipteran flies which are parasites of bats and bear live young.
A fly of the family Nycteribiidae; a bat fly.
--Examples--

noun

A genus comprising the typical night herons. Also formerly (in form nycticorax): a bird of this genus.

adjective
--Meanings--
Adapted for winking or blinking; nictitating. Also (occasionally): giving the appearance of winking or blinking.
--Examples--
--Word--
nictate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Blink.
--Examples--
‘the lid of her left eye began to nictate’

nictitation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

niddy-noddy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An idiot, a fool; a grotesque image. Also as adjective: stupid. English regional in later use.
A hand-held device used to skein and measure yarn, consisting of a vertical central bar with shorter horizontal bars at either end offset at right angles to one another, round which yarn is wound in a figure-of-eight movement; a hand reel.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1892–1971), US theologian and political activist. Professor of Christian ethics at Union Theological Seminary 1928–60, he wrote Moral Man and Immoral Society (1932) and The Irony of American History (1952).

--Word--
Bohr, Niels 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1885–1962), Danish physicist and pioneer in quantum physics; full name Niels Hendrik David Bohr. Bohr's theory of the structure of the atom incorporated quantum theory for the first time, and is the basis for present-day quantum-mechanical models. Bohr helped to develop the atom bomb in Britain and then in the US. Nobel Prize for Physics (1922). His son, Aage Niels Bohr (1922–2009), shared the 1975 prize for his studies of the physics of the atomic nucleus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nielsen, Carl August 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1865–1931), Danish composer. He is best known for his six symphonies (1890–1925).
--Examples--
--Word--
Nyerere, Julius Kambarage 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–99), Tanzanian statesman, president of Tanganyika 1962–4 and of Tanzania 1964–85. He led Tanganyika to independence in 1961 and in 1964 successfully negotiated a union with Zanzibar, creating the new state of Tanzania.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
Niger 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in north-western Africa, which rises on the north-eastern border of Sierra Leone and flows in a great arc for 4,100 km (2,550 miles) north-east to Mali, then south-east through western Niger and Nigeria, before turning southwards into the Gulf of Guinea.
A landlocked country in West Africa, on the southern edge of the Sahara; population 19,900,000 (estimated 2015): languages, French (official), Hausa, and other West African languages: capital, Niamey. Part of French West Africa from 1922, Niger became an autonomous republic within the French Community in 1958 and fully independent in 1960.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nigeria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country on the coast of West Africa; population 182,200,000 (estimated 2015); languages, English (official), Hausa, Igbo, Yoruba, and others; capital, Abuja.
--Examples--
--Word--

niggle 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cause slight but persistent annoyance, discomfort, or anxiety.
Criticize or annoy (someone) in a petty way.
A trivial criticism, discomfort, or annoyance.
--Examples--
‘Doreen wanted to discuss matters that niggled at her mind’
‘people niggling me for doing too much work’
‘it is an excellent book except for my few niggles’
‘he can only throw underarm at the moment because of a niggle’

--Word--
night 
--Type--
noun, exclamation, adverb
--Meanings--
The period from sunset to sunrise in each twenty-four hours.
The night as the interval between two days.
The darkness of night.
Nightfall.
The period between afternoon and bedtime; an evening.
An evening characterized by a particular event or activity.
During the night; at night.
--Examples--
‘a moonless night’
‘the door is always locked at night’
‘supplements per person per night’
‘a line of watchfires stretched away into the night’
‘he was not allowed to go out on weekday nights’
‘a quiz night’
‘wasn't it a great night out?’
‘investments that won't keep us awake nights with worry’
--Word--
nightbird

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
night 
--Type--
noun, exclamation, adverb
--Meanings--
The period from sunset to sunrise in each twenty-four hours.
The night as the interval between two days.
The darkness of night.
Nightfall.
The period between afternoon and bedtime; an evening.
An evening characterized by a particular event or activity.
During the night; at night.

‘supplements per person per night’
‘a line of watchfires stretched away into the night’
‘he was not allowed to go out on weekday nights’

Perfectly suited or trained to do a particular job.
(of an organization, movement, or idea) brought into existence.
Existing as a result of (a particular situation or feeling)
--Examples--
‘she was born in Aberdeen’
‘I was born with a sense of curiosity’
‘a newly born baby’
‘a German-born philosopher’
‘he's a born engineer’
‘men born to rule’
‘on 1 January 1992, the new company was born’
‘his work is born of despair’
--Word--
night 
--Type--
noun, exclamation, adverb
--Meanings--
The period from sunset to sunrise in each twenty-four hours.
The night as the interval between two days.
The darkness of night.
Nightfall.
The period between afternoon and bedtime; an evening.
An evening characterized by a particular event or activity.
During the night; at night.
--Examples--
‘a moonless night’
‘the door is always locked at night’
‘supplements per person per night’
‘a line of watchfires stretched away into the night’
‘he was not allowed to go out on weekday nights’
‘a quiz night’
‘wasn't it a great night out?’
‘investments that won't keep us awake nights with worry’
--Word--
nightcap

noun
--Meanings--
A cap worn in bed.
A hot or alcoholic drink taken before bedtime.
The second game of a double-header.
--Examples--
‘he pitched a four-hit shutout in the nightcap’

--Word--
nightman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A man employed to empty cesspools, outdoor privies, etc., at night and to remove the waste matter. Also figurative. Now archaic and historical.
A man who works during the night or on a night shift. Also (slang): a nocturnal wrongdoer or criminal; a burglar.
--Examples--
--Word--
mantled howler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(More fully "mantled howler monkey") a tropical American howler monkey, Alouatta palliata, which is mainly black with long yellowish or brownish fur on the sides of the body.
--Examples--

--Word--
swift 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Happening quickly or promptly.
Moving or capable of moving at high speed.
Swiftly.
A swift-flying insectivorous bird with long, slender wings and a superficial resemblance to a swallow, spending most of its life on the wing.
A moth, typically yellow-brown in colour, with fast darting flight. The eggs are scattered in flight and the larvae live underground feeding on roots, where they can be a serious pest.
A light, adjustable reel for holding a skein of silk or wool.
--Examples--
‘a remarkably swift recovery’
‘the water was very swift’
‘the swiftest horse in his stable’
‘streams that ran swift and clear’
‘a swift-moving narrative’

noun
--Meanings--
The time between evening and morning; the time of darkness.
--Examples--
‘they asked police for extra night-time patrols’
--Word--

--Examples--
--Word--
round-tripping 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of making a round trip.
Finance. The practice of earning profit by borrowing on overdraft and relending in the money markets; (later also) the practice of investing capital abroad and then reinvesting it in its country of origin, in order to take advantage of favourable tax rates, etc., given to foreign investors.
--Examples--
--Word--
night 
--Type--
noun, exclamation, adverb
--Meanings--
The period from sunset to sunrise in each twenty-four hours.
The night as the interval between two days.
The darkness of night.
Nightfall.
The period between afternoon and bedtime; an evening.
An evening characterized by a particular event or activity.
During the night; at night.
--Examples--
‘a moonless night’
‘the door is always locked at night’
‘supplements per person per night’
‘a line of watchfires stretched away into the night’
‘he was not allowed to go out on weekday nights’
‘a quiz night’
‘wasn't it a great night out?’
‘investments that won't keep us awake nights with worry’
--Word--
night-wake 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of staying awake, or maintaining a watch, during the night; a nocturnal vigil.
--Examples--
--Word--
night-walk 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To walk or travel across (a place) at night. Also in extended use.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
warble 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
(of a bird) sing softly and with a succession of constantly changing notes.
(of a person) sing in a trilling or quavering voice.
A warbling sound or utterance.
A swelling or abscess beneath the skin on the back of cattle, horses, and other mammals, caused by the presence of the larva of a warble fly.
The larva of the warble fly.
--Examples--
‘larks were warbling in the trees’
‘he warbled in an implausible soprano’
‘through the wall came a faint warble’
‘the warble of the phone’
--Word--
nightward 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
Towards night.
Formerly: †coming, taking place, etc., towards nightfall (obsolete). Now: in the direction of or leading towards the night; westward.
--Examples--
--Word--
nightwards 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Towards the region of night; westwards.
--Examples--
--Word--
night watch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period at night during which a person or group of people is stationed to look out for danger or trouble.
A person or group of people stationed to look out for danger or trouble at night.
--Examples--
‘a fight broke out during the lieutenant's night watch’
‘he was the supervisor of a three-man night watch’

noun

--Word--
nihilism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rejection of all religious and moral principles, in the belief that life is meaningless.
The belief that nothing in the world has a real existence.
The doctrine of an extreme Russian revolutionary party c.1900 which found nothing to approve of in the established social order.
--Examples--

Nijinsky, Vaslav 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1890–1950), Russian ballet dancer and choreographer; full name Vaslav Fomich Nijinsky. The leading dancer with Diaghilev's Ballets Russes from 1909, he went on to choreograph Debussy's L'Après-midi d'un faune (1912) and Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring (1913).
--Examples--

nikethamide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A derivative of nicotinic acid used as a respiratory stimulant and analeptic; nicotinic acid diethylamide, (C₅H₄N)CON(CH₂CH₃)₂. [A trademark for this drug is Coramine.]
--Examples--
--Word--
Lauda, Niki 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1949), Austrian motor-racing driver; full name Nikolaus Andreas Lauda. World champion in 1975, he suffered severe injuries in the 1976 German Grand Prix, but won two more championships (1977 and 1984). He retired in 1985.
--Examples--
--Word--
Khrushchev, Nikita 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1894–1971), Soviet statesman, premier of the USSR 1958–64; full name Nikita Sergeevich Khrushchev. He was First Secretary of the Communist Party of the USSR 1953–64 after the death of Stalin, whom he denounced in 1956. He came close to war with the US over the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962 and also clashed with China, which led to his being ousted by Brezhnev and Kosygin.
--Examples--
--Word--
Tesla, Nikola 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1856–1943), American electrical engineer and inventor, born in what is now Croatia of Serbian descent. He developed the first alternating-current induction motor, as well as several forms of oscillators, the Tesla coil, and a wireless guidance system for ships.
--Examples--
--Word--
Vavilov, Nikolai 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–c.1943), Soviet plant geneticist; full name Nikolai Ivanovich Vavilov. He amassed a considerable collection of new plants, utilizing their genetic resources for crop improvement.
--Examples--

Tesla, Nikola

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1856–1943), American electrical engineer and inventor, born in what is now Croatia of Serbian descent. He developed the first alternating-current induction motor, as well as several forms of oscillators, the Tesla coil, and a wireless guidance system for ships.

Otto, Nikolaus August 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1832–91), German engineer, whose name is given to the four-stroke cycle on which most internal combustion engines work.

nilas

--Meanings--

--Word--
Nile 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in eastern Africa, the longest river in the world, which rises in east central Africa near Lake Victoria and flows 6,695 km (4,160 miles) generally northwards through Uganda, South Sudan, Sudan, and Egypt to empty through a large delta into the Mediterranean.
--Examples--

nylon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tough, lightweight, elastic synthetic polymer with a protein-like chemical structure, able to be produced as filaments, sheets, or moulded objects.
Fabric or yarn made from nylon fibres.
Stockings or tights made of nylon.
--Examples--
‘the tent is made of blue nylon’
‘nylon carpet’
‘a pair of nylons’
--Word--
Nilo-Saharan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting or belonging to a phylum of languages that includes the Nilotic family together with certain other languages of northern and eastern Africa.
The Nilo-Saharan phylum of languages.
--Examples--

--Word--
Nilotic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the River Nile or to the Nile region of Africa.
Denoting or belonging to a family of languages spoken in Egypt, Sudan, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania. The western group includes Luo and Dinka; the eastern group includes Masai and Turkana.

Nilsson, Birgit

proper noun
--Meanings--

noun

Nimby 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who objects to the siting of something perceived as unpleasant or hazardous in their own neighbourhood, especially while raising no such objections to similar developments elsewhere.

‘rural development arouses intense suspicion from Nimbys and conservationists’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being more than is necessary or desirable; excess.
--Examples--
‘Coleridge criticized Schiller for what he called the nimiety of his blank verse’

--Word--
Nimitz, Chester William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1885–1966), US naval officer. Chief of the Bureau of Navigation (1939–41), he became commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. A noted strategist, he introduced the practice of island hopping, which contributed to many victories. Nimitz accepted the Japanese surrender for the US in 1945 aboard his flagship, the USS Missouri, and after World War II served as chief of naval operations 1945–47.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nimpkish 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people of the Kwakiutl group inhabiting northern Vancouver Island.
Of or relating to the Nimpkish.
--Examples--
--Word--
nymph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mythological spirit of nature imagined as a beautiful maiden inhabiting rivers, woods, or other locations.
A beautiful young woman.
An immature form of an insect that does not change greatly as it grows, e.g. a dragonfly, mayfly, or locust.
An artificial fishing fly made to resemble the aquatic nymph of an insect.
A mainly brown butterfly that frequents woods and forest glades.
--Examples--
‘the idyllic world of nymphs and shepherds’
‘a wood nymph’
--Word--
nympha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology= "nymph".
Anatomy. A labium minus. Now rare.
Conchology. Either of a pair of prominences on either side of the hinge of certain bivalve shells to which the ends of the external ligament are attached. Usually in plural.

nymphalid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
nymphing 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Feeding by fish on insect larvae at the surface of the water. rare.
Angling. The action or practice of angling with a nymph as a fly; nymph fishing.
Of a fish, especially a trout: that is feeding on insect larvae at the surface of the water.
Angling. Of or relating to the practice of angling with a nymph as a fly.

--Word--
Nimrud 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Modern name of an ancient Mesopotamian city on the east bank of the Tigris south of Nineveh, near the modern city of Mosul. It was the capital of Assyria 879–722 BC. The city was known in biblical times as Calah (Gen. 10:11); the modern name arose through association in Islamic mythology with the biblical figure of Nimrod.
--Examples--
--Word--
nim 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A game in which two players alternately take one or more objects from one of a number of heaps, each trying to take, or to compel the other to take, the last remaining object.
--Examples--
--Word--
La Niña 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cooling of the water in the equatorial Pacific, which occurs at irregular intervals, and is associated with widespread changes in weather patterns complementary to those of El Niño, but less extensive and damaging in their effects.
--Examples--

--Word--
nine-banded armadillo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The common long-nosed armadillo, Dasypus novemcinctus, of northern South America, Central America, and the southern U.S., with body armour that forms nine or (commonly) eight bands across the middle; also called peba.
--Examples--
--Word--
nine-point circle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A circle passing through the mid-points of the three sides of a triangle, the feet of its three altitudes, and the mid-points of the segments of the altitudes from the vertices to their point of intersection.

--Word--
nine holes 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various games of skill involving nine target holes, spots, etc.; specifically (a) a game in which players try to roll small balls into nine holes made in the ground, each hole having a separate scoring value; (b) a similar game played with a wooden bridge or board having nine holes or arches.
British regional. A lamprey.
--Examples--

--Word--
inch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A unit of linear measure equal to one twelfth of a foot (2.54 cm)
A person's height or waist measurement.
A very small amount or distance.
(as a unit of rainfall) a quantity that would cover a horizontal surface to a depth of one inch, equivalent to 253.7 cubic metres per hectare.
(as a unit of atmospheric pressure) an amount that would support a column of mercury one-inch high in a barometer (equal to 33.86 millibars, 29.5 inches being equal to one bar).
(as a unit of map scale) so many inches representing one mile on the ground.
Move along slowly and carefully.
Cause (something) to move slowly and carefully.
--Examples--
‘the toy train is four inches long’
‘eighteen inches of thread’
‘my only reservation is the goalkeeper's lack of inches’
‘I had no intention of budging an inch’
‘more than four inches of rain is expected’
‘one-inch maps of the east Midland counties’
‘he inched away as I approached’
‘Spain's conservatives are inching ahead’
‘he inched the car forward’

jointed

--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
ninepence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The sum or value of nine pence, especially in British currency before decimalization.
"as neat (also nice, right,etc.) as ninepence": (of an action) neat or brisk; (of a person or thing): tidy, healthy, well-ordered.
British informal"ninepence in (also to) the shilling": below average, especially in intelligence; mentally slow. Also as noun: a person of low intelligence.
--Examples--
--Word--
ninepence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

ninepenny 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Valued at or costing ninepence.
Designating alternative names for the game of nine men's morris, as "ninepenny marl", "ninepenny miracle", "ninepenny morris".
Something costing or worth ninepence. rare.

--Word--
ply 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thickness or layer of a folded or laminated material.
A strand of yarn or rope.
The number of multiple layers or strands of which something is made.
A reinforcing layer of fabric in a tyre.
(in game theory) the number of levels at which branching occurs in a tree of possible outcomes, typically corresponding to the number of moves ahead (in chess strictly half-moves ahead) considered by a computer program.
A half-move (i.e. one player's move) in computer chess.
Work steadily with (a tool)
Work steadily at (one's business or trade)
(of a vessel or vehicle) travel regularly over a route, typically for commercial purposes.
Regularly travel over (a route)
Provide someone with (food or drink) in a continuous or insistent way.
Direct (numerous questions) at someone.
--Examples--
‘tiles that have a black PVC ply in the lamination’
‘four-ply yarn’
‘the yarn can be any ply from two to eight’
‘a six-ply whitewall tire’
‘a tailor delicately plying his needle’
‘for three years he plied a profitable export trade between England and Australia’
‘ferries ply across a strait to the island’
‘the fleet has plied the Bristol Channel since Victorian times’
‘she plied me with tea and scones’
‘she plied him with questions about his visit’

--Word--
share 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A part or portion of a larger amount which is divided among a number of people, or to which a number of people contribute.
Each of the notional parts into which property held by joint owners is divided.
The allotted or due amount of something that a person expects to have or to do, or that is expected to be accepted or done by them.
A person's part in or contribution to something.
One of the equal parts into which a company's capital is divided, entitling the holder to a proportion of the profits.
An instance of posting or reposting something on a social media website or application.
Have a portion of (something) with another or others.
Give a portion of (something) to another or others.
Use, occupy, or enjoy (something) jointly with another or others.
Possess (a view or quality) in common with others.
(of a number of people or organizations) have a part in (something, especially an activity)
Tell someone about (something, especially something personal)
Post or repost (something) on a social media website or application.
--Examples--
‘under the proposals, investors would pay a greater share of the annual fees required’
‘we gave them all the chance to have a share in the profits’
‘Jake had a share in a large, seagoing vessel’
‘she's done more than her fair share of globetrotting’
‘she can't take a share in childcare—she's a nervous wreck’
‘he's selling his shares in BT’
‘there have been 25,000 shares on Twitter and 117 likes on Facebook as of 7:30 p.m.’
‘he shared the pie with her’
‘all members of the band equally share the band's profits’
‘they shared out the peanuts’
‘they once shared a flat in Chelsea’
‘there weren't enough plates so we had to share’
‘other countries don't share our reluctance to eat goat meat’
‘UK companies would share in the development of three oil platforms’
‘she had never shared the secret with anyone before’
‘the app lets you share your photos on Facebook, Twitter, and Tumblr’
--Word--
shilling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former British coin and monetary unit equal to one twentieth of a pound or twelve pence.
The basic monetary unit in Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda, equal to 100 cents.

--Word--
nine tenths 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Nearly all.
--Examples--
‘nine tenths of his life consisted of doing things he disliked’
--Word--
ninety 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
Equivalent to the product of nine and ten; ten less than one hundred; 90.
The numbers from 90 to 99, especially the years of a century or of a person's life.
Ninety years old.
Ninety miles an hour.
--Examples--
‘a cheque for ninety pounds’
‘art in the nineties’
‘she is nearly ninety’
‘we passed the junction doing about ninety’
--Word--

--Word--
ninety-day 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a promissory note or bill of exchange, under the terms of which payment is to be made ninety days from the time of writing.
Generally. Of, lasting, or valid for ninety days; given ninety days in advance.
South African. Also in form 90-day (occasionally 90 day). Designating or relating to the General Law Amendment Act of 1963, or more particularly Section 17 of this Act, which stipulates that a police officer may detain a person in relation to certain political offences for up to ninety days without access to a court of law.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
eighth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number eight in a sequence; 8th.
The eighth finisher or position in a race or competition.
Each of eight equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
--Examples--
‘in the eighth century’
‘the eighth of September’
‘seven men admitted conspiracy, an eighth admitted assisting an offender’
‘she finished eighth of the eleven runners’
‘an eighth of an inch’
--Word--
naughty nineties 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The 1890s, regarded as a time of liberalism and permissiveness, especially in Britain and France.
--Examples--
--Word--
ninetieth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number ninety in a sequence; 90th.
Each of ninety equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
--Examples--
‘her ninetieth birthday celebration’
‘a goal in the ninetieth minute’
‘a series of lines a ninetieth of an inch apart’

ninetyish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Valois, Dame Ninette de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Nineveh 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city located on the east bank of the River Tigris, opposite the modern city of Mosul. It was the oldest city of the ancient Assyrian empire and its capital until it was destroyed by a coalition of Babylonians and Medes in 612 BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ninevite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the ancient city of Nineveh, capital of Assyria from the reign of Sennacherib (704–681 b.c.) until its sack in 612 b.c.
Of, relating to, or designating the Ninevites or their culture.
--Examples--
--Word--
voiced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Speaking or singing with a voice of a specified kind.
(of an opinion or attitude) expressed in a particular way.
(of a speech sound) uttered with resonance of the vocal cords (e.g. b, d, g)
--Examples--
‘a squeaky-voiced comedian’
‘a passionate deep-voiced singer’
‘a commonly voiced concern amongst doctors’
‘strongly voiced sentiments’
‘a voiced velar fricative’
--Word--
nine 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
Equivalent to the product of three and three; one more than eight, or one less than ten; 9.
A group of nine individuals.
Nine years old.
Nine o'clock.
A size of garment or other merchandise denoted by nine.
A playing card with nine pips.
The nine Muses.
--Examples--
‘nine European countries’
‘nine of the twelve members’
‘I was only nine’
‘it's ten to nine’

ninhydrin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
El Niño 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An irregularly occurring and complex series of climatic changes affecting the equatorial Pacific region and beyond every few years, characterized by the appearance of unusually warm, nutrient-poor water off northern Peru and Ecuador, typically in late December. The effects of El Niño include reversal of wind patterns across the Pacific, drought in Australasia, and unseasonal heavy rain in South America.
--Examples--
--Word--
ninon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lightweight silk dress fabric.
--Examples--
‘ninon stockings’
--Word--
ninon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lightweight silk dress fabric.
--Examples--
‘ninon stockings’
--Word--
Nynorsk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A literary form of the Norwegian language, based on certain country dialects and constructed in the 19th century to serve as a national language more clearly distinct from Danish than Bokmål.
--Examples--
--Word--
El Niño 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An irregularly occurring and complex series of climatic changes affecting the equatorial Pacific region and beyond every few years, characterized by the appearance of unusually warm, nutrient-poor water off northern Peru and Ecuador, typically in late December. The effects of El Niño include reversal of wind patterns across the Pacific, drought in Australasia, and unseasonal heavy rain in South America.
--Examples--
--Word--
ninth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number nine in a sequence; 9th.
The ninth finisher or position in a race or competition.
An interval spanning nine consecutive notes in a diatonic scale.
The note which is higher by a ninth than the tonic of a diatonic scale or root of a chord.
A chord in which the ninth note of the scale forms an important component.
Each of nine equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
--Examples--
‘the ninth century’
‘the ninth of March’
‘he came in ninth’

--Word--
Niobe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The daughter of Tantalus. Apollo and Artemis, enraged because Niobe boasted herself superior to their mother Leto, killed her children and turned her into a stone.
--Examples--
--Word--
Niobean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or resembling Niobe.
--Examples--

niobite 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--

niobium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 41, a silver-grey metal of the transition series, used in superconducting alloys.
--Examples--

niobium 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
nip 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Bite or pinch sharply.
(of the cold or frost) damage or hurt.
Remove something by pinching or squeezing sharply.
Go quickly.
Steal or snatch (something).
A sharp bite or pinch.
A feeling of biting cold.
--Examples--
‘one of the dogs nipped him on the leg’
‘his teeth nipped at her ear’
‘the vegetable garden, nipped now by frost’
‘he nipped off a length of wire with the cutters’
‘I'm just nipping down to the Post Office’
‘a strong beak which can deliver a serious nip’
‘a keen nip in the air’
--Word--
NYP 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
Nipmuc 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating, of, or relating to the Nipmucs or their language.
A member of any of several Algonquian-speaking North American Indian peoples formerly inhabiting parts of central Massachusetts and adjacent Connecticut and Rhode Island. Also, in later use: a member of any of several groups claiming decent from these.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nipmuc 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating, of, or relating to the Nipmucs or their language.
A member of any of several Algonquian-speaking North American Indian peoples formerly inhabiting parts of central Massachusetts and adjacent Connecticut and Rhode Island. Also, in later use: a member of any of several groups claiming decent from these.
--Examples--

--Word--
nipper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A child.
Pliers, pincers, or a similar tool for gripping or cutting.
The grasping claw of a crab or lobster.
An insect or other creature that nips or bites.
A burrowing marine prawn used as fishing bait.
A junior lifeguard.
--Examples--
‘I was force-fed vegetables as a nipper’
‘using a pair of nippers you can chip away at the tiles’
‘mosquitoes must be some of the most voracious nippers ever created’
--Word--
nipperkin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quantity of liquid that can be contained in a nipperkin; a small quantity of ale, wine, spirits, etc. Chiefly Scottish in later use.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
nippy 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to move quickly; nimble.
(of a motor vehicle) able to accelerate quickly.
(of the weather) chilly.
(of an animal) having a tendency to nip or bite.
(of food) sharp-tasting; tangy.
A waitress in any of the restaurants of J. Lyons & Co. Ltd in London from about 1920 to 1950.
--Examples--
‘a very nippy scrum half’
‘the new Saab is very nippy and jolly safe when overtaking’
‘it's a bit nippy this morning’
‘macaws can sometimes be nippy and unpredictable’
‘nippy Red Leicester’
--Word--
nippy 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to move quickly; nimble.
(of a motor vehicle) able to accelerate quickly.
(of the weather) chilly.
(of an animal) having a tendency to nip or bite.
(of food) sharp-tasting; tangy.

nip 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Bite or pinch sharply.
(of the cold or frost) damage or hurt.
Remove something by pinching or squeezing sharply.
Go quickly.
Steal or snatch (something).
A sharp bite or pinch.
A feeling of biting cold.

‘his teeth nipped at her ear’
‘the vegetable garden, nipped now by frost’
‘he nipped off a length of wire with the cutters’
‘I'm just nipping down to the Post Office’
‘a strong beak which can deliver a serious nip’
‘a keen nip in the air’

nipple 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The small projection in which the mammary ducts of female mammals terminate and from which milk can be secreted.
The vestigial structure in a male that corresponds to the nipple of a female mammal.
The teat of a feeding bottle.
A small projection on a device, especially one from which oil or other fluid is dispensed.
A short section of pipe with a screw thread at each end for coupling.
--Examples--
‘it is crucial to remove the cap or nipple of the baby's bottle before heating’
‘the centralized greasing point comprises a bank of seven nipples’
‘install a threaded nipple between the valve outlet and the shut-off inlet’

noun
--Meanings--

nirvana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Buddhism) a transcendent state in which there is neither suffering, desire, nor sense of self, and the subject is released from the effects of karma and the cycle of death and rebirth. It represents the final goal of Buddhism.
An ideal or idyllic state or place.
--Examples--
‘the days of socialist nirvana in Europe are over’

--Word--
nisi prius 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A writ directing a sheriff to provide a jury at the Court of Westminster on a particular day, unless the assize judges come before that day to the county from which the jury was to be drawn. Now only in "writ of nisi prius".
The hearing of civil causes by the judges in the Assize Court or (in later British use) Crown Court; court business of this kind. Also in "cause (also court, justice, record,etc.) of nisi prius".
--Examples--

nispero

noun
--Meanings--
Any of several trees resembling the medlar tree, or which produce fruits resembling the medlar; specifically (a) any of various tropical American trees of the genus Manilkara, especially the sapodilla, M. zapota; (b) the loquat or Japanese medlar, Eriobotrya japonica.

--Word--
blue 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour intermediate between green and violet, as of the sky or sea on a sunny day.
(of a person's skin) having turned blue as a result of cold or breathing difficulties.
(of a bird or other animal) having blue markings.
(of a cat, fox, or rabbit) having fur of a smoky grey colour.
(of a ski run) of the second-lowest level of difficulty, as indicated by blue markers positioned along it.
Denoting one of three colours of quark.
(of a person or mood) melancholy, sad, or depressed.
(of a film, joke, or story) having sexual or pornographic content.
Politically conservative.
Blue colour or pigment.
Blue clothes or material.
The blue ball in snooker, billiards, and similar games.
The sky or sea, or the unknown.
A small butterfly, the male of which is predominantly blue while the female is typically brown.
A person who has represented Cambridge University (a Cambridge blue) or Oxford University (an Oxford blue) at a particular sport in a match between the two universities.
A distinction awarded to a Cambridge blue or an Oxford blue.
An argument or fight.
A mistake.
A nickname for a red-headed person.
A supporter of the Conservative Party.
Make or become blue.
Heat (metal) so as to give it a greyish-blue finish.
Wash (white clothes) with bluing.
--Examples--
‘the clear blue sky’
‘a blue silk shirt’
‘deep blue eyes’
‘Ashley went blue and I panicked’
‘a blue jay’
‘the blue fox’
‘he's feeling blue’
‘a blue movie’
‘the successful blue candidate’
‘she was dressed in blue’
‘the dark blue of his eyes’
‘armchairs in pastel blues and greens’
‘Susan wore blue’
‘far out upon the blue were many sails’
‘a flyweight boxing blue’
‘Adrian's brother won a rugby blue in December’
‘did you have a blue or what?’
‘his tactical blue in saying the opposition wasn't ready to govern’
‘only an Aussie could make a red-headed man ‘Blue.’’
‘the light dims, bluing the retina’
‘blued paper’
‘the day would haze, the air bluing with afternoon’
‘nickel-plated or blued hooks’
‘they blued the shirts and starched the uniforms’

--Word--
Nitralloy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: any of a range of alloy steels specially manufactured for nitriding and usually containing (among other elements) about one per cent of aluminium and 0.2 to 0.5 per cent of carbon.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitramine 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of compounds containing the group \\\NNO₂, some of which are used as propellants or explosives.
Specifically. An aromatic compound of this class, (CH₃)(NO₂)NC₆H₂(NO₂)₃, used as a pH indicator and in explosives.
An alkaloid which occurs naturally in several shrubs of the genus Nitraria (nitre-bushes); C₁₀H₁₉NO.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitroaniline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of three isomeric yellow or orange crystalline compounds, C₆H₄(NO₂)(NH₂), which are derivatives of aniline having a nitro group attached to the carbon ring, and are used in the manufacture of dyes; nitrophenylamine.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A salt or ester of nitric acid, containing the anion NO₃- or the group —NO₃
Treat (a substance) with nitric acid, especially so as to introduce nitro groups.
--Examples--
‘preserved meat and vegetables contain nitrates’
‘fish-fry populations are damaged by nitrate’
‘nitrated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons’
‘a powerful nitrating agent’

noun

nitritoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating an adverse drug reaction (originally to arsenicals, now especially to parenteral gold salts) characterized by facial flushing, nausea, dizziness, and rarely hypotension and syncope, resembling the effects of the vasodilator amyl nitrite.

noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-negative bacteria (family Nitrobacteraceae), whose members are found in soil and water and have the ability to oxidize nitrites to nitrates; (also nitrobacter) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrobacterium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any nitrifying bacterium; especially one of the genus Nitrobacter, which oxidizes nitrites to nitrates. Usually in plural.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrobarite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native barium nitrate, crystallizing in the cubic system and occurring as colourless octahedral crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrobenzene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow oily liquid made by nitrating benzene, used in chemical synthesis.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrocalcite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native hydrated calcium nitrate, crystallizing in the monoclinic system and occurring as a whitish efflorescence on soil and calcareous rocks.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrocellulose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly flammable material made by treating cellulose with concentrated nitric acid, used to make explosives (e.g. guncotton) and celluloid.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrocellulose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly flammable material made by treating cellulose with concentrated nitric acid, used to make explosives (e.g. guncotton) and celluloid.
--Examples--

nitrocotton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Guncotton.

nitrocotton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Guncotton.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitroform 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An explosive white crystalline compound, CH(NO₂)₃, which is a derivative of methane having three nitro groups attached to the carbon atom; trinitromethane.
A preparation of urea-formaldehyde used as a slow-release nitrogenous fertilizer. [A trademark in the United States.]
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrofuran 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A furan derivative having a nitro group attached to one of the carbon atoms of the furan ring, especially one which has been used as an antiseptic or antibacterial agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 7, a colourless, odourless unreactive gas that forms about 78 per cent of the earth's atmosphere. Liquid nitrogen (made by distilling liquid air) boils at 77.4 kelvins (−195.8°C) and is used as a coolant.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrogenate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To combine or treat with nitrogen; to nitride (an alloy steel).
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrogenation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of combining or treating a substance with nitrogen; (Metallurgy) = nitridation.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrogen-fixing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or bringing about nitrogen fixation.
--Examples--

nitrogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 7, a colourless, odourless unreactive gas that forms about 78 per cent of the earth's atmosphere. Liquid nitrogen (made by distilling liquid air) boils at 77.4 kelvins (−195.8°C) and is used as a coolant.

nitrolic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

nitromagnesite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native hydrated magnesium nitrate, crystallizing in the monoclinic system and occurring as an efflorescence on certain rocks.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitromannite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An explosive colourless crystalline substance, C₆H₈(ONO₂)₆, which is obtained by treating mannitol with a mixture of nitric and sulphuric acids and used in the manufacture of explosive caps and medicinally as a vasodilator; mannitol hexanitrate.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument designed for the determination of the amount of nitrogen in a compound; especially †(a) (originally) an instrument devised by Andrew Ure (1778–1857) for the measurement of alkalis (including sodium and potassium nitrates) by neutralization with acid (obsolete); (b) (later) an apparatus of a type devised by Georg Lunge (1839–1923), incorporating a burette and a parallel glass tube, for the measurement of the nitric oxide evolved by reaction of nitrates with sulphuric acid in the presence of mercury (and also used to measure gases evolved in other reactions).
--Examples--
--Word--
nitromethane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oily liquid which is used as a solvent and as rocket fuel.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitronaphthalene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two isomeric crystalline compounds, C₁₀H₇NO₂, which are nitro-derivatives of naphthalene.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitroparaffin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance obtained by the nitration of (a) paraffin; a nitroalkane or mixture of nitroalkanes.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrophenol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound containing a nitro and a phenolic hydroxyl group; specifically each of three isomeric derivatives of phenol, C₆H₄(NO₂)OH, in which one of the hydrogen atoms has been replaced by a nitro group.

--Word--
nitroprusside 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt containing the complex anion [Fe(CN)₅NO]2−, obtained by treating a ferro or ferricyanide with nitric acid; especially such a salt (frequently sodium nitroprusside) used as a reagent in various analytical tests and as an emergency hypotensive agent.

noun
--Meanings--
A compound containing the group NNO attached to two organic groups. Compounds of this kind are generally carcinogenic.

nitrosyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The group —N=O; the cation NO+. Also: a complex containing nitric oxide (NO) bonded to a metal atom as a neutral ligand.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrosyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The group —N=O; the cation NO+. Also: a complex containing nitric oxide (NO) bonded to a metal atom as a neutral ligand.
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrosylsulphuric acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline acid, HO.SO₂.ONO, which forms as an intermediate during the manufacture of sulphuric acid by the lead chamber process and is used (in sulphuric acid solution) for bleaching cereal milling products and for dye manufacture.

--Word--
Nitrosomonas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-negative aerobic bacteria (family Nitrobacteraceae) whose members have the ability to oxidize ammonia to nitrite, and are found in soil and water; (also nitrosomonas) a bacterium of this genus (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
nitrotoluene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of three isomeric derivatives of toluene, C₆H₄(NO₂)CH₃, obtained by replacing one of the ring hydrogen atoms with a nitro group, two of which (the ortho and para isomers) are used in the manufacture of dyes.

--Word--
Niue 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island territory in the South Pacific to the east of Tonga; population 1,200 (estimated 2015); languages, English (official), local Austronesian; capital, Alofi. Annexed by New Zealand in 1901, the island achieved self-government in free association with New Zealand in 1974. Niue is the world's largest coral island.
--Examples--
--Word--
Niuean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Niue, an island territory in the South Pacific.
Relating to Niue or its people.
--Examples--
‘the Niueans found themselves in an extremely insecure position’
‘the Niuean education system’

nivation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

nix 
--Type--
pronoun, exclamation, verb, noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Nothing.
Expressing denial or refusal.
Put an end to; cancel.
A water sprite.
Used as a signal or warning that a person in authority is approaching.
--Examples--
‘apart from that, nix’
‘‘I owe you some money,’ ‘Nix, nix.’’
‘he nixed the deal just before it was to be signed’

--Word--
Nixon, Richard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1913–94), American Republican statesman, 37th president of the US 1969–74; full name Richard Milhous Nixon. His period of office was overshadowed by the Vietnam War. Re-elected in 1972, he became the first president to resign from office, owing to his involvement in the Watergate scandal.
--Examples--
--Word--
nixtamal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Latin American cookery: maize kernels which have been boiled and steeped in an alkaline solution (usually lime water) in order to remove the hulls, used to make masa.

Nkomo, Joshua 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1917–99), Zimbabwean statesman; full name Joshua Mqabuko Nyongolo Nkomo. He became leader of the ZAPU party in 1961; in 1976 he formed the Patriotic Front with Robert Mugabe, leader of ZANU, and he held a cabinet post in the first post-independence government. He was vice president 1990–9.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nkrumah, Kwame 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1909–72), Ghanaian statesman, prime minister 1957–60, president 1960–6. The first prime minister after independence, he became increasingly dictatorial and was finally overthrown in a military coup.
--Examples--
--Word--
NKVD 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The secret police agency in the former Soviet Union which absorbed the functions of the former OGPU in 1934. It merged with the MVD in 1946.

--Word--
no 
--Type--
determiner, exclamation, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Not any.
Used to indicate that something is quite the opposite of what is being specified.
Hardly any.
Used in notices or slogans forbidding or rejecting something specified.
Used to give a negative response.
Expressing disagreement or contradiction.
Expressing agreement with or affirmation of a negative statement.
Expressing shock or disappointment.
Not at all; to no extent.
Not.
A negative answer or decision, especially in voting.
--Examples--
‘there is no excuse’
‘no two plants are alike’
‘it was no easy task persuading her’
‘Toby is no fool’
‘you'll be back in no time’
‘No Smoking signs’
‘no nukes’
‘‘Is anything wrong?’ ‘No.’’
‘‘This is boring.’ ‘No, it's not!’’
‘they would never cause a fuss, oh no’
‘oh no, look at this!’
‘they were no more able to perform the task than I was’
‘I'll no be a minute’
‘he was unable to change his automatic yes to a no’

--Examples--
--Word--
Chomsky, Noam 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1928), US theoretical linguist; full name Avram Noam Chomsky. Noted for expounding the theory of generative grammar, he also theorized that linguistic behaviour is innate, not learned, and that all languages share the same underlying grammatical base. Chomsky is known also for his opposition to American involvement in the Vietnam War and the Gulf War. Notable works: Syntactic Structures (1957) and Aspects of the Theory of Syntax (1965).
--Examples--
--Word--
nob 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person of wealth or high social position.
A person's head.
--Examples--
‘it was quite a do—all the nobs were there’
--Word--
no-ball 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An unlawfully delivered ball, counting one as an extra to the batting side if not otherwise scored from.
(of an umpire) declare (a bowler) to have bowled a no-ball; declare (a delivery) to be a no-ball.
--Examples--
‘we also bowled far too many no-balls and wides’
‘at Lord's he took a Test hat-trick and was no-balled for throwing’
