--Word--
nobble 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Try to influence or thwart by underhand or unfair methods.
Tamper with (a racehorse or greyhound) to prevent it from winning a race, especially by giving it a drug.
Obtain dishonestly; steal.
Seize or accost (someone)
--Examples--
‘an attempt to nobble the jury’
‘a doping ring nobbled three of the trainer's horses in 1990’
‘he intended to nobble Rose's money’
‘they nobbled him and threw him on to the train’
‘people always tried to nobble her at parties’
--Word--
nobble 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Try to influence or thwart by underhand or unfair methods.
Tamper with (a racehorse or greyhound) to prevent it from winning a race, especially by giving it a drug.
Obtain dishonestly; steal.
Seize or accost (someone)
--Examples--
‘an attempt to nobble the jury’
‘a doping ring nobbled three of the trainer's horses in 1990’
‘he intended to nobble Rose's money’
‘they nobbled him and threw him on to the train’
‘people always tried to nobble her at parties’

nobbler

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
nobelium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 102, a radioactive metal of the actinide series. Nobelium does not occur naturally and was first produced by bombarding curium with carbon nuclei.
--Examples--

nobility 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being noble in character.
The quality of belonging to the aristocracy.
The group of people belonging to the highest social class in a country; the aristocracy.

‘after 1722 nobility was only acquired by service in the army or bureaucracy’
‘a member of the English nobility’

--Word--
non nobis 
--Type--
exclamation, noun
--Meanings--
Expressing gratitude or thanksgiving.
Psalm 115 (part of Psalm 113 in the Vulgate), which in the King James Bible begins ‘Not unto us, O Lord, not unto us’ (Vulgate Non nobis, Domine, non nobis). Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
noble 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging by rank, title, or birth to the aristocracy.
Having or showing fine personal qualities or high moral principles.
Of imposing or magnificent size or appearance.
Of excellent or superior quality.
(especially in former times) a person of noble rank or birth.
A former English gold coin first issued in 1351.
--Examples--
‘the medieval palace was once owned by a noble Florentine family’
‘the Duchess of Kent and several other noble ladies’
‘the promotion of human rights was a noble aspiration’
‘noble arches and massive granite columns’
‘there is nothing more noble than a mature pine forest’
‘Chardonnay is the noble grape from which some of the finest white wines are produced’
‘the greater a noble's military power, the more land he could control’
‘the king imposed a tax on both nobles and peasants’
--Word--
noble-born 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging by birth to the aristocracy.
--Examples--
‘the noble-born Lady Mary Hamilton’

--Word--
featured 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having distinctive attributes or aspects of a specified kind.
Having facial parts, such as the mouth, nose, and eyes, of a specified kind.
(of a newspaper or magazine article, broadcast programme, or show) made a special attraction.
--Examples--
‘the front of the chassis is well featured’
‘the complexities of a fully featured computer’
‘this blond, blue-eyed, regular-featured queen’
‘my aunt was a tall, hard-featured lady’
‘our featured interview for this issue’
‘he was the featured guest artist’

--Word--
Nocardia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-positive, aerobic actinomycetes whose members typically form mycelia that tend to fragment into rod-shaped or coccoid elements, and are widely distributed in soil and water, sometimes acting as (usually opportunistic) pathogens of humans and other animals.
--Examples--
--Word--
nocardiosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease caused by Nocardia species, especially N. asteroides, chiefly seen in immunocompromised individuals and typically beginning with abscess formation in the lungs or in the skin, sometimes spreading to other organs, especially the brain.
--Examples--
--Word--
nocent 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
nocerite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral originally regarded as an oxyfluoride of calcium and magnesium, but later recognized as identical with the mineral fluoborite, Mg₃BO₃(F,OH)₃.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun, verb

--Word--
nod 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Lower and raise one's head slightly and briefly, especially in greeting, assent, or understanding, or to give someone a signal.
Signify or express (greeting, assent, or understanding) by nodding.
Approve something by general agreement, without discussion.
Move one's head up and down repeatedly.
Let one's head fall forward when drowsy or asleep.
Make a mistake due to a momentary lack of alertness or attention.
Head (the ball) without great force.
An act of nodding the head.
A gesture of acknowledgement or concession to.
--Examples--
‘he looked around for support and everyone nodded’
‘she nodded her head in agreement’
‘he nodded his consent’
‘the DTI nodded through the bid from Airtours’
‘he shut his eyes, nodding to the beat’
‘foxgloves nodding by the path’
‘Anna nodded over her book’
‘scientific reason, like Homer, sometimes nods’
‘Henry nodded the ball over the line’
‘at a nod from his father he left the room’
‘the device is a nod to the conventions of slapstick’
--Word--
nodal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting a point in a network or diagram at which lines or pathways intersect or branch.
Relating to the part of a plant stem from which one or more leaves emerge, often forming a slight swelling.
Relating to or characterized by a lymph node or other structure consisting of a small mass of differentiated tissue.
--Examples--
‘pencil lines overlap at some nodal points’
‘Lwow is a nodal point for the railroads’
‘the nodal roots develop about an inch above the seed’
‘nodal lymphoma’
--Word--
nodality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Geography. The degree to which a place is a point of convergence for different routes.
Generally. The property of being nodal or of possessing nodes.
Limnology. The number of nodes of an oscillation.
--Examples--
--Word--
nodality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Geography. The degree to which a place is a point of convergence for different routes.
Generally. The property of being nodal or of possessing nodes.
Limnology. The number of nodes of an oscillation.
--Examples--
--Word--
nodally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
As regards nodes; at or with nodes; (in extended use) at particular points of concentration.
--Examples--
--Word--
nod 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Lower and raise one's head slightly and briefly, especially in greeting, assent, or understanding, or to give someone a signal.

--Meanings--
A foolish person.
A tropical tern with mainly dark-coloured plumage.
A brief shot in a filmed interview in which the interviewer nods in agreement or acknowledgement.
A character in the writings of Enid Blyton, a toy figure of a boy whose head is fixed in such a way that he has to nod when he speaks.
--Examples--
--Word--
noddy 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A foolish person.
A tropical tern with mainly dark-coloured plumage.
A brief shot in a filmed interview in which the interviewer nods in agreement or acknowledgement.
A character in the writings of Enid Blyton, a toy figure of a boy whose head is fixed in such a way that he has to nod when he speaks.
--Examples--
--Word--
nod 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Lower and raise one's head slightly and briefly, especially in greeting, assent, or understanding, or to give someone a signal.
Signify or express (greeting, assent, or understanding) by nodding.
Approve something by general agreement, without discussion.
Move one's head up and down repeatedly.
Let one's head fall forward when drowsy or asleep.
Make a mistake due to a momentary lack of alertness or attention.
Head (the ball) without great force.
An act of nodding the head.
A gesture of acknowledgement or concession to.
--Examples--
‘he looked around for support and everyone nodded’
‘she nodded her head in agreement’
‘he nodded his consent’
‘the DTI nodded through the bid from Airtours’
‘he shut his eyes, nodding to the beat’
‘foxgloves nodding by the path’
‘Anna nodded over her book’
‘scientific reason, like Homer, sometimes nods’
‘Henry nodded the ball over the line’
‘at a nod from his father he left the room’
‘the device is a nod to the conventions of slapstick’
--Word--
noddingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of nodding, with nodding; (with reference to knowledge, acquaintance, etc.) in a slight or small degree, to a slight extent.
--Examples--

--Word--
node 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A point in a network or diagram at which lines or pathways intersect or branch.
A piece of equipment, such as a computer or peripheral, attached to a network.
(in generative grammar) a vertex or end point in a tree diagram.
A point at which a curve intersects itself.
Either of the two points at which a planet's orbit intersects the plane of the ecliptic or the celestial equator.
The part of a plant stem from which one or more leaves emerge, often forming a slight swelling.
A lymph node or other structure consisting of a small mass of differentiated tissue.
A point at which the amplitude of vibration in a standing wave system is zero.
A point at which a harmonic function has the value zero, especially a point of zero electron density in an orbital.
A point of zero current or voltage.
--Examples--
‘the intersections of two or more such arteries would clearly become major nodes of traffic and urban activity’
‘the company's internal worldwide area network now has some 22,000 nodes’
‘every node on the Internet’
‘the stem is cut midway between nodes’
‘infection in these nodes may lead to backache’
--Word--
noded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing a node or nodes. Also as the second element in compounds: containing or having a specified number of nodes.
--Examples--
--Word--
deposit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sum of money paid into a bank or building society account.
A sum payable as a first instalment on the purchase of something or as a pledge for a contract, the balance being payable later.
A returnable sum payable on the hire or rental of something, to cover possible loss or damage.
(in the UK) a sum of money lodged by an election candidate and forfeited if they fail to receive a certain proportion of the votes.
A layer or mass of accumulated matter.
A natural underground layer of rock, coal, or other material.
The action of placing something in a specified place.
Put or set down (something or someone) in a specific place.
(of water, the wind, or other natural agency) lay down (matter) gradually as a layer or covering.
Lay (an egg)
Place (something) somewhere for safekeeping.
Pay (a sum of money) into a bank or building society account.
Pay (a sum) as a first instalment or as a pledge for a contract.
--Examples--
‘cash funds which are an alternative to bank or building society deposits’
‘we've saved enough for a deposit on a house’
‘a refundable €100 deposit is payable on arrival at the villa’
‘he lost his deposit but was credited with contributing to the Conservatives' defeat’
‘the deposits of salt on the paintwork’
‘a great quantity of pottery was found in this deposit’
‘areas of mineral deposits’
‘the deposit of a thesis in a library gives no guarantee of copyright protection’
‘I'd like to make a deposit’
‘he deposited a pile of school books on the kitchen table’
‘beds where salt is deposited by the tide’
‘the female deposits a line of eggs’
‘a vault in which guests may deposit valuable property’
‘the money had been deposited in a Swiss bank account’
‘I had to deposit 10% of the price of the house’
--Word--
the point of no return 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
The point in a journey or enterprise at which it becomes essential or more practical to continue to the end rather than turn back.

--Word--
nodule 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small swelling or aggregation of cells in the body, especially an abnormal one.
A swelling on a root of a leguminous plant, containing nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
A small rounded lump of matter distinct from its surroundings, e.g. of flint in chalk, carbon in cast iron, or a mineral on the seabed.
--Examples--
‘the area feels firm but has irregular nodules which can be painful to touch’
‘laparotomy showed white nodules in the liver’
‘flint nodules’
‘in the coal pits nodules of iron ore were mined’

no 
--Type--
determiner, exclamation, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Not any.
Used to indicate that something is quite the opposite of what is being specified.
Hardly any.
Used in notices or slogans forbidding or rejecting something specified.
Used to give a negative response.
Expressing disagreement or contradiction.
Expressing agreement with or affirmation of a negative statement.
Expressing shock or disappointment.
Not at all; to no extent.
Not.
A negative answer or decision, especially in voting.
--Examples--
‘there is no excuse’
‘no two plants are alike’
‘it was no easy task persuading her’
‘Toby is no fool’
‘you'll be back in no time’
‘No Smoking signs’
‘no nukes’
‘‘Is anything wrong?’ ‘No.’’
‘‘This is boring.’ ‘No, it's not!’’

‘they were no more able to perform the task than I was’

‘he was unable to change his automatic yes to a no’

noesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Philosophy. In phenomenology: a process or an act of perceiving or thinking, as opposed to an object of perception or thought; (also) the subjective aspect of an intentional experience, as opposed to the noema.

--Word--
Noetherian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or arising from the work of Max or Emmy Noether.
Specifically. Designating a ring in which there exists no infinitely growing sequence of ideals such that each ideal is a subset of the next in sequence. Also: designating a module in which there exists no infinitely growing sequence of submodules such that each is a subset of its successor.
--Examples--
--Word--

Noguchi, Isamu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–88), US sculptor and designer. The son of a Japanese father and American mother, he lived in both countries when young. His interests and achievements extended to set design for Martha Graham’s ballet, garden design, furniture design, construction of paper lamps, and the sculpting of massive stone works.

--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
noise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sound, especially one that is loud or unpleasant or that causes disturbance.
A series or combination of loud, confused sounds, especially when causing disturbance.
Conventional remarks made to express something.
Irregular fluctuations that accompany a transmitted electrical signal but are not part of it and tend to obscure it.
Random fluctuations that obscure or do not contain meaningful data or other information.
Talk about or make known publicly.
Make much noise.
--Examples--
‘making a noise like a pig’
‘what's that rustling noise outside the door?’
‘she was dazed with the heat and noise’
‘vibration and noise from traffic’
‘the government made tough noises about defending sterling’
‘the enhancer can improve the video signal quality, reducing noise and increasing image sharpness’
‘over half the magnitude of the differences came from noise in the data’
‘you've discovered something that should not be noised about’
‘rook, crow and jackdaw—noising loud’

‘the pub was crowded and noisy’
‘noisy pressure groups’
--Word--
noisy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Making or given to making a lot of noise.
Full of or characterized by noise.
Stridently seeking to attract attention to one's views.
Accompanied by or introducing random fluctuations that obscure the real signal or data.
--Examples--
‘a noisy, giggling group of children’
‘diesel cars can be very noisy’
‘the pub was crowded and noisy’
‘noisy pressure groups’

adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner that makes a lot of noise.
In a manner that stridently seeks to attract attention to one's views.
--Examples--
‘helicopters hovered noisily overhead’
‘Elizabeth exhaled noisily in exasperation’
‘he has noisily criticized pension reform plans’

--Examples--
--Word--
noise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sound, especially one that is loud or unpleasant or that causes disturbance.
A series or combination of loud, confused sounds, especially when causing disturbance.
Conventional remarks made to express something.
Irregular fluctuations that accompany a transmitted electrical signal but are not part of it and tend to obscure it.
Random fluctuations that obscure or do not contain meaningful data or other information.
Talk about or make known publicly.
Make much noise.
--Examples--
‘making a noise like a pig’
‘what's that rustling noise outside the door?’
‘she was dazed with the heat and noise’
‘vibration and noise from traffic’
‘the government made tough noises about defending sterling’
‘the enhancer can improve the video signal quality, reducing noise and increasing image sharpness’
‘over half the magnitude of the differences came from noise in the data’
‘you've discovered something that should not be noised about’
‘rook, crow and jackdaw—noising loud’

noisome

adjective
--Meanings--

‘a noisome concoction of which cheap port is the basis’
‘even if a journalist wanted to deliver the noisome truth, patriotism and censorship would prevent him’

--Word--
Ryan, Nolan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1947), US baseball player; full name Lynn Nolan Ryan, Jr. He pitched for the New York Mets 1966, 1968–71, the California Angels 1972–79, the Houston Astros 1980–88, and the Texas Rangers 1989–93. He holds the career records for no-hitters (7) and strikeouts (5,714). Baseball Hall of Fame (1999).

--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation, plural noun, verb

--Word--
nomad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a people that travels from place to place to find fresh pasture for its animals and has no permanent home.
A person who does not stay long in the same place; a wanderer.
--Examples--
‘the withering of their grasslands forced the nomads of the Sahara to descend into the Nile valley’
‘the nomads who roam the borderlands of Afghanistan’
‘the Magyars were a nomad people of the steppes’
‘Dolly was a nomad who had finally taken root in Hawaii’

nomenclature 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The devising or choosing of names for things, especially in a science or other discipline.
The body or system of names used in a particular specialist field.
The term or terms applied to someone or something.

‘the most important rule of nomenclature is that the name of a substance should be unambiguous’
‘the students found it hard to decipher the nomenclature of chemical compounds’
‘‘customers’ was preferred to the original nomenclature ‘passengers’’

--Word--
nominal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a role or status) existing in name only.
Relating to or consisting of names.
(of a price or charge) very small; far below the real value or cost.
(of a quantity or dimension) stated or expressed but not necessarily corresponding exactly to the real value.
Expressed in terms of current prices or figures, without making allowance for changes over time.
Relating to or functioning as a noun.
(chiefly in the context of space travel) functioning normally or acceptably.
--Examples--
‘Thailand retained nominal independence under Japanese military occupation’
‘the streets have names like Third Avenue, but the resemblance to Manhattan is only nominal’
‘a nominal roll of the Grenadier Company shows a total of 86 men’
‘they charge a nominal fee for the service’
‘EU legislation allowed variation around the nominal weight (that printed on each packet)’
‘the nominal exchange rate’
‘a nominal group’
--Word--
nominalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine that universals or general ideas are mere names without any corresponding reality. Only particular objects exist, and properties, numbers, and sets are merely features of the way of considering the things that exist. Important in medieval scholastic thought, nominalism is associated particularly with William of Occam.
--Examples--
--Word--
nominalist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
nominate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Propose or formally enter as a candidate for election or for an honour or award.
Appoint to a job or position.
Specify (something) formally, typically the date or place for an event.
Denoting a race or subspecies which is given the same epithet as the species to which it belongs, e.g. Homo sapiens sapiens.
--Examples--
‘the film was nominated for several Oscars’
‘the company nominated her as a delegate to the convention’
‘a day was nominated for the exchange of contracts’
‘the nominate race and two subspecies occur’

nomineeism

nomogram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diagram representing the relations between three or more variable quantities by means of a number of scales, so arranged that the value of one variable can be found by a simple geometrical construction, e.g. by drawing a straight line intersecting the other scales at the appropriate values.
--Examples--
‘in calculating dosage we encourage the use of a nomogram that takes account of age, sex, renal function, and body weight’

nomology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science and philosophy concerned with the laws or principles governing the operation of the mind, especially as defined by custom or culture. Formerly also: †a treatise on this (obsolete).
The science of law; the branch of knowledge concerned with law and justice.
--Examples--
--Word--
nomological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting principles that resemble laws, especially those laws of nature which are neither logically necessary nor theoretically explicable, but just are so.

--Word--
nomothetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the study or discovery of general scientific laws.
--Examples--
--Word--
nom 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation, plural noun, verb
--Meanings--
A nomination for an honour, award, etc.
Nominate for an honour, award, etc.
Used to express pleasure at eating, or at the prospect of eating.
Food.
Eat (something), typically with great enjoyment.
--Examples--
‘she isn't the the only star to receive an Oscar nom for her first feature film role’
‘Inception was nommed for an Oscar but lost out to The King's Speech’
‘chili and cornbread for dinner, nom nom!’
‘I love pizza. Nom nom nom’
‘Try the mac and cheese! Nom!’
‘tempura shrimp, lettuce, cucumber, spicy mayo—om nom nom’
‘there were all kinds of nom noms—onion rings, hot dogs, burgers, and fries’
‘a Mexican restaurant that serves noms like sweet potato empanadas’
‘I nommed all my pizza before I remembered to take a picture’
‘the first sighting of a leatherback turtle in Dorset—it's nomming a jellyfish, as they do’
‘I just nom-nommed the kettle chips you brought me’
‘we nommed on stir-fry and then ordered several desserts’
--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’

non-atomic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not involving atoms; not composed of atoms, structurally continuous.
Logic. Of a proposition: containing a logical constant.
Mathematics and Computing. Not simple but compound; composed conceptually of smaller units; (specifically in measure theory) designating a metric space, or a measure defined on such a space, in which every measurable set having non-zero measure contains a measurable subset having a smaller non-zero measure.

--Word--
Bolshevik 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.
Relating to or characteristic of Bolsheviks or Bolshevism.
--Examples--
‘the Bolshevik revolution’
--Word--
Bolshevism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The communist form of government adopted in Russia following the Bolshevik revolution of 1917.
--Examples--
‘enthusiastic supporters of Bolshevism’
--Word--
Bolshevist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A supporter or member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.
--Examples--
‘the seizure of power by the Bolshevists’
‘the Bolshevist movement’
‘he is not a bolshevist, but he is by nature a bit of a grumbler’
‘students with bolshevist tendencies’
--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’
--Word--
non-book 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Something that is not a book, especially a publication or library holding (as a manuscript, microfilm, audio-visual tool, etc.).
A book of little or no literary merit, a potboiler, picture book, etc.
Of, relating to, using, or designating something (especially a publication or other communicative medium) that is not a book, or not a book of any literary merit. Chiefly attributive.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Brahmanical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to the highest Hindu caste, originally that of the priesthood.
--Examples--
‘Buddhist stupas and Brahminical temples’
--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’

--Word--
Caucasian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
White-skinned; of European origin.
Relating to one of the traditional divisions of humankind, covering a broad group of peoples from Europe, western Asia, and parts of India and North Africa.
Relating to the Caucasus.
Relating to a group of languages spoken in the region of the Caucasus, of which thirty-eight are known, many not committed to writing. The most widely spoken is Georgian, of the small South Caucasian family, not related to the three North Caucasian families.
A white person; a person of European origin.
A person from the Caucasus.
--Examples--
‘twenty of the therapists were Caucasian, two were African American, and two were Hispanic’
‘a Caucasian of slim build, 198 cm tall with short grey hair and a grey beard’
‘the Caucasians of Southern Russia’

adjective

In early use of (part of) a school: not resembling or preparing pupils for a college.

nonconforming

--Word--
nonconformism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nonconformist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Protestant Church which dissents from the established Church of England.
A person who does not conform to prevailing ideas or practices in their behaviour or views.
Relating to Nonconformists or their principles and practices.
Characterized by behaviour or views that do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
--Examples--
‘originally a Nonconformist, he was later converted to Anglo-Catholicism’
‘Jenkins was a nonconformist who disdained the rugby union coaching certificate’
‘she was a nonconformist, an individualist’
‘teetotalism was a largely Nonconformist movement’
‘a Nonconformist minister’
‘he was eccentric and nonconformist, as artists tend to be’
‘nonconformist directors like Scorsese’
--Word--

Characterized by behaviour or views that do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
--Examples--
‘originally a Nonconformist, he was later converted to Anglo-Catholicism’
‘Jenkins was a nonconformist who disdained the rugby union coaching certificate’
‘she was a nonconformist, an individualist’
‘teetotalism was a largely Nonconformist movement’
‘a Nonconformist minister’
‘he was eccentric and nonconformist, as artists tend to be’
‘nonconformist directors like Scorsese’
--Word--
nonconformist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Protestant Church which dissents from the established Church of England.
A person who does not conform to prevailing ideas or practices in their behaviour or views.
Relating to Nonconformists or their principles and practices.
Characterized by behaviour or views that do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.

‘the nonemployment of force’
--Word--
non-empty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a set or class) not empty; having at least one element or member.
--Examples--

noun

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
none-so-pretty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of fabric used in dressmaking and furnishing, probably a worsted or lightish stuff. Now historical and rare.
Chiefly North American. A kind of decorative haberdashery tape (more fully "none-so-pretty tape"), often woven in two colours or patterned with simple motifs, and typically used to dress furnishings. Now historical and rare.
Any of several garden flowers, especially (a) London pride, Saxifraga× urbium (now rare); (b) heartsease, Viola tricolor; (c) sweet william catchfly, Silene armeria. Compare "nancy-pretty". Now chiefly North American.

gypsy 
--Type--

--Word--
Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goths or their extinct language, which belongs to the East Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family. It provides the earliest manuscript evidence of any Germanic language (4th–6th centuries AD).
Of or in the style of architecture prevalent in western Europe in the 12th–16th centuries (and revived in the mid 18th to early 20th centuries), characterized by pointed arches, rib vaults, and flying buttresses, together with large windows and elaborate tracery. English Gothic architecture is divided into Early English, Decorated, and Perpendicular.
Belonging to or redolent of the Dark Ages; portentously gloomy or horrifying.
(of lettering) of or derived from the angular style of handwriting with broad vertical downstrokes used in western Europe from the 13th century, including Fraktur and black-letter typefaces.
Relating to goths or goth music.
The extinct language of the Goths.
The Gothic style of architecture.
Gothic type.
--Examples--
‘19th-century Gothic horror’
--Word--
Gothically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
Hebrew 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient people living in what is now Israel and Palestine and, according to biblical tradition, descended from the patriarch Jacob, grandson of Abraham. After the Exodus (c.1300 BC) they established the kingdoms of Israel and Judah, and their scriptures and traditions form the basis of the Jewish religion.
A Jew.
The Semitic language spoken by the Hebrews, in its ancient or modern form.
Of or in Hebrew.
Of the Hebrews or the Jews.

nonius 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device consisting of a series of concentric arcs engraved on a quadrant, used for the accurate measurement of angles, altitudes, and heights. Also (in full "nonius quadrant"): the quadrant itself; also called pantometer. Frequently attributive Now chiefly historical.

--Word--
non-local 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
That is not local; not relating to, originating from, or restricted to a particular place or locality.
Mathematics and Physics. Designating an operation or property of a topological space that is not applicable only to a specified neighbourhood in the space; (specifically in quantum theory) relating to the phenomenon whereby properties of isolated systems which are not causally related classically or relativistically may depend on each other.
A person who does not inhabit, or is not associated with, a particular place or locality.

--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’

Nordic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting Scandinavia, Finland, and Iceland.
Relating to or denoting a physical type of northern European peoples characterized by tall stature, a bony frame, light colouring, and a dolichocephalic head.
Involving the disciplines of cross-country skiing or ski jumping.
A person from Scandinavia, Finland, or Iceland.
--Examples--
‘the Nordic countries’
‘the Nordic races’
‘on one street corner a dusky Moorish maiden, the next a Nordic blonde’
‘Jim competes as a veteran in Nordic events in Scotland’
‘the Nordics might share a common history, speak similar languages, enjoy the same culture’

--Word--
Norman 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city in central Oklahoma, south of Oklahoma City, home to the University of Oklahoma; population 106,957 (est. 2008).
A member of a people of mixed Frankish and Scandinavian origin who settled in Normandy from about AD 912 and became a dominant military power in western Europe and the Mediterranean in the 11th century.
Any of the Normans who conquered England in 1066, or their descendants.
A native or inhabitant of modern Normandy.
The form of French spoken by the Normans.
Relating to the Normans.
Denoting or relating to the style of Romanesque architecture used in Britain under the Normans.
Relating to modern Normandy.
--Examples--
‘the castle goes right back to the Normans’
‘born c.1080, he was presumably a Norman from Calvados’
‘the Norman invasion’
‘the 11th-century Norman crypt of Winchester Cathedral’
‘Willy rambled on about Norman archways and Perpendicular naves’
‘Norman ore was to have been smelted there with Ruhr coal’
--Word--

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The Norwegian language, especially in an ancient or medieval form, or the Scandinavian language group.
Norwegians or Scandinavians in ancient or medieval times.
Relating to ancient or medieval Norway or Scandinavia.
--Examples--
‘he spent a lifetime fighting against the Norse’
‘Loki was the Norse god of evil’
‘Norse settlements in Ireland’
‘Keld is a Norse word meaning ‘a spring’’

--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’

non-performing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is guilty of failing to fulfil a promise, contract, obligation, etc. (rare).
Designating or relating to a person affiliated with the arts but not involved in public performance. Also: denoting an art such as painting, sculpture, etc., which does not normally involve public performance by the artist.
Finance. Of, relating to, or denoting an asset that is not producing the anticipated or contractually due income; especially denoting a loan whose borrower has defaulted on repayments. Frequently in "non-performing asset", "non-performing loan".

polish 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Make the surface of (something) smooth and shiny by rubbing it.
Improve, refine, or add the finishing touches to.
A substance used to give something a smooth and shiny surface when rubbed in.
An act of rubbing something to give it a shiny surface.
Smoothness or glossiness produced by rubbing or friction.
Refinement or elegance in a person or thing.
polish something off
Quickly finish or consume something.
Relating to Poland, its inhabitants, or their language.
The Western Slavic language of Poland, spoken by more than 40 million people.
--Examples--
‘behind the bar the steward polished glasses busily’
‘he's got to polish up his French for his job’
‘a tin of shoe polish’
‘I could give the wardrobe a polish’
‘the machine refines the shape of the stone and gives it polish’
‘his poetry has clarity and polish’
‘they polished off most of the sausages’

--Word--
Protestant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member or follower of any of the Western Christian Churches that are separate from the Roman Catholic Church in accordance with the principles of the Reformation, including the Baptist, Presbyterian, and Lutheran Churches.
Relating to or belonging to any of the Protestant Churches.
--Examples--
‘the Protestant religion’
‘the family were staunchly Protestant’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

adjective
--Meanings--
Of a school or the education given there: not provided by the local education authority.

Prussian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the former kingdom of Prussia.
A native or inhabitant of Prussia.
--Examples--
‘her eldest daughter was married to the Prussian Crown Prince’
‘a general advance pushed the Prussians from the field’

--Word--
Quaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the Religious Society of Friends, a Christian movement founded by George Fox c.1650 and devoted to peaceful principles. Central to the Quakers' belief is the doctrine of the ‘Inner Light’, or sense of Christ's direct working in the soul. This has led them to reject both formal ministry and all set forms of worship.
--Examples--
‘a Quaker burial ground’
--Word--
Quakerish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

non-recoil 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Especially of a firearm, its mounting, etc.: that does not rebound when discharged. In quot. 1855 as noun: the fact of not rebounding.
--Examples--
--Word--
non-recoil 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
non-recourse 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Attributive Of, designating, or relating to, a loan under the terms of which the lender has a limited right of recourse, or none, against the borrower; especially (US) a government loan made to a farmer and secured against a future crop, whereby the government is legally prohibited from taking action should the proceeds of the crop be insufficient for repayment (frequently as "non-recourse loan"). Also: of, designating, or relating to, a loan made to finance a particular project, whereby the project's profits are the only assets out of which the borrowing company is legally obliged to repay the loan.
--Examples--
--Word--
nonrecurring 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of costs, charges, taxes, etc.) occurring one time only.
Not returning or recurring.
--Examples--
‘nonrecurring grants to officers’
‘a nonrecurring illness’

non-resident 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

‘the bank's deposits are held by UK residents and non-residents’

Riemannian geometry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of differential non-Euclidean geometry developed by Bernhard Riemann, used to describe curved space. It provided Einstein with a mathematical basis for his general theory of relativity.

Russian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Russia, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Russia, or a person of Russian descent.
(in general use) a national of the former Soviet Union.

--Word--
sabbatical 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A period of paid leave granted to a university teacher or other worker for study or travel, traditionally one year for every seven years worked.
Relating to a sabbatical.
Of or appropriate to the sabbath.
--Examples--
‘she's away on sabbatical’
‘he requested permission to take a sabbatical in Istanbul’
‘he took a three-month sabbatical from his job as CEO of a family business’
‘sabbatical leave’
‘a number of sabbatical positions are available’

--Word--
Saxon 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people that inhabited parts of central and northern Germany from Roman times, many of whom conquered and settled in much of southern England in the 5th–6th centuries.
A native of modern Saxony in Germany.
The West Germanic language of the ancient Saxons.
The Low German dialect of modern Saxony.
Relating to the Anglo-Saxons, their language (Old English), or their period of dominance in England (5th–11th centuries).
Relating to or denoting the style of early Romanesque architecture preceding the Norman in England.
Relating to Saxony or the continental Saxons or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Scandinavian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Scandinavia, its people, or their languages.
A native or inhabitant of Scandinavia, or a person of Scandinavian descent.
The northern branch of the Germanic languages, comprising Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, Icelandic, and Faroese, all descended from Old Norse.

--Word--
non-self 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Philosophy. That which is not a self, or is not regarded as part of an individual's conscious self; the external world. Also: (especially in Buddhism) a state characterized by the absence of, or a lack of awareness of, any form of conscious, independent self.
Immunology. Non-self matter.
Immunology. Of, relating to, or designating matter which has not been produced by a particular individual and so is identified by the body's immune system (in normal circumstances) as foreign or abnormal, provoking an immune response.
--Examples--
--Word--
governing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having authority to conduct the policy, actions, and affairs of a state, organization, or people.
--Examples--
‘the governing coalition’
--Word--
Semite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of the peoples who speak or spoke a Semitic language, including in particular the Jews and Arabs.
--Examples--
--Word--
Semitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages that includes Hebrew, Arabic, and Aramaic and certain ancient languages such as Phoenician and Akkadian, constituting the main subgroup of the Afro-Asiatic family.
Relating to the peoples who speak Semitic languages, especially Hebrew and Arabic.
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsensity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Nonsensicality.
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsense 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Spoken or written words that have no meaning or make no sense.
Used to show strong disagreement.
Denoting verse or other writing intended to be amusing by virtue of its absurd or whimsical language.
Foolish or unacceptable behaviour.
Something ridiculously impractical or ill-advised.
--Examples--
‘he was talking absolute nonsense’
‘‘Nonsense! No one can do that.’’
‘nonsense poetry’
‘she's a strong woman who stands no nonsense’
‘the law is a nonsense’
‘the proposal would make a nonsense of their plans’

--Type--

--Meanings--
The fact or quality of being nonsensical, nonsensicality.
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsensical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having no meaning; making no sense.
Ridiculously impractical or ill-advised.
--Examples--
‘a nonsensical argument’
‘he dismissed the claim as nonsensical’
‘a tax that everyone recognizes was nonsensical’
--Word--
nonsensicality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsensically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsensicalness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or quality of being nonsensical, nonsensicality.
--Examples--
--Word--
nonsensification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The production of nonsense.

--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Shakespearean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of William Shakespeare or his works.
An expert on or student of Shakespeare's writings.
--Examples--
‘the early Shakespearean plays’
‘an eminent Shakespearean actor’
‘there is an almost Shakespearean quality to the narrative’
‘several Shakespeareans have reviewed the film’
--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’
--Word--
Sienese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Italian city of Siena or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the Italian city of Siena.
--Examples--
‘Sienese dancers’
‘plenty of cash changes hands as the Sienese furtively bet on their horse to win’

Slavic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the branch of the Indo-European language family that includes Russian, Ukrainian, and Belorussian (Eastern Slavic), Polish, Czech, Slovak, and Sorbian (Western Slavic), and Bulgarian, Serbian, Croatian, Macedonian, and Slovene (Southern Slavic).
Relating to or denoting the peoples of central and eastern Europe who speak any of these languages.
The Slavic languages collectively.

--Word--
non-stop 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Continuing without stopping or pausing.
(of a passenger vehicle or journey) not having or making stops at intermediate places on the way to its destination.
Oppressively constant; relentless.
Without stopping or pausing.
A non-stop flight or train.
--Examples--
‘we had two days of almost non-stop rain’
‘a non-stop flight to Los Angeles’
‘the show was axed after non-stop criticism’
‘Stephen had been working non-stop’
‘the airline offers seven non- stops to New York every business day’
--Word--
non-striker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Sport. A player who does not strike the ball; (Cricket) the batsman who is at the bowler's end at the time of a delivery, and who therefore does not face the ball.
A person (especially a worker) who chooses not to go on strike.

--Word--
tartar 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A hard calcified deposit that forms on the teeth and contributes to their decay.
A deposit of impure potassium hydrogen tartrate formed during the fermentation of wine.
A member of the combined forces of central Asian peoples, including Mongols and Turks, who under the leadership of Genghis Khan conquered much of Asia and eastern Europe in the early 13th century, and under Tamerlane (14th century) established an empire with its capital at Samarkand.
A harsh, fierce, or intractable person.
--Examples--
‘my new Company Commander is a horrible tartar’

adjective
--Meanings--
Not characteristic of the tropics; not located in or native to the tropics; (of a disease) not acquired in or limited to the tropics.
--Examples--
--Word--
non-truth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An untruth; a lie, a falsehood.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Turkey, or a person of Turkish descent.
A member of any of the ancient central Asian peoples who spoke Turkic languages, including the Seljuks and Ottomans.
A member of the ruling Muslim population of the Ottoman Empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turkic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a large group of closely related Altaic languages of western and central Asia, including Turkish, Azerbaijani, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Uighur, Uzbek, and Tatar.
The Turkic languages collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turkish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Turkey or to the Turks or their language.
Relating to or associated with the Ottoman Empire.
The official language of Turkey, a Turkic language spoken by about 50 million people. It was written in the Arabic script until 1928, when the Roman alphabet was adopted.
--Examples--
--Word--
Tuscan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Tuscany, its inhabitants, or the form of Italian spoken there, which is a standard variety widely taught to foreign learners.
Relating to or denoting a classical order of architecture resembling the Doric but lacking all ornamentation.
A native or inhabitant of Tuscany.
The form of Italian spoken in Tuscany.
The Tuscan order of architecture.
--Examples--
--Word--
non-U 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of language or social behaviour) not characteristic of the upper social classes; not socially acceptable to certain people.
--Examples--
‘he's always teasing her for her Cockney accent and her non-U turns of phrase’
--Word--
Ukrainian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Ukraine, or a person of Ukrainian descent.
The Eastern Slavic language of Ukraine, which has about 60 million speakers worldwide.
Relating to Ukraine, its people, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Umbrian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Umbria, its people, or their languages.
A native or inhabitant of Umbria, especially in pre-Roman times.
An extinct Italic language of central Italy, related to Oscan and surviving in inscriptions mainly of the 2nd and 1st centuries BC.

Unitarian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who asserts the unity of God and rejects the doctrine of the Trinity.
A member of a Church or religious body maintaining this belief and typically rejecting formal dogma in favour of a rationalist and inclusivist approach to belief.
Relating to the Unitarians.

adjective
--Meanings--

universalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective

nonuplet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Music. A group of nine notes to be performed in the time of eight or six. rare.
Each of nine siblings resulting from a single pregnancy. Usually in plural.
Science. A multiplet of nine subatomic particles; an aggregate of nine components. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
non- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Expressing negation or absence.
Not of the kind or class described.
Not of the importance implied.
(added to adverbs) not in the way described.
(added to verbs to form adjectives) not causing or requiring.
Expressing a neutral negative sense when a corresponding form beginning with in- or un- has a special connotation (such as non-human compared with inhuman).
--Examples--
‘non-aggression’
‘non-recognition’
‘non-believer’
‘nonconformist’
‘non-issue’
‘non-uniformly’
‘non-skid’
‘non-iron’

non-utility 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Lack of practical usefulness; uselessness.
US. Designating or relating to a company other than a public utility; specifically (a) of or relating to power generation other than for public use; (b) of or relating to power generation by a privately owned company as opposed to a public utility.
Not merely functional; specifically (during and following the Second World War, 1939–45), designating clothes and household goods of better than utility quality.
--Examples--

non-valent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: (now rare) not readily forming chemical bonds; inert. Later: having a formal oxidation state of zero; = "zerovalent".

--Word--
non-vascular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. That does not contain blood vessels (or, rarely: lymphatic vessels); that has not undergone vascularization; that does not have a blood supply. Also: that does not involve or belong to blood vessels; that is not caused by (disease of) blood vessels.
Botany. That lacks conducting tissue (xylem and phloem).
--Examples--
--Word--
non-vascular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. That does not contain blood vessels (or, rarely: lymphatic vessels); that has not undergone vascularization; that does not have a blood supply. Also: that does not involve or belong to blood vessels; that is not caused by (disease of) blood vessels.
Botany. That lacks conducting tissue (xylem and phloem).

--Word--
welsh 
--Type--
verb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Fail to honour (a debt or obligation incurred through a promise or agreement)
Relating to Wales, its people, or their language.
The Celtic language of Wales, spoken by about 500,000 people (mainly bilingual in English). Descended from the Brythonic language spoken in most of Roman Britain, it has been strongly revived after a long decline.
The people of Wales collectively.
--Examples--
‘banks began welshing on their agreement not to convert dollar reserves into gold’

noo 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
New. In early use chiefly in representations of spoken place names, as "Noo Yawk", "Noo Orleans", with the spelling being regarded as imitative of the pronunciation of speakers from the place concerned.

noodle 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A very thin, long strip of pasta or a similar flour paste, eaten with a sauce or in a soup.
A stupid or silly person.
A person's head.
Improvise or play casually on a musical instrument.
Search (an opal dump) for opals.
--Examples--
‘cook the noodles in a large pan of boiling water’
‘spicy Sichuan noodles’
‘tapes of him noodling on his farfisa organ’
‘he was half-heartedly noodling the dumps for opal chips’
‘anyone can noodle in the gravelly tailings of the mine’

--Word--
Noonan syndrome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An inherited (autosomal dominant) syndrome typically characterized by short stature, facial dysmorphism, webbed neck, congenital heart disease, and various other abnormalities, resembling Turner's syndrome but without sex chromosome abnormalities.

noon-flower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Australian and South African. Any of the plants belonging or formerly belonging to the genus Mesembryanthemum (family Aizoaceae), many of which flower only around midday. Compare midday flower).

noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loop with a running knot, tightening as the rope or wire is pulled and used to trap animals or hang people.
Death by hanging.
Put a noose on (someone)
Catch (an animal) with a noose.
Form (a rope) into a noose.
--Examples--
‘he began to choke as the noose tightened about his throat’
‘a hangman's noose’
‘the West is exploring ways to tighten the economic noose’
‘he earned a reprieve from the noose’
‘she was noosed and hooded, then strangled by the executioner’
‘the animal was eventually noosed and sedated by dog handlers’
‘Gomez had noosed a coil of rope around his neck’
--Word--
noose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
noosphere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A postulated sphere or stage of evolutionary development dominated by consciousness, the mind, and interpersonal relationships.
--Examples--
‘creatures evolve: a new biosphere emerges, and with it a new noosphere’
--Word--
Nootka 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an indigenous people of Vancouver Island, Canada.
The Wakashan language of the Nootka, now with few speakers.
Relating to the Nootka or their language.

nopal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cactus which is a major food plant of the bugs from which cochineal is obtained.
The edible fleshy pads of the nopal cactus, used in Mexican cuisine.

--Word--
nor 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Used before the second or further of two or more alternatives (the first being introduced by a negative such as ‘neither’ or ‘not’) to indicate that they are each untrue or each do not happen.
Used to introduce a further negative statement.
Than.
A Boolean operator which gives the value one if and only if all operands have a value of zero and otherwise has a value of zero.
A circuit which produces an output signal only when there are no signals on any of the input connections.
--Examples--
‘they were neither cheap nor convenient’
‘the sheets were never washed, nor the towels, nor his shirts’
‘nor God nor demon can undo the done’
‘‘I don't see how.’ ‘Nor do I.’’
‘she thinks she knows better nor me’
--Word--
nor' 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
(especially in compounds) north.
--Examples--
‘seek shelter from a raging nor'easter’
--Word--
nor- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Denoting an organic compound derived from another, in particular by the shortening of a chain or ring by the removal of one methylene group or by the replacement of one or more methyl side chains by hydrogen atoms.
--Examples--
‘noradrenaline’

--Word--
noradrenaline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hormone which is released by the adrenal medulla and by the sympathetic nerves and functions as a neurotransmitter. It is also used as a drug to raise blood pressure.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

adjective
--Meanings--

norbergite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic basic silicate and fluoride of magnesium, Mg₃SiO₄(F,OH)₂, which is a member of the humite group and occurs as pink or whitish crystals.

--Word--
Wiener, Norbert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1894–1964), American mathematician. He is best known for establishing the science of cybernetics in the late 1940s. Wiener made major contributions to the study of stochastic processes, integral equations, harmonic analysis, and related fields.

--Type--
adjective, noun

Nordic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting Scandinavia, Finland, and Iceland.
Relating to or denoting a physical type of northern European peoples characterized by tall stature, a bony frame, light colouring, and a dolichocephalic head.
Involving the disciplines of cross-country skiing or ski jumping.
A person from Scandinavia, Finland, or Iceland.
--Examples--
‘the Nordic countries’
‘the Nordic races’
‘on one street corner a dusky Moorish maiden, the next a Nordic blonde’
‘Jim competes as a veteran in Nordic events in Scotland’
‘the Nordics might share a common history, speak similar languages, enjoy the same culture’

noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine of or belief in the cultural and racial supremacy of the Nordic people. Now historical.

Nordicist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
nordicity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A measure of the degree of northernness of high-latitude regions, calculated by assessing both natural factors, such as climate and temperature, and human factors, such as types of economic activity and cultural self-perception. Also (in extended use): northernness.
--Examples--

nordmarkite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mineralogy. A brown variety of staurolite rich in manganese.
Geology. A syenite composed mainly of microperthite, with lesser amounts of quartz and usually oligoclase and biotite, and characterized by a trachytoid or granitic texture.

nor'-east 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
North-east.
Situated in the north-east or designating the north-eastern part of an area. Also (of a wind): blowing from the north-east. Compare "north-east"rare before 19th cent.
From a north-easterly direction. rare.

Noric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Noricum, an ancient Celtic kingdom and later Roman province in Western Europe whose borders roughly corresponded to present-day Austria.
Made from or designating a kind of steel manufactured in this area, used especially for swords.
Geology= Norian. Also as noun Now rare.
--Examples--

norland 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating a nurse or nanny trained at Norland College or its precursor, and training given under its auspices. Also absol.: a Norland nurse or nanny. [A trademark in the U.K.]
Belonging to the north, that comes from the north.
A northern region, a land or country in the north; specifically the northern part of Scotland.
A northerner; a person from the north, especially the north of Scotland. Compare Norlander. Now rare.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
norm 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Something that is usual, typical, or standard.
A standard or pattern, especially of social behaviour, that is typical or expected.
A required standard; a level to be complied with or reached.
The product of a complex number and its conjugate, equal to the sum of the squares of its real and imaginary components, or the positive square root of this sum.
An analogous quantity used to represent the magnitude of a vector.
Adjust (something) to conform to a norm.
--Examples--
‘strikes were the norm’
‘the norms of good behaviour in the Civil Service’
‘the 7 per cent pay norm had been breached again’
--Word--
Norma 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small and inconspicuous southern constellation (the Rule), lying partly in the Milky Way between Lupus and Ara.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Norma.
--Examples--
‘the star Gamma Normae’
--Word--
normal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Conforming to a standard; usual, typical, or expected.
(of a person) free from physical or mental disorders.
(of a line, ray, or other linear feature) intersecting a given line or surface at right angles.
(of a salt solution) containing the same salt concentration as the blood.
(of a solution) containing one gram-equivalent of solute per litre.
Denoting a fault or faulting in which a relative downward movement occurred in the strata situated on the upper side of the fault plane.
The usual, typical, or expected state or condition.
A person who is conventional or healthy.
A line at right angles to a given line or surface.
--Examples--
‘it's quite normal for puppies to bolt their food’
‘normal working hours’
‘until her accident Louise had been a perfectly normal little girl’
‘many previously normal people exhibit psychotic symptoms after a few nights without sleep’
‘a single plane of symmetry with a diad axis normal to it’
‘dilute the stock solution with sterile water or normal saline’
‘her temperature was above normal’
‘the service will be back to normal next week’
‘the view is along the normal to the surface’
--Word--
normality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being normal; the state of being usual, typical, or expected.
--Examples--
‘the office gradually returned to a semblance of normality’
--Word--
normalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of bringing or returning something to a normal condition or state.
--Examples--
‘the normalization of the situation will make the area more conducive to business activities’
‘he paved the way for normalization of relations between the two countries’
--Word--
normalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Bring or return to a normal or standard condition or state.
Multiply (a series, function or item of data) by a factor that makes the norm or some associated quantity such as an integral equal to a desired value (usually 1)
(in floating-point representation) express (a number) in the standard form as regards the position of the radix point, usually immediately following the first non-zero digit.
--Examples--
‘the two countries normalized diplomatic relations in 1995’
‘the situation had normalized’
‘both sets of data have been normalized such that the lowest value is equal to 1’

adverb

normal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Conforming to a standard; usual, typical, or expected.

--Word--
Norman 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city in central Oklahoma, south of Oklahoma City, home to the University of Oklahoma; population 106,957 (est. 2008).
A member of a people of mixed Frankish and Scandinavian origin who settled in Normandy from about AD 912 and became a dominant military power in western Europe and the Mediterranean in the 11th century.
Any of the Normans who conquered England in 1066, or their descendants.
A native or inhabitant of modern Normandy.
The form of French spoken by the Normans.
Relating to the Normans.
Denoting or relating to the style of Romanesque architecture used in Britain under the Normans.
Relating to modern Normandy.
--Examples--
‘the castle goes right back to the Normans’
‘born c.1080, he was presumably a Norman from Calvados’
‘the Norman invasion’
‘the 11th-century Norman crypt of Winchester Cathedral’
‘Willy rambled on about Norman archways and Perpendicular naves’
‘Norman ore was to have been smelted there with Ruhr coal’
--Word--
Normandy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former province of north-western France with a coastline on the English Channel, now divided into the two regions of Lower Normandy (Basse-Normandie) and Upper Normandy (Haute-Normandie); chief town, Rouen.
--Examples--

Normanesque

adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Norman French 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The northern form of Old French spoken by the Normans.
The variety of Norman French used in English law courts from the 11th to 13th centuries; Anglo-Norman French.
The French dialect of modern Normandy.

Norman 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city in central Oklahoma, south of Oklahoma City, home to the University of Oklahoma; population 106,957 (est. 2008).
A member of a people of mixed Frankish and Scandinavian origin who settled in Normandy from about AD 912 and became a dominant military power in western Europe and the Mediterranean in the 11th century.
Any of the Normans who conquered England in 1066, or their descendants.
A native or inhabitant of modern Normandy.
The form of French spoken by the Normans.
Relating to the Normans.
Denoting or relating to the style of Romanesque architecture used in Britain under the Normans.
Relating to modern Normandy.

--Word--
norm 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Something that is usual, typical, or standard.
A standard or pattern, especially of social behaviour, that is typical or expected.
A required standard; a level to be complied with or reached.
The product of a complex number and its conjugate, equal to the sum of the squares of its real and imaginary components, or the positive square root of this sum.
An analogous quantity used to represent the magnitude of a vector.
Adjust (something) to conform to a norm.
--Examples--
‘strikes were the norm’
‘the norms of good behaviour in the Civil Service’
‘the 7 per cent pay norm had been breached again’
--Word--
normie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ordinary or conventional person, as distinguished from someone who is a member of a particular group or subculture.
--Examples--
‘I need a guide for geeks struggling to buy presents for normies’
‘the venue had a ‘no blue jeans’ policy to keep out normies’

--Word--
normoblast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An immature, nucleated red blood cell of normal size, having cytoplasm that is basophilic, polychromatophilic, or acidophilic (orthochromatic), depending on its stage of development.
--Examples--

normoblastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involving normoblasts.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

normotensive

--Word--
normothermia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Normal body temperature; the condition of having a normal body temperature. Also: a range of environmental temperature at which cellular activity is normal (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
normothermic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to normothermia; exhibiting or occurring at normal body temperature.

Norns 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The three virgin goddesses of destiny (Urd or Urdar, Verdandi, and Skuld), who sit by the well of fate at the base of the ash tree Yggdrasil and spin the web of fate.
--Examples--
--Word--
norpinic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline dicarboxylic acid, C₈H₁₂O₄, existing in cis and trans isomers and differing from pinic acid in having a carboxyl group attached to the cyclobutane ring in place of a carboxymethyl group.
--Examples--
--Word--
Norris, Frank 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1870–1902), US journalist and writer; full name Benjamin Franklin Norris, Jr. His fiction includes McTeague: A Story of San Francisco (1899) and The Octopus (1901). His unfinished trilogy Epic of Wheat documents the history of muckraking.
--Examples--
--Word--
norie 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The Atlantic puffin, Fratercula arctica.
Shetland. An inhabitant of the island of Foula.
A copy of the Epitome of Navigation by J. W. Norie (originally published in 1805) or a successor publication, such as Norie's Nautical Tables (1936, etc.), regarded as a standard work of reference.
--Examples--

Norris, Frank 
--Type--

--Meanings--
(1870–1902), US journalist and writer; full name Benjamin Franklin Norris, Jr. His fiction includes McTeague: A Story of San Francisco (1899) and The Octopus (1901). His unfinished trilogy Epic of Wheat documents the history of muckraking.

--Word--
north 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction.
The compass point corresponding to north.
A direction in space parallel to the earth's axis of rotation and towards the point on the celestial sphere around which the stars appear to turn anticlockwise.
The northern part of the world or of a specified country, region, or town.
The northern part of England.
The northern part of the US, especially the north-eastern states that fought to preserve the Union during the Civil War.
The industrialized and economically advanced nations of the world.
The player occupying a designated position at the table, sitting opposite and partnering South.
Lying towards, near, or facing the north.
(of a wind) blowing from the north.
Of or denoting the northern part of a specified country, region, or town.
To or towards the north.
Above (a particular amount, cost, etc.)
--Examples--
‘a bitter wind blew from the north’
‘Mount Kenya is to the north of Nairobi’
‘he drew a circle and marked north, south, east, and west’
‘there will be heavy wintry showers, particularly in the north’
‘he hired two lads from the North’
‘Cornishmen felt that the affairs of the North were too remote to interest them’
‘delegates from Virginia voted to join the North’
‘the summit was likely to be a failure due to the North's refusal to commit itself to safeguarding species diversity’
‘North deals and opens one club’
‘the north bank of the river’
‘the north door’
‘they were sheltering from the north winds’
‘North Wales’
‘North African’
‘the town is twenty-five miles north of Newport’
‘a north-facing wall’
‘they expect to spend north of $6 million for this latest campaign’

--Word--
Northcliffe, 1st Viscount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1865–1922), British newspaper proprietor; born Alfred Charles William Harmsworth. He built up a large newspaper empire, including The Times, the Daily Mail, and the Daily Mirror.

north-east 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction towards the point of the horizon midway between north and east.
The compass point corresponding to north-east.
The north-eastern part of a country, region, or town.
Lying towards, near, or facing the north-east.
(of a wind) blowing from the north-east.
Of or denoting the north-eastern part of a specified country, region, or town.
To or towards the north-east.
--Examples--
‘I pointed to the north-east’
‘the north-east of Scotland’
‘a seaside resort on the north-east coast of Kent’
‘there was a strong north-east wind’
‘north-east London’
‘the ship sailed north-east’
‘the north-east-facing slopes’

--Word--
Northeast Passage 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A passage for ships along the northern coast of Europe and Asia, from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean via the Arctic Ocean, sought for many years as a possible trade route to the East. It was first navigated in 1878–79 by Swedish Arctic explorer Baron Nordenskjöld (1832–1901).
--Examples--
--Word--

--Examples--
‘the troops marched north-eastwards’
‘the north-eastward territorial expansion of the city’

--Word--
northing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Distance travelled or measured northward, especially at sea.
A figure or line representing northward distance on a map (expressed by convention as the second part of a grid reference, after easting)
--Examples--
‘we should have to make 300 miles of northing’
‘everything above the 80 northing is positive, while everything below is negative’

north 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction.
The compass point corresponding to north.
A direction in space parallel to the earth's axis of rotation and towards the point on the celestial sphere around which the stars appear to turn anticlockwise.
The northern part of the world or of a specified country, region, or town.
The northern part of England.
The northern part of the US, especially the north-eastern states that fought to preserve the Union during the Civil War.
The industrialized and economically advanced nations of the world.
The player occupying a designated position at the table, sitting opposite and partnering South.
Lying towards, near, or facing the north.
(of a wind) blowing from the north.
Of or denoting the northern part of a specified country, region, or town.
To or towards the north.
Above (a particular amount, cost, etc.)
--Examples--
‘a bitter wind blew from the north’
‘Mount Kenya is to the north of Nairobi’
‘he drew a circle and marked north, south, east, and west’
‘there will be heavy wintry showers, particularly in the north’
‘he hired two lads from the North’
‘Cornishmen felt that the affairs of the North were too remote to interest them’
‘delegates from Virginia voted to join the North’
‘the summit was likely to be a failure due to the North's refusal to commit itself to safeguarding species diversity’
‘North deals and opens one club’
‘the north bank of the river’
‘the north door’
‘they were sheltering from the north winds’
‘North Wales’
‘North African’
‘the town is twenty-five miles north of Newport’
‘a north-facing wall’
‘they expect to spend north of $6 million for this latest campaign’
--Word--
north-north-eastwards 
--Type--
adverb

--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
north 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction.
The compass point corresponding to north.
A direction in space parallel to the earth's axis of rotation and towards the point on the celestial sphere around which the stars appear to turn anticlockwise.
The northern part of the world or of a specified country, region, or town.
The northern part of England.
The northern part of the US, especially the north-eastern states that fought to preserve the Union during the Civil War.
The industrialized and economically advanced nations of the world.
The player occupying a designated position at the table, sitting opposite and partnering South.
Lying towards, near, or facing the north.
(of a wind) blowing from the north.
Of or denoting the northern part of a specified country, region, or town.
To or towards the north.
Above (a particular amount, cost, etc.)
--Examples--
‘a bitter wind blew from the north’
‘Mount Kenya is to the north of Nairobi’
‘he drew a circle and marked north, south, east, and west’
‘there will be heavy wintry showers, particularly in the north’
‘he hired two lads from the North’
‘Cornishmen felt that the affairs of the North were too remote to interest them’
‘delegates from Virginia voted to join the North’
‘the summit was likely to be a failure due to the North's refusal to commit itself to safeguarding species diversity’
‘North deals and opens one club’
‘the north bank of the river’
‘the north door’
‘they were sheltering from the north winds’
‘North Wales’
‘North African’
‘the town is twenty-five miles north of Newport’
‘a north-facing wall’
‘they expect to spend north of $6 million for this latest campaign’
--Word--
north-north-westwards 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Towards the north-north-west.
--Examples--

north polar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a north pole, especially the earth's North Pole.

preceding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Coming before something in order, position, or time.
--Examples--
‘the preceding pages’
‘a growth in sales above those of the preceding year’
--Word--
Frye, Northrop 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–91), Canadian literary critic; full name Herman Northrop Frye. His work explores the use of myth and symbolism. Notable works: Fearful Symmetry (1947) and The Great Code: The Bible and Literature (1982).
--Examples--
--Word--
northness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being (relatively) northerly in direction, position, or orientation.
Northern quality or character.
--Examples--

--Examples--
‘thrill-seeking first years took part in abseiling’
‘such thrill-seeking comes at a price’

sider 
--Type--

--Meanings--

Northumbria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An area of north-eastern England comprising Northumberland, Durham, and Tyne and Wear.
An ancient Anglo-Saxon kingdom in north-eastern England extending from the Humber Estuary to the River Forth.
--Examples--

‘thousands of Northumbrians are celebrating their culture and history’
--Word--
northupite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chloride and carbonate of sodium and magnesium, Na₃Mg(CO₃)₂Cl, found as fine octahedral crystals belonging to the cubic system.

--Word--
north-west 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction towards the point of the horizon midway between north and west.
The compass point corresponding to north-west.
The north-western part of a country, region, or town.
Lying towards, near, or facing the north-west.
(of a wind) blowing from the north-west.
Of or denoting the north-western part of a country, region, or town, or its inhabitants.
To or towards the north-west.
--Examples--
‘he pointed to the north-west’
‘the north-west of London’
‘the north-west corner of the square’
‘a north-west gale’
‘north-west Europe’
‘he turned on to the motorway and headed north-west’

--Word--
Northwest Territory 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region and former territory of the US lying between the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and the Great Lakes. It was acquired in 1783 after the War of American Independence and now forms the states of Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Illinois, and Wisconsin.
--Examples--
--Word--

‘the river flows north-westwards towards Rheims’

nortriptyline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tricyclic antidepressant drug, C₁₉H₂₁N, with actions and uses similar to those of amitriptyline, and given orally as the hydrochloride.
