--Word--
nose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part projecting above the mouth on the face of a person or animal, containing the nostrils and used for breathing and smelling.
The sense of smell, especially a dog's ability to track something by its scent.
An instinctive talent for detecting something.
The aroma of a particular substance, especially wine.
The front end of an aircraft, car, or other vehicle.
A projecting part of something.
An act of looking around or prying.
A police informer.
(of an animal) thrust its nose against or into something.
Smell or sniff (something)
Look around or pry into something.
Detect by diligent searching.
(of a vehicle) move cautiously forward.
(of a competitor) manage to achieve a leading position by a small margin.
--Examples--
‘he slowly breathed out the air through his nose’
‘he pushed his glasses higher on to the bridge of his nose’
‘the dog pressed his nose into the palm of my hand’
‘a dog with a keen nose’
‘he has a nose for a good script’
‘the wine has a raspberry nose and a clean taste’
‘white peaches are particularly appreciated for their perfumed aromatic nose’
‘the plane's nose dipped as it started descending towards the runway’
‘the nose of the saddle’
‘she wanted a good nose round the house’
‘he knew that CID men are allowed to drink on duty as much of their time is spent with noses’
‘the pony nosed at the straw’
‘because of its strength, whisky is nosed rather than tasted’
‘Mario's gun dog nosed the carcass’
‘I was anxious to get inside and nose around her house’
‘she's always nosing into my business’
‘he nosed out the signs of trespass’
‘he turned left and nosed into an empty parking space’
‘they nosed ahead by one point’
--Word--
nosean 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral of the sodalite group, a silicate and sulphate of sodium and aluminium, Na₈Al₆Si₆O₂₄(SO₄), that crystallizes in the cubic system and occurs in phonolites and related volcanic rocks.
--Examples--
--Word--

nosedive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A steep downward plunge by an aircraft.
A sudden dramatic deterioration.
(of an aircraft) make a nosedive.
Deteriorate suddenly and dramatically.
--Examples--
‘the pilot put the plane in a nosedive and ejected’
‘the player's fortunes took a nosedive’
‘the plane nosedived into the ground and exploded’
‘massive strikes caused the economy to nosedive’

--Word--
dove 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
A stocky bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, feeding on seeds or fruit. Doves are generally smaller and more delicate than pigeons, but many kinds have been given both names.
A person who advocates peaceful or conciliatory policies, especially in foreign affairs.
(in Christian art and poetry) the Holy Spirit (as represented in John 1:32).
--Examples--
‘he was the cabinet's leading dove, the only minister to advocate peace talks’

piercing 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or showing shrewdness or keen intelligence.
(of a sound) extremely high or loud.
(of wind or extreme cold) seeming to cut through one.
(of a feeling) intense, typically in a distressing way.
A small hole in a part of the body, typically other than the ears, made so as to insert a ring, stud, or other piece of jewellery.
A ring, stud, or other piece of jewellery worn in a pierced part of the body.
--Examples--
‘her piercing analysis’
‘a tall blonde with piercing eyes’
‘she let out a piercing scream’
‘the piercing cold of winter’
‘I recall one moment of piercing sadness’
‘this is the place to get your tattoo or piercing done’
‘two months ago, I decided to take out all my piercings’

nose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part projecting above the mouth on the face of a person or animal, containing the nostrils and used for breathing and smelling.
The sense of smell, especially a dog's ability to track something by its scent.
An instinctive talent for detecting something.
The aroma of a particular substance, especially wine.
The front end of an aircraft, car, or other vehicle.
A projecting part of something.
An act of looking around or prying.
A police informer.
(of an animal) thrust its nose against or into something.
Smell or sniff (something)
Look around or pry into something.
Detect by diligent searching.
(of a vehicle) move cautiously forward.
(of a competitor) manage to achieve a leading position by a small margin.
--Examples--
‘he slowly breathed out the air through his nose’
‘he pushed his glasses higher on to the bridge of his nose’
‘the dog pressed his nose into the palm of my hand’
‘a dog with a keen nose’
‘he has a nose for a good script’
‘the wine has a raspberry nose and a clean taste’
‘white peaches are particularly appreciated for their perfumed aromatic nose’

‘the nose of the saddle’
‘she wanted a good nose round the house’

--Word--
pulled work 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ornamental working of woven fabric by pulling its constituent threads out of alignment (with or without subsequent needlework); cloth worked in this way.
--Examples--
--Word--
noser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A prying or inquisitive person, a person who seeks out; specifically (slang) an informer or spy for the police.
Distilling. A person employed to assess or maintain the quality of an alcoholic drink (especially whisky) by inhaling the aroma; specifically a master distiller.
--Examples--

--Examples--

--Word--
shy 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Nervous or timid in the company of other people.
Slow or reluctant to do (something)
Having a dislike of or aversion to a specified thing.
(of a wild mammal or bird) reluctant to remain in sight of humans.
Less than; short of.
Before.
(of a plant) not bearing flowers or fruit well or prolifically.
(especially of a horse) start suddenly aside in fright at an object, noise, or movement.
Avoid doing or becoming involved in (something) due to nervousness or a lack of confidence.
A sudden startled movement, especially of a frightened horse.
Fling or throw (something) at a target.
An act of flinging or throwing something at a target.
--Examples--
‘I was pretty shy at school’
‘a shy smile’
‘the wealthy have become less shy of displaying their privilege’
‘he was very car shy when he came here’
‘otters are very shy animals’
‘the shares are 29p shy of their flotation price’
‘he left school just shy of his fourteenth birthday’
‘their horses shied at the unfamiliar sight’
‘don't shy away from saying what you think’
‘he tore the spectacles off and shied them at her’
--Word--
smart 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person) clean, tidy, and well dressed.
(of clothes) attractively neat and stylish.
(of an object) bright and fresh in appearance.
(of a place) fashionable and upmarket.
Having or showing a quick-witted intelligence.
(of a device) programmed so as to be capable of some independent action.
Showing impertinence by making clever or sarcastic remarks.
Quick; brisk.
(of part of the body) feel a sharp stinging pain.
Feel upset and annoyed.
Sharp stinging pain.
Mental pain or suffering.
Intelligence; acumen.
--Examples--
‘you look very smart’
‘a smart blue skirt’
‘a smart green van’
‘a smart restaurant’
‘if he was that smart he would never have been tricked’
‘hi-tech smart weapons’
‘don't get smart or I'll whack you one’
‘he set off at a smart pace’
‘her legs were scratched and smarting’
‘defence chiefs are still smarting from the government's cuts’
‘the smart of the recent cuts’
‘sorrow is the effect of smart, and smart the effect of faith’
‘I don't think I have the smarts for it’
--Word--
nose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part projecting above the mouth on the face of a person or animal, containing the nostrils and used for breathing and smelling.
The sense of smell, especially a dog's ability to track something by its scent.
An instinctive talent for detecting something.
The aroma of a particular substance, especially wine.
The front end of an aircraft, car, or other vehicle.
A projecting part of something.
An act of looking around or prying.
A police informer.
(of an animal) thrust its nose against or into something.
Smell or sniff (something)
Look around or pry into something.
Detect by diligent searching.
(of a vehicle) move cautiously forward.
(of a competitor) manage to achieve a leading position by a small margin.
--Examples--
‘he slowly breathed out the air through his nose’
‘he pushed his glasses higher on to the bridge of his nose’
‘the dog pressed his nose into the palm of my hand’
‘a dog with a keen nose’
‘he has a nose for a good script’
‘the wine has a raspberry nose and a clean taste’
‘white peaches are particularly appreciated for their perfumed aromatic nose’
‘the plane's nose dipped as it started descending towards the runway’
‘the nose of the saddle’
‘she wanted a good nose round the house’
‘he knew that CID men are allowed to drink on duty as much of their time is spent with noses’
‘the pony nosed at the straw’
‘because of its strength, whisky is nosed rather than tasted’
‘Mario's gun dog nosed the carcass’
‘I was anxious to get inside and nose around her house’
‘she's always nosing into my business’
‘he nosed out the signs of trespass’
‘he turned left and nosed into an empty parking space’
‘they nosed ahead by one point’

nosism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With reference to a group of people: a self-centred attitude, corresponding to egotism in an individual. rare before 20th cent.
With reference to an individual: the use of the word ‘we’ in stating his or her own opinions. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
system 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A set of things working together as parts of a mechanism or an interconnecting network; a complex whole.
A set of organs in the body with a common structure or function.
The human or animal body as a whole.
A group of related hardware units or programs or both, especially when dedicated to a single application.
(in chronostratigraphy) a major range of strata that corresponds to a period in time, subdivided into series.
A group of celestial objects connected by their mutual attractive forces, especially moving in orbits about a centre.
A set of principles or procedures according to which something is done; an organized scheme or method.
A set of rules used in measurement or classification.
Organized planning or behaviour; orderliness.
A method of choosing one's procedure in gambling.
The prevailing political or social order, especially when regarded as oppressive and intransigent.
A set of staves in a musical score joined by a brace.
--Examples--
‘the state railway system’
‘fluid is pushed through a system of pipes or channels’
‘the digestive system’
‘you need to get the cholesterol out of your system’
‘the Devonian system’
‘the system of bright stars known as the Gould Belt’
‘a multiparty system of government’
‘the public-school system’
‘the metric system’
‘there was no system at all in the company’
‘don't try bucking the system’

Nostradamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Nostradamus; resembling the work of Nostradamus; prophetic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nostradamus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1503–66), French astrologer and physician; Latinized name of Michel de Nostredame. His cryptic and apocalyptic predictions in rhyming quatrains appeared in two collections (1555; 1558). Their interpretation continues to be the subject of controversy.
--Examples--
--Word--
nostrificate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
With reference to (especially eastern) European universities: to recognize (a foreign degree).
--Examples--
--Word--
nostrification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With reference to (especially central) European universities: the action or process of recognizing foreign degrees. rare.
In Czechoslovakia: nationalization, especially the action, process, or policy of acquiring or requisitioning stock, capital, etc., held by foreign banks and nationals in order to transfer it to Czechoslovak owners. Occasionally similarly in early use with reference to Romania and Yugoslavia. Now historical.
--Examples--

--Word--
surrender 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Stop resisting to an enemy or opponent and submit to their authority.
(in sport) lose (a point, game, or advantage) to an opponent.
Give in to (a powerful emotion or influence)
Give up or hand over (a person, right, or possession), typically on compulsion or demand.
(of a person assured) cancel (a life insurance policy) and receive back a proportion of the premiums paid.
Give up (a lease) before its expiry.
The action of surrendering to an opponent or powerful influence.
The action of surrendering a lease or life insurance policy.
--Examples--
‘over 140 rebels surrendered to the authorities’
‘she surrendered only twenty games in her five qualifying matches’
‘the president has surrendered to panic and is making things worse’
‘he surrendered himself to the mood of the hills’
‘in 1815 Denmark surrendered Norway to Sweden’
‘the UK is opposed to surrendering its monetary sovereignty’
‘the final surrender of Germany on 8 May 1945’
‘the colonel was anxious to negotiate a surrender’
--Word--
not 
--Type--
adverb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Used with an auxiliary verb or ‘be’ to form the negative.
Used in some constructions with other verbs.
Used as a short substitute for a negative clause.
Used to express the negative of other words.
Used with a quantifier to exclude a person or part of a group.
No more than (used to indicate a surprisingly small quantity)
Used in understatements to suggest that the opposite of a following word or phrase is true.
Following and emphatically negating a statement.
A Boolean operator with only one variable that has the value one when the variable is zero and vice versa.
A circuit which produces an output signal only when there is not a signal on its input.
(of paper) not hot-pressed, and having a slightly textured surface.
--Examples--
‘he would not say’
‘she isn't there’
‘didn't you tell me?’
‘he has been warned not to touch’
‘the pain of not knowing’
‘she not only wrote the text but also researched the photographs’
‘maybe I'll regret it, but I hope not’
‘‘Don't you keep in touch?’ ‘I'm afraid not’’
‘they wouldn't know if I was telling the truth or not’
‘not a single attempt was made’
‘treating the symptoms and not the cause’
‘‘How was it?’ ‘Not so bad.’’
‘not all the poems are serious’
‘the brakes went on not ten feet from him’
‘the not too distant future’
‘not a million miles away’
‘that sounds like quality entertainment—not’

notalgia paraesthetica 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of sensory neuropathy characterized by itching, burning, or other abnormal sensation affecting the skin of the back in the distribution of the thoracic spinal nerves (T2 to T6).

notarikon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rabbinical and kabbalistic method of interpreting the Hebrew Scriptures by making words from letters taken from the beginning, middle, or end of the words in a sentence; (more generally) a method of forming a word in this way, or of interpreting a word as having been so constructed.

notch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An indentation or incision on an edge or surface.
Each of a series of holes for the tongue of a buckle.
A nick made on something in order to keep a score or record.

Score or achieve (something)
--Examples--
‘there was a notch in the end of the arrow for the bowstring’
‘he tightened his belt an extra notch’
‘the notches in the rail represent the number of bear sightings we have in a year’
‘her opinion of Nicole dropped a few notches’
‘he notched the stick at each end’
‘she notched her belt tighter’
‘he notched up fifteen years' service with the company’

The process of giving birth.

--Word--
note 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A brief record of points or ideas written down as an aid to memory.
A short comment on or explanation of a word or passage in a book or article; an annotation.
A short informal letter or written message.
A short official document certifying a particular thing.
An official letter sent from the representative of one government to another.
A banknote.
A written promise or notice of payment of various kinds.
A single tone of definite pitch made by a musical instrument or the human voice.
A written sign representing the pitch and duration of a musical note.
A key of a piano or similar instrument.
A bird's song or call, or a single tone in this.
A particular quality or tone that reflects or expresses a mood or attitude.
Any of the basic components of a fragrance or flavour.
Notice or pay particular attention to (something)
Remark upon (something) in order to draw attention to it.
Record (something) in writing.
--Examples--
‘I'll make a note in my diary’
‘lecture notes’
‘see note iv above’
‘I left her a note explaining where I was going’
‘you need a sick note from your doctor’
‘the Secretariat sent a diplomatic note to the embassy protesting about the sale of arms’
‘a ten-pound note’
‘a credit note’
‘the last notes of the symphony died away’
‘black notes’
‘the tawny owl has a harsh flight note’
‘there was a note of scorn in her voice’
‘the decade could have ended on an optimistic note’
‘the fresh note of bergamot’
‘he noted his mother's unusual gaiety’
‘please note that you will not receive a reminder that final payment is due’
‘we noted earlier the difficulties inherent in this strategy’
‘he noted down her address on a piece of paper’
--Word--
blind 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Unable to see because of injury, disease, or a congenital condition.
(of an action, especially a test or experiment) done without being able to see or without having relevant information.
(of flying) using instruments only.
Lacking perception, awareness, or judgement.
Not controlled by reason.
Not governed by purpose.
(of a corner or bend in a road) impossible to see round.
(of a door or window) walled up.
Closed at one end.
Not the slightest (used in emphatic expressions)
(of a plant) without buds, eyes, or terminal flowers.
Cause (someone) to be unable to see, permanently or temporarily.
Deprive (someone) of understanding, judgement, or perception.
Confuse or overawe someone with (something they do not understand)
Move very fast and dangerously.
A screen for a window, especially one on a roller or made of slats.
An awning over a shop window.
Something designed to conceal one's real intentions.
A camouflaged shelter used for observing or hunting wildlife.
A heavy drinking bout.
Without being able to see clearly.
Without having all the relevant information; unprepared.
(of a stake in poker or brag) put up by a player before the cards dealt are seen.
--Examples--
‘a blind man with a stick’
‘he was blind in one eye’
‘guide dogs for the blind’
‘a blind tasting of eight wines’
‘blind landings during foggy conditions’
‘a blind acceptance of the status quo’
‘she was blind to the realities of her position’
‘they left in blind panic’
‘a world of blind chance’
‘two trucks collided on a blind curve in the road’
‘fresco paintings on the blind windows’
‘a blind pipe’
‘this declaration is not a blind bit of good to the workers’
‘planting too shallowly is the most common cause of bulbs coming up blind’
‘the injury temporarily blinded him’
‘her eyes were blinded with scalding tears’
‘he was blinded by his faith’
‘somehow Clare and I were blinded to the truth’
‘they try to blind you with science’
‘I could see the bombs blinding along above the roof tops’
‘she pulled down the blinds’
‘he phoned again from his own home: that was just a blind for his wife’
‘a duck blind’
‘he's off on a blind again’
‘he was the first pilot in history to fly blind’
‘wines were tasted blind’
‘he was going into the interview blind’

--Word--
good 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
To be desired or approved of.
Pleasing and welcome.
Showing approval.
Having the required qualities; of a high standard.
Skilled at doing or dealing with a specified thing.
Healthy, strong, or well.
Useful, advantageous, or beneficial in effect.
Appropriate to a particular purpose.
(of language) with correct grammar and pronunciation.
Strictly adhering to or fulfilling all the principles of a particular religion or cause.
Possessing or displaying moral virtue.
Showing kindness.
Obedient to rules or conventions.
Used to address or refer to people in a courteous, patronizing, or ironic way.
Commanding respect.
Belonging or relating to a high social class.
Giving pleasure; enjoyable or satisfying.
Pleasant to look at; attractive.
(of clothes) smart and suitable for formal wear.
Thorough.
Used to emphasize that a number is at least as great as one claims.
Used to emphasize a following adjective or adverb.
Fairly large in number, amount, or size.
Valid.
Likely to provide.
Sufficient to pay for.
Used in conjunction with the name of God or a related expression as an exclamation of extreme surprise or anger.
That which is morally right; righteousness.
Benefit or advantage to someone or something.
Merchandise or possessions.
Things to be transported, as distinct from passengers.
The genuine article.
Well.

‘it's good that he's back to his old self’
‘a good quality of life’
‘Good! The more people the better!’

‘it's good to see you again’
‘the play had good reviews’
‘a good restaurant’
‘his marks are just not good enough’

‘he was good with children’
‘she's not feeling too good’
‘too much sun is not good for you’

‘she speaks good English’
‘I am the eldest of five in a good Catholic family’
‘her father was a good man’
‘it was good of you to come’

‘now is the time to have a really good clear-up’
‘have a good look around’
‘they're a good twenty years younger’
‘we had a good long hug’

--Word--
Nothofagus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of evergreen or deciduous trees of the family Fagaceae, allied to the beech but with male flowers borne singly or in threes, which are native to temperate parts of Australasia and South America and increasingly planted elsewhere; (also nothofagus) a tree of this genus.

--Word--
notice 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The fact of observing or paying attention to something.
Notification or warning of something, especially to allow preparations to be made.
A formal declaration of one's intention to end an agreement, typically one concerning employment or tenancy, at a specified time.
A displayed sheet or placard giving news or information.
A small advertisement or announcement in a newspaper or magazine.
A short published review of a new film, play, or book.
Become aware of.
Treat (someone) as worthy of recognition or attention.
Mention or remark on.
--Examples--
‘their silence did not escape my notice’
‘it has come to our notice that you have been missing school’
‘interest rates are subject to fluctuation without notice’
‘she handed in her notice’
‘his employers gave him two weeks' notice’
‘the jobs were advertised in a notice posted in the common room’
‘an obituary notice’
‘she had good notices in her first film’
‘he noticed the youths behaving suspiciously’
‘I noticed that she was looking tired’
‘they were too drunk to notice’
‘it was only last year that the singer really began to be noticed’
‘she looked so much better that Sir Charles noticed it to Lady Harriet’

A short published review of a new film, play, or book.
Become aware of.
Treat (someone) as worthy of recognition or attention.
Mention or remark on.
--Examples--
‘their silence did not escape my notice’
‘it has come to our notice that you have been missing school’
‘interest rates are subject to fluctuation without notice’
‘she handed in her notice’
‘his employers gave him two weeks' notice’
‘the jobs were advertised in a notice posted in the common room’
‘an obituary notice’
‘she had good notices in her first film’
‘he noticed the youths behaving suspiciously’
‘I noticed that she was looking tired’
‘they were too drunk to notice’
‘it was only last year that the singer really began to be noticed’
‘she looked so much better that Sir Charles noticed it to Lady Harriet’
--Word--
notify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Inform (someone) of something, typically in a formal or official manner.
Give notice of or report (something) formally or officially.
--Examples--
‘you will be notified of our decision as soon as possible’
‘they were notified that John had been taken prisoner’
‘births and deaths are required by law to be notified to the Registrar’

--Word--
note 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A brief record of points or ideas written down as an aid to memory.
A short comment on or explanation of a word or passage in a book or article; an annotation.
A short informal letter or written message.
A short official document certifying a particular thing.
An official letter sent from the representative of one government to another.
A banknote.
A written promise or notice of payment of various kinds.
A single tone of definite pitch made by a musical instrument or the human voice.
A written sign representing the pitch and duration of a musical note.
A key of a piano or similar instrument.
A bird's song or call, or a single tone in this.
A particular quality or tone that reflects or expresses a mood or attitude.
Any of the basic components of a fragrance or flavour.
Notice or pay particular attention to (something)
Remark upon (something) in order to draw attention to it.
Record (something) in writing.
--Examples--
‘I'll make a note in my diary’
‘lecture notes’
‘see note iv above’
‘I left her a note explaining where I was going’

‘a credit note’
‘the last notes of the symphony died away’
‘black notes’

‘the fresh note of bergamot’
‘he noted his mother's unusual gaiety’
‘please note that you will not receive a reminder that final payment is due’
‘we noted earlier the difficulties inherent in this strategy’
‘he noted down her address on a piece of paper’

Notre Dame 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Gothic cathedral church in Paris, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, on the Île de la Cité (an island in the Seine). It was built between 1163 and 1250 and is especially noted for its innovatory flying buttresses and sculptured facade.

not 
--Type--
adverb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Used with an auxiliary verb or ‘be’ to form the negative.
Used in some constructions with other verbs.
Used as a short substitute for a negative clause.
Used to express the negative of other words.
Used with a quantifier to exclude a person or part of a group.
No more than (used to indicate a surprisingly small quantity)
Used in understatements to suggest that the opposite of a following word or phrase is true.
Following and emphatically negating a statement.
A Boolean operator with only one variable that has the value one when the variable is zero and vice versa.
A circuit which produces an output signal only when there is not a signal on its input.
(of paper) not hot-pressed, and having a slightly textured surface.

‘he would not say’
‘she isn't there’
‘didn't you tell me?’

adverb
--Meanings--
Introducing reference to alternatives or different things, about each of which a negative statement is made. Followed by †ne, †no, or nor.
--Examples--
--Word--
nouveau 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Modern or up to date.
--Examples--
‘nouveau wines’
--Word--
nouveau riche 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
People who have recently acquired wealth, typically those perceived as ostentatious or lacking in good taste.
Relating to or characteristic of the nouveau riche.
--Examples--
‘the long-term wealthy and the nouveau riche came flocking to Saint Laurent's show’
‘the nouveau riche of today buy leather covered volumes by the metre’
‘nouveau-riche social climbers’
--Word--
nouveaux arrivés 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Persons in possession of recently acquired wealth or position; such people regarded collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
nouvelle 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or specializing in nouvelle cuisine.
--Examples--
‘nouvelle bistros’

--Meanings--

--Word--
Novatian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a schismatic sect which arose in the mid 3rd cent., led by the Roman priest Novatian and characterized by a rigorism according to which the Church had no power to absolve Christians who had apostasized, or committed other serious offences.
Of, relating to, or following the precepts of Novatian or the Novatians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Novatianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rigorist doctrines and practices of the Novatians; the Novatian movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
Novatianist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= Novatian.
--Examples--
--Word--
novation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The substitution of a new contract in place of an old one.

--Meanings--

--Word--
novel 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A fictitious prose narrative of book length, typically representing character and action with some degree of realism.
The literary genre represented or exemplified by novels.
Interestingly new or unusual.
--Examples--
‘the novels of Jane Austen’
‘a paperback novel’
‘the novel is the most adaptable of all literary forms’
‘he hit on a novel idea to solve his financial problems’

--Word--
Novello, Ivor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1951), Welsh composer, songwriter, actor, and playwright; born David Ivor Davies. His song ‘Keep the Home Fires Burning’ (1914) became one of the most popular songs of the First World War.
--Examples--

--Word--
novelty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being new, original, or unusual.
A new or unfamiliar thing or experience.
Denoting an object intended to be amusing as a result of its unusual design.
A small and inexpensive toy or ornament.
--Examples--
‘the novelty of being a married woman wore off’
‘in 1914 air travel was still a novelty’
‘a novelty teapot’
‘he bought chocolate novelties to decorate the Christmas tree’

--Word--
November 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The eleventh month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the last month of autumn.
A code word representing the letter N, used in radio communication.
--Examples--
‘the shop opened in November’
‘he hasn't played for England since last November’
--Word--
Novemberish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of November; dismal, gloomy.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
Novgorod 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north-western Russia, on the Volkhov River at the northern tip of Lake Ilmen; population 214,400 (est. 2009). Russia's oldest city, it was settled by the Varangian chief Rurik in 862 and ruled by Alexander Nevsky between 1238 and 1263, when it was an important centre of medieval eastern Europe.
--Examples--
--Word--
Novi Sad 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in Serbia, on the River Danube, capital of the autonomous province of Vojvodina; population 197,900 (est. 2008).
--Examples--

Novial 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
novice 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person new to and inexperienced in a job or situation.
An animal, especially a racehorse, that has not yet won a major prize or reached a sufficient level of performance to qualify for important events.
A person who has entered a religious order and is under probation, before taking vows.
--Examples--
‘he was a complete novice in foreign affairs’
‘last season as a novice he won three races’
‘the novice hurdles’
--Word--
novicehood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being a novice.

novobiocin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A weakly acidic tetracyclic phenol, C₃₁H₃₆N₂O₁₁, that is produced by certain actinomycetes of the genus Streptomyces and is used in treating infections caused by bacteria resistant to less toxic antibiotics.
--Examples--

novodamus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A charter containing) a clause by which a feudal superior renews a former grant (now specifically with an alteration or correction). Also as "charter (clause,etc.) of novodamus".
--Examples--

Novosibirsk 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
Novotný, Antonín 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–75), Czechoslovak communist statesman, president 1957–68. A founder member of the Czechoslovak Communist Party (1921), he played a major part in the communist seizure of power in 1948. He was ousted by the reform movement in 1968.
--Examples--
--Word--
Porto Novo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Benin, a port on the Gulf of Guinea close to the border with Nigeria; population 255,878 (2006). It was a centre of the Portuguese slave trade.
--Examples--

--Word--
now 
--Type--
adverb, conjunction, adjective
--Meanings--
At the present time or moment.
At the time directly following the present moment; immediately.
Under the present circumstances; as a result of something that has recently happened.
On this further occasion, typically as the latest in a series of annoying situations or events.
Used to emphasize a particular length of time.
(in a narrative or account of past events) at the time spoken of or referred to.
Used, especially in conversation, to draw attention to a particular statement or point in a narrative.
Used in a request, instruction, or question, typically to give a slight emphasis to one's words.
Used when pausing or considering one's next words.
Used at the end of an ironic question echoing a previous statement.
As a consequence of the fact.
Fashionable or up to date.
--Examples--
‘where are you living now?’
‘it's the most popular style of jazz right now’
‘not now, I'm late’
‘they should be back by now’
‘if we leave now we can be home by ten’
‘I'd rather do it now than leave it till later’
‘it is now clear that we should not pursue this policy’
‘I didn't receive the letter, but it hardly matters now’
‘what do you want now?’
‘they've been married four years now’
‘she was nineteen now, and she was alone’
‘now, my first impulse was to run away’
‘I don't like Scotch. Now, if it had been Irish Whiskey you'd offered me’
‘we can hardly send her back, now can we?’
‘run along now’
‘let me see now, oh yes, I remember’
‘‘Mum says you might let me have some of your stamps.’ ‘Does she now?’’
‘they spent a lot of time together now that he had retired’
‘now you mention it, I haven't seen her around for ages’
‘see more of what's now during our autumn catwalk show’
--Word--
now 
--Type--
adverb, conjunction, adjective
--Meanings--
At the present time or moment.
At the time directly following the present moment; immediately.
Under the present circumstances; as a result of something that has recently happened.
On this further occasion, typically as the latest in a series of annoying situations or events.
Used to emphasize a particular length of time.
(in a narrative or account of past events) at the time spoken of or referred to.
Used, especially in conversation, to draw attention to a particular statement or point in a narrative.
Used in a request, instruction, or question, typically to give a slight emphasis to one's words.
Used when pausing or considering one's next words.
Used at the end of an ironic question echoing a previous statement.
As a consequence of the fact.
Fashionable or up to date.
--Examples--
‘where are you living now?’
‘it's the most popular style of jazz right now’
‘not now, I'm late’
‘they should be back by now’
‘if we leave now we can be home by ten’
‘I'd rather do it now than leave it till later’
‘it is now clear that we should not pursue this policy’
‘I didn't receive the letter, but it hardly matters now’
‘what do you want now?’
‘they've been married four years now’
‘she was nineteen now, and she was alone’
‘now, my first impulse was to run away’
‘I don't like Scotch. Now, if it had been Irish Whiskey you'd offered me’
‘we can hardly send her back, now can we?’
‘run along now’
‘let me see now, oh yes, I remember’
‘‘Mum says you might let me have some of your stamps.’ ‘Does she now?’’
‘they spent a lot of time together now that he had retired’
‘now you mention it, I haven't seen her around for ages’
‘see more of what's now during our autumn catwalk show’

nowaday 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Nowadays.
Of or belonging to the present day, contemporary.
The present time. rare.
--Examples--

--Word--
being 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Existence.
Being alive; living.
The nature or essence of a person.
A real or imaginary living creature or entity, especially an intelligent one.
--Examples--
‘the railway brought many towns into being’
‘the single market came into being in 1993’
‘holism promotes a unified way of being’
‘sometimes one aspect of our being has been developed at the expense of the others’
‘alien beings’
‘a rational being’
--Word--
now 
--Type--
adverb, conjunction, adjective
--Meanings--
At the present time or moment.
At the time directly following the present moment; immediately.
Under the present circumstances; as a result of something that has recently happened.
On this further occasion, typically as the latest in a series of annoying situations or events.
Used to emphasize a particular length of time.
(in a narrative or account of past events) at the time spoken of or referred to.
Used, especially in conversation, to draw attention to a particular statement or point in a narrative.
Used in a request, instruction, or question, typically to give a slight emphasis to one's words.
Used when pausing or considering one's next words.
Used at the end of an ironic question echoing a previous statement.
As a consequence of the fact.
Fashionable or up to date.
--Examples--
‘where are you living now?’
‘it's the most popular style of jazz right now’
‘not now, I'm late’
‘they should be back by now’
‘if we leave now we can be home by ten’
‘I'd rather do it now than leave it till later’
‘it is now clear that we should not pursue this policy’
‘I didn't receive the letter, but it hardly matters now’
‘what do you want now?’
‘they've been married four years now’
‘she was nineteen now, and she was alone’
‘now, my first impulse was to run away’
‘I don't like Scotch. Now, if it had been Irish Whiskey you'd offered me’
‘we can hardly send her back, now can we?’
‘run along now’
‘let me see now, oh yes, I remember’
‘‘Mum says you might let me have some of your stamps.’ ‘Does she now?’’
‘they spent a lot of time together now that he had retired’
‘now you mention it, I haven't seen her around for ages’
‘see more of what's now during our autumn catwalk show’
--Word--
borne 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
Carried or transported by the thing specified.
--Examples--
‘waterborne bacteria’

--Word--
ply 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thickness or layer of a folded or laminated material.
A strand of yarn or rope.
The number of multiple layers or strands of which something is made.
A reinforcing layer of fabric in a tyre.
(in game theory) the number of levels at which branching occurs in a tree of possible outcomes, typically corresponding to the number of moves ahead (in chess strictly half-moves ahead) considered by a computer program.
A half-move (i.e. one player's move) in computer chess.
Work steadily with (a tool)
Work steadily at (one's business or trade)
(of a vessel or vehicle) travel regularly over a route, typically for commercial purposes.
Regularly travel over (a route)
Provide someone with (food or drink) in a continuous or insistent way.
Direct (numerous questions) at someone.
--Examples--
‘tiles that have a black PVC ply in the lamination’
‘four-ply yarn’
‘the yarn can be any ply from two to eight’
‘a six-ply whitewall tire’
‘a tailor delicately plying his needle’
‘for three years he plied a profitable export trade between England and Australia’
‘ferries ply across a strait to the island’
‘the fleet has plied the Bristol Channel since Victorian times’
‘she plied me with tea and scones’
‘she plied him with questions about his visit’

vis-à-vis 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
In relation to; with regard to.
As compared with; as opposed to.
In a position facing a specified or implied subject.
A person or group occupying a corresponding position to that of another in a different sphere; a counterpart.
A face-to-face meeting.
--Examples--
‘many agencies now have a unit to deal with women's needs vis-à-vis employment’
‘the advantage for US exports is the value of the dollar vis-à-vis other currencies’
‘he was there vis-à-vis with Miss Arundel’
‘his admiration for the US armed services extends to their vis-à-vis, the Russian military’
‘the dreaded vis-à-vis with his boss’

Stubby or lumpy.
--Examples--
‘nubby blue cotton’
‘the nubby points of the new leaves’
--Word--
nubecula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Astronomy. In form Nubecula. (The name of) either of the Magellanic Clouds.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nubia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient region of southern Egypt and northern Sudan, including the Nile valley between Aswan and Khartoum and the surrounding area. Much of Nubia is now drowned by the waters of Lake Nasser, formed by the building of the two dams at Aswan. Nubians constitute an ethnic minority group in Egypt.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nubian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Nubia, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Nubia.
The Nilo-Saharan language spoken by the Nubians.
A goat of a short-haired breed with long pendant ears and long legs, originally from Africa.

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
nucleolysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pathology and Biochemistry. The disintegration, dissolution, or disruption of cell nuclei; karyolysis. Also: the breakdown of nucleic acid molecules, especially by enzymatic activity.
Surgery. The destruction of a nucleus in the central nervous system. rare.
Surgery and Medicine. Destruction of the nucleus pulposus of an intervertebral disc, especially by the injection of an enzyme or chemical. Compare earlier chemonucleolysis.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

nucleosidase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any enzyme that catalyses the hydrolysis of a nucleoside into its constituent base and sugar. Also: any of various other enzymes involved in the catabolism of nucleosides or nucleoside-containing compounds.

--Examples--
--Word--
nucleus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The central and most important part of an object, movement, or group, forming the basis for its activity and growth.
The positively charged central core of an atom, consisting of protons and neutrons and containing nearly all its mass.
A dense organelle present in most eukaryotic cells, typically a single rounded structure bounded by a double membrane, containing the genetic material.
A discrete mass of grey matter in the central nervous system.
The solid part of a comet's head.
--Examples--
‘the nucleus of a British film-producing industry’
--Word--
nucleus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The central and most important part of an object, movement, or group, forming the basis for its activity and growth.
The positively charged central core of an atom, consisting of protons and neutrons and containing nearly all its mass.
A dense organelle present in most eukaryotic cells, typically a single rounded structure bounded by a double membrane, containing the genetic material.
A discrete mass of grey matter in the central nervous system.
The solid part of a comet's head.
--Examples--
‘the nucleus of a British film-producing industry’

--Word--
nucule 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †each of the seeds in a nuculanium (obsolete). Later: a small nut or nutlet; a section of a compound (usually hard) fruit; a nut borne in an involucre. Now rare.
The female reproductive structure (oogonium) of a charophyte.
--Examples--
--Word--
nuculoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: of, relating to, or resembling bivalve molluscs of a type represented by the nut shell Nucula. In later use: specifically of, relating to, or designating protobranch bivalve molluscs of the order Nuculoida, which includes mainly deposit-feeding species attested in the fossil record from the Ordovician period onwards, and often regarded as among the most primitive extant bivalves.
A nuculoid mollusc.

nude 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Wearing no clothes; naked.
Depicting or performed by naked people.
Denoting or relating to clothing or makeup that is of a colour resembling that of the wearer’s skin.
Of a pale pinkish-beige colour.
A naked human figure, typically as the subject of a painting, sculpture, or photograph.
A colour of clothing or make-up resembling that of the wearer's skin.
A pale pinkish-beige colour.
--Examples--
‘a painting of a nude model’
‘she won't do any nude scenes’
‘a nude camisole under a sheer blouse’
‘balance the intensity of the eyes with a soft lip color in a nude shade’
‘nude tights’
‘a study of a kneeling nude’
‘the nude was regarded as the ultimate test of artistic skill’
‘sheer lip colour in all shades of nude’
‘silks in ivory, nude, and shimmering silver’

--Word--
nudge 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Prod (someone) gently with one's elbow in order to attract attention.
Touch or push (something) gently or gradually.
Coax or gently encourage (someone) to do something.
Approach (an age, figure, or level) very closely.
A light touch or push.
--Examples--
‘people were nudging each other and pointing at me’
‘the canoe nudged a bank of reeds’
‘we have to nudge the politicians in the right direction’
‘both men were nudging fifty’
‘he gave her shoulder a nudge’
‘she appreciated the nudge to her memory’

nomen nudum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Latin name which was introduced without publication of an adequate description of the organism to which it was intended to be applied, or otherwise fails to conform to the appropriate code of biological nomenclature, and is therefore not available or valid as a result of that introduction. Occasionally: a vernacular name that cannot be attached to any species.

Nueces River

nuevo sol 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
Nuffield, 1st Viscount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1877–1963), British motor manufacturer and philanthropist; born William Richard Morris. After working as a mechanic on bicycles and motorcycles he opened the first Morris automobile factory in Oxford in 1912. He endowed Nuffield College, Oxford (1937) and created the Nuffield Foundation (1943) for medical, social, and scientific research.

--Word--
nuisance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing causing inconvenience or annoyance.
An act which is harmful or offensive to the public or a member of it and for which there is a legal remedy.
--Examples--
‘it's a nuisance having all those people clomping through the house’
‘I hope you're not going to make a nuisance of yourself’

--Word--
null 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Having no legal or binding force; invalid.
Having or associated with the value zero.
(of a set or matrix) having no elements, or only zeros as elements.
Lacking distinctive qualities; having no positive substance or content.
A zero.
A dummy letter in a cipher.
A condition of no signal.
A direction in which no electromagnetic radiation is detected or emitted.
Combine (a signal) with another in order to create a null; cancel out.
--Examples--
‘the establishment of a new interim government was declared null and void’
‘his curiously null life’
‘the tumour can be more readily identified by nulling the high signal from bone marrow’

nullisomic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating, relating to, or characterized by the condition of having an aneuploid chromosome complement lacking a particular pair or polyploid set of homologous chromosomes. Also (of a gamete): lacking a chromosome; producing a nullisomic individual.
A nullisomic individual or variety.

--Word--
manifold 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Many and various.
Having many different forms or elements.
A pipe or chamber branching into several openings.
(in an internal combustion engine) the part conveying air and fuel from the carburettor to the cylinders or that leading from the cylinders to the exhaust pipe.
A collection of points forming a certain kind of set, such as those of a topologically closed surface or an analogue of this in three or more dimensions.
(in Kantian philosophy) the sum of the particulars furnished by sense before they have been unified by the synthesis of the understanding.
--Examples--
‘the implications of this decision were manifold’
‘the appeal of the crusade was manifold’
‘US aircraft attacked the pipeline manifold feeding the Sea Island’
‘the exhaust manifold’
--Word--
nullo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cards.(a) A contract in some varieties of bridge and in certain other card games, in which the object is to win no tricks or to prevent the contract from being made. (b) In some varieties of contract bridge: each of the tricks beyond a total of six which a bidder can undertake to lose, when play is conducted in no trumps. Also in plural: (play in) no trumps when such a contract has been made.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
number 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An arithmetical value, expressed by a word, symbol, or figure, representing a particular quantity and used in counting and making calculations.
A figure or group of figures used to identify someone or something.
Arithmetic.
A quantity or amount.
Several.
A group or company of people.
A large quantity or amount, often in contrast to a smaller one; numerical preponderance.
A single issue of a magazine.
A song, dance, piece of music, etc., especially one of several in a performance.
An item of clothing of a particular type, regarded with approval or admiration.
A grammatical classification of words that consists typically of singular and plural, and, in Greek and certain other languages, dual.
Amount to (a specified figure or quantity); comprise.
Mark with a number or assign a number to, typically to indicate position in a series.
Count.
Include or classify as a member of a group.
--Examples--
‘think of a number from one to ten and multiply it by three’
‘even numbers’
‘she picked up the phone and dialled his home number’
‘the boy was adept at numbers’
‘the company is seeking to increase the number of women on its staff’
‘the exhibition attracted vast numbers of visitors’
‘we have discussed the matter on a number of occasions’
‘there were some distinguished names among our number’
‘the weight of numbers turned the battle against them’
‘the October number of ‘Travel’’
‘they go from one melodious number to another’
‘Yvonne was wearing a little black number’
‘the form of English pronouns reflects their number and gender’
‘the demonstrators numbered more than 5,000’
‘each document was numbered consecutively’
‘strategies like ours can be numbered on the fingers of one hand’
‘the orchestra numbers Brahms among its past conductors’

--Examples--
--Word--
numerator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The number above the line in a vulgar fraction showing how many of the parts indicated by the denominator are taken, for example, 2 in 2/3.
--Examples--
--Word--
numerator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The number above the line in a vulgar fraction showing how many of the parts indicated by the denominator are taken, for example, 2 in 2/3.

adjective

--Word--
Numidia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient kingdom, later a Roman province, situated in North Africa in an area north of the Sahara corresponding roughly to present-day Algeria.
--Examples--

Numidian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Numidia, an ancient kingdom situated in North Africa, or its inhabitants.

‘the military was dominated by Numidians’

nummulite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The flat disc-shaped calcareous shell of a foraminiferan (single-celled planktonic animal), found commonly as a fossil up to 8 cm across in marine Tertiary deposits.
--Examples--
--Word--
nummulite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The flat disc-shaped calcareous shell of a foraminiferan (single-celled planktonic animal), found commonly as a fossil up to 8 cm across in marine Tertiary deposits.
--Examples--
--Word--
nummulitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing or consisting of nummulites; especially designating an Eocene limestone formation which outcrops widely from North Africa and the Alps to east Asia.

--Examples--
--Word--
nunation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Semitic Grammar. Now usually in form nunation. The addition of a final n-sound to the pronunciation of the indefinite forms of certain nouns and adjectives in Arabic; (also) the appending of n to the flectional vowels of other Semitic languages.
Usually in form nunnation. In extended use: the addition of a final n to an inflection in another language, e.g. Middle English. Also (frequently attributive, especially in "nunnation mark"): the insertion of a nasal consonant after a vowel.

--Examples--
--Word--
nunc stans 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Eternity or eternal existence, especially as an attribute of God, conceived not as infinite temporal duration but as a form of existence not subject to the limitations of time, and hence involving neither change nor succession. Also occasionally in extended use, especially with reference to mystical experience.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Semitic Grammar. Now usually in form nunation. The addition of a final n-sound to the pronunciation of the indefinite forms of certain nouns and adjectives in Arabic; (also) the appending of n to the flectional vowels of other Semitic languages.

--Examples--
--Word--
Balboa, Vasco Núñez de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1475–1519), Spanish explorer. In 1513 he reached the western coast of the isthmus of Darien (Panama), thereby becoming the first European to see the eastern shores of the Pacific Ocean.

Nuphar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of water lilies of Eurasia and eastern North America (family Nymphaeaceae), having yellow or purple flowers usually held above the water; (also nuphar) a water lily of this genus, especially the yellow water lily, Nuphar luteum.

--Word--
nerd 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A foolish or contemptible person who lacks social skills or is boringly studious.
A single-minded expert in a particular technical field.
--Examples--
‘I was a serious nerd until I discovered girls and cars’
‘a computer nerd’
--Word--
Nureyev, Rudolf 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1939–93), Russian-born ballet dancer and choreographer. He defected to the West in 1961, joining the Royal Ballet in London, where he began his noted partnership with Margot Fonteyn. He became a naturalized Austrian citizen in 1982.
--Examples--
--Word--
Nuremberg 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern Germany, in Bavaria; population 500,900 (est. 2006). In the 1930s the Nazi Party congresses and annual rallies were held in the city and in 1945–6 it was the scene of the Nuremberg war trials, in which Nazi war criminals were tried by international military tribunal.
--Examples--

To shrivel, shrink; to pinch with the cold.

--Word--
nurser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which nurses (someone or something).
North American. An infant's feeding bottle; a nursing bottle.
--Examples--
--Word--
nurse 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A person trained to care for the sick or infirm, especially in a hospital.
A person employed or trained to take charge of young children.
A wet nurse.
A worker bee, ant, or other social insect, caring for a young brood.
A tree or crop planted as a shelter to others.
Give medical and other attention to (a sick person)
Work as a nurse.
Try to cure or alleviate (an injury, injured part, or illness) by treating it carefully and protectively.
Hold closely and carefully or caressingly.
Hold (a drink), sipping it occasionally.
Harbour (a belief or feeling), especially for a long time.
Take special care of, especially to promote development or well-being.
Feed (a baby) at the breast.
Be fed at the breast.
Be brought up in (a specified condition)
Try to play strokes which keep (the balls) close together.
A greyish Australian shark of shallow inshore waters.
--Examples--
‘a team of doctors and nurses’
‘a psychiatric nurse’
‘her mother's old nurse’
‘these plants grow beneath nurse trees such as oak’
‘he was gradually nursed back to health’
‘she nursed at the hospital for thirty years’
‘he has been nursing a cold’
‘he nursed his hurt pride’
‘he nursed his small case on his lap’
‘I nursed a double brandy’
‘he still nursed a secret desire to try and make amends’
‘our political unity needs to be protected and nursed’
‘the women nursed their babies’
‘lionesses who were nursing their own cubs’
‘the baby snuffled as he nursed’
‘he was nursed in the lap of plenty’
--Word--
nurse-child 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A child cared for by a nurse, especially a wet nurse; a foster-child. Also (euphemism): an illegitimate child. Occasionally figurative.
--Examples--

A place where young children are cared for during the working day; a nursery school.
An institution or environment in which certain types of people or qualities are fostered or bred.
A place or natural habitat which breeds or supports animals.
Denoting a race for two-year-old horses.
A place where young plants and trees are grown for sale or for planting elsewhere.
--Examples--
‘a toy-strewn nursery’
‘toys and nursery furniture’
‘that nursery of traitors’
‘this estuary provides a vast nursery for fish’
‘a six-furlong nursery handicap’
‘the plants are available from specialist nurseries’
‘tree nursery’

nurse 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A person trained to care for the sick or infirm, especially in a hospital.
A person employed or trained to take charge of young children.
A wet nurse.
A worker bee, ant, or other social insect, caring for a young brood.
A tree or crop planted as a shelter to others.
Give medical and other attention to (a sick person)
Work as a nurse.
Try to cure or alleviate (an injury, injured part, or illness) by treating it carefully and protectively.
Hold closely and carefully or caressingly.
Hold (a drink), sipping it occasionally.
Harbour (a belief or feeling), especially for a long time.
Take special care of, especially to promote development or well-being.
Feed (a baby) at the breast.
Be fed at the breast.
Be brought up in (a specified condition)
Try to play strokes which keep (the balls) close together.
A greyish Australian shark of shallow inshore waters.
--Examples--
‘a team of doctors and nurses’
‘a psychiatric nurse’
‘her mother's old nurse’
‘these plants grow beneath nurse trees such as oak’
‘he was gradually nursed back to health’
‘she nursed at the hospital for thirty years’
‘he has been nursing a cold’
‘he nursed his hurt pride’
‘he nursed his small case on his lap’
‘I nursed a double brandy’
‘he still nursed a secret desire to try and make amends’
‘our political unity needs to be protected and nursed’
‘the women nursed their babies’
‘lionesses who were nursing their own cubs’
‘the baby snuffled as he nursed’
‘he was nursed in the lap of plenty’

--Word--
nurture 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Care for and protect (someone or something) while they are growing.
Help or encourage the development of.
Cherish (a hope, belief, or ambition)
The action or process of nurturing someone or something.
Upbringing, education, and environment, contrasted with inborn characteristics as an influence on or determinant of personality.
--Examples--
‘Jarrett was nurtured by his parents in a close-knit family’
‘my father nurtured my love of art’
‘for a long time she had nurtured the dream of buying a shop’
‘the nurture of children’
‘we are all what nature and nurture have made us’

A fruit consisting of a hard or tough shell around an edible kernel.

The part at the lower end of the bow of a violin or similar instrument, with a screw for adjusting the tension of the hair.
A crazy or eccentric person.
A person who is excessively interested in or enthusiastic about a specified thing.
A person's head.
A man's testicles.
The fixed ridge on the neck of a stringed instrument over which the strings pass.
Butt (someone) with one's head.
Gather nuts.

nutation

noun

--Word--
hook 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of metal or other hard material curved or bent back at an angle, for catching hold of or hanging things on.
A bent piece of metal, typically barbed and baited, for catching fish.
A thing designed to catch people's attention.
A catchy chorus or repeated instrumental passage in a piece of popular music.
A curved cutting instrument, especially as used for reaping or shearing.
A short swinging punch made with the elbow bent and rigid, especially in boxing.
A stroke made to the on side with a horizontal or slightly upward swing of the bat at shoulder height.
A stroke that makes the ball deviate in flight in the direction of the follow-through (from right to left for a right-handed player), typically inadvertently.
A curved stroke in handwriting.
An added stroke transverse to the stem in the symbol for a quaver or other note.
A curved promontory or sand spit.
Attach or fasten with a hook or hooks.
Bend into the shape of a hook so as to fasten around or to an object.
Catch with a hook.
Attract and hold the attention of; captivate.
Steal.
Hit (the ball) round to the on side with a horizontal or slightly upward swing of the bat at shoulder height; hit a ball delivered by (the bowler) with such a stroke.
Strike (the ball) so that it deviates in the direction of the follow-through, typically inadvertently.
Punch one's opponent with the elbow bent and rigid.
Secure (the ball) and pass it backwards with the foot in the scrum.
Run away.
(of a woman) work as a prostitute.
--Examples--
‘a picture hook’
‘companies are looking for a sales hook’
‘strong, funky vocals with a hook that gets into your head’
‘a perfectly timed right hook to the chin’
‘the truck had a red lamp hooked to its tailgate’
‘she tried to hook up her bra’
‘a ladder that hooks over the roof ridge’
‘he hooked his thumbs in his belt’
‘she hooked a thread around her crochet hook’
‘her legs hooked around mine’
‘he hooked a 24 lb pike’
‘I was hooked by John's radical zeal’
‘a maid hooked one of her mistress's dresses’
‘McKenzie switched his attack downstairs, hooking to the ribs’
‘kindly hook it—I just want you to scram’

--Word--
oil-nut 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "oil-nut tree". Any of various trees or shrubs that produce oil-rich nuts or large seeds; specifically (a) the castor oil plant, Ricinus communis; (b) the butternut, Juglans cinerea; (c) the buffalo-nut, Pyrularia pubera; (d) the oil palm, Elaeis guineensis.
The nut or large seed of such a plant.

--Meanings--
Having the pleasant taste characteristic of sugar or honey; not salt, sour, or bitter.
(of air, water, or food) fresh, pure, and untainted.
Smelling pleasant like flowers or perfume; fragrant.
Pleasing in general; delightful.
Highly satisfying or gratifying.
Used in expressions of assent or approval.
Working, moving, or done smoothly or easily.
(of sound) melodious or harmonious.
Denoting music, especially jazz, played at a steady tempo without improvisation.
(of a person or action) pleasant and kind or thoughtful.
Charming and endearing.
Infatuated or in love with.
Dear; beloved.
Used as a respectful form of address.
Used for emphasis in various phrases and exclamations.
A small shaped piece of confectionery made with sugar.
A sweet dish forming a course of a meal; a pudding or dessert.
Used as an affectionate form of address.
The sweet part or element of something.
The pleasures or delights found in something.
--Examples--
‘a cup of hot sweet tea’
‘lungfuls of the clean, sweet air’
‘a bunch of sweet-scented flowers’
‘it was the sweet life he had always craved’
‘some sweet, short-lived revenge’
‘Yeah, I'd like to come to the party. Sweet!’
‘the sweet handling of this motorcycle’
‘the sweet notes of the flute’
‘a very sweet nurse came along’
‘it was sweet of you to come’
‘a sweet little cat’
‘she seemed quite sweet on him’
‘my sweet love’
‘go to thy rest, sweet sir’
‘What had happened? Sweet nothing’
‘a bag of sweets’
‘hello, my sweet’
‘you have had the bitter, now comes the sweet’
‘the sweets of office’
--Word--
tapper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
nut 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fruit consisting of a hard or tough shell around an edible kernel.
The hard kernel of a nut.
A small lump of something hard or solid, especially coal.
A small flat piece of metal or other material, typically square or hexagonal, with a threaded hole through it for screwing on to a bolt as a fastener.
The part at the lower end of the bow of a violin or similar instrument, with a screw for adjusting the tension of the hair.
A crazy or eccentric person.
A person who is excessively interested in or enthusiastic about a specified thing.
A person's head.
A man's testicles.
The fixed ridge on the neck of a stringed instrument over which the strings pass.
Butt (someone) with one's head.
Gather nuts.
--Examples--
‘he was cracking nuts with his teeth’
‘savoury snacks like crisps and nuts’
‘fix the new pipe and tighten the nuts’
‘the final wheel nut was tightened’
‘she would have written me off as a time-wasting nut’
‘a football nut’
‘he's aiming to break a record by balancing a car on his nut’
‘the positioning allows the strings a straight path over the nut’
‘I thought he was going to nut me in the face’

--Meanings--

nuttery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place in which nut trees grow or are raised.
US slang. A psychiatric hospital.

--Word--
nutty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tasting like nuts.
Containing a lot of nuts.
Mad.
--Examples--
‘wild rice has a very nutty flavour’
‘a nutty vegetable bake’
‘he came up with a few nutty proposals’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
nut tree 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree that bears nuts, especially the hazel.
--Examples--
--Word--
nut weevil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various weevils (beetles of the family Curculionidae), mainly of the genus Curculio, affecting nut-bearing trees or shrubs; especially a small yellow-scaled weevil, Curculio nucum, which deposits its eggs in green hazelnuts and filbert nuts.
--Examples--
--Word--
nut-wood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Wood from a nut-bearing tree, especially a hickory or walnut.
Australian the tree Terminalia arostrata (family Combretaceae) of northern Australia, having a fruit with an edible seed.
--Examples--
--Word--
nu- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Informal respelling of ‘new’, used especially in names of new or revived genres of popular music.
--Examples--
‘nu-metal bands’
‘nu-disco’
--Word--
nuzzle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Rub or push against gently with the nose and mouth.
Snuggle up to.
--Examples--
‘he nuzzled her hair’
‘the foal nuzzled at its mother’
‘she nuzzled up against me’
